headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Brent, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax Fourth Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.I would now like to turn the ca
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Brent, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax Fourth Quarter Earnings Release Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you.
I would now like to turn the call over to Katharine Kenny, Vice President, Investor Relations. Please go ahead.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi. Thank you, and good morning. Thanks for joining our Fourth Quarter and Year-end Earnings Conference Call. On the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our CEO; Bill Nash, our President; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.Before we be
componenttext:
Hi. Thank you, and good morning. Thanks for joining our Fourth Quarter and Year-end Earnings Conference Call. On the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our CEO; Bill Nash, our President; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them. For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 28, 2015, with the SEC. And we will be filing our most recent 10-K shortly.
[Operator Instructions] Thank you.
Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us.We had a very solid year in fiscal 2016, where total revenues grew to more than $15 billion. And we sold over 1 million vehicles total both in retail and wholesale for the first time ev
componenttext:
Thank you, Katharine. Good morning, everyone. Thanks for joining us.
We had a very solid year in fiscal 2016, where total revenues grew to more than $15 billion. And we sold over 1 million vehicles total both in retail and wholesale for the first time ever, about 620,000 used cars and about 395,000 wholesale cars, while still -- while also delivering double-digit EPS growth for the year. Some key drivers for the year: Used unit comps increased by 2.4%. Total used units grew a little over 6.5%. Wholesale units grew by 4.9%. CAF income, up 6.7% to more than $392 million. Net income for fiscal '16, up 4.4% to $623 million; and EPS, up 11% to $3.03. Proceeds from our legal settlement benefited our fiscal 2015 net income by $12.9 million or $0.06 a share. Our data for the year indicates that, for calendar year 2015, we increased our share of the 0- to 10-year-old used vehicles by approximately 1%. And we continued to focus on returning value to our shareholders through our stock repurchase program. During the year, we bought back 16.3 million shares at a cost of $971 million.
For the fourth quarter, used unit comps increased by 0.7%, driven by an improvement in conversion. And total used units grew by 4%. Our total web traffic increased by 11%. Total wholesale units, up 2.3%. CAF quarterly income grew by 2.2% to $92 million. Net income for the fourth quarter declined by 1.5% to $141 million, and EPS rose 6% to $0.71 a share. Remember that the impairment-related charge in this quarter reduced our net income by $5.2 million or $0.03 a share, while in the previous year's fourth quarter, net income was increased by the adjustment to capitalized interest expense of $4.2 million or $0.02 a share.
I'll now turn it over to Tom Reedy to give you some details around CAF. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody.As Tom mentioned, CAF income grew by 2% compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015, and average managed receivables grew by 14% to $9.5 billion. For loans originated during the quarter, the weighted average contra
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody.
As Tom mentioned, CAF income grew by 2% compared to the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015, and average managed receivables grew by 14% to $9.5 billion. For loans originated during the quarter, the weighted average contract rate charged to customers was 7.5%, up from 7.2% in last year's fourth quarter. Total interest margin declined to 5.9% of average managed receivables compared to 6.3% in the fourth quarter last year and 6% last quarter. For the quarter, charge-offs and loss provision were in line with our expectations. The year-over-year increase in loss provision reflects both the favorability we commented on in last year's fourth quarter and the growth in receivables. Our ending allowance for loan losses at $95 million was 0.99% of managed receivables compared to 0.97% in last year's fourth quarter.
CAF net penetration was 41.7% compared to 40.9% in last year's fourth quarter. This increase reflects the mix of applications in the stores, where we continued to see growth at the higher end of the credit spectrum and less volume at the lower end. Net loan dollars originated in the quarter rose 7% year-over-year to $1.3 billion. That's due to a combination of the growth in CarMax sales and our higher penetration at CAF. Percent of CAF penetration attributable to our subprime test was similar to last year, 0.7% versus 0.6% of sales in the prior year. As mentioned in the press release, we are comfortable and plan to continue to originate these loans at the same pace, a targeted volume of 5% of CarMax' overall Tier 3 sales. Tier 3 financing as a percent of sales was 15.1% compared to 17% in the fourth quarter of fiscal 2015, largely due to the reduced volume of lower-credit applications I mentioned earlier. In Q4, we continued to experience a year-over-year decline in the number of credit applications across the lower end of the credit spectrum and moderate growth at the high end.
During the fourth quarter, we repurchased 3 million shares for about $156 million. For the fiscal year, as Tom said, we repurchased 16.3 million shares. And since inception of the program, we've repurchased 46.4 million shares. At the end of FY '16, we had 1.4 billion remaining under the current authorization.
Now I'll turn the call over to Bill.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everyone.As a percentage of our sales mix this quarter, 0- to 4-year-old vehicles increased to approximately 77% compared to 75% in the fourth quarter of last year. Mid-size, large SUVs and trucks as a percentage of sales were
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everyone.
As a percentage of our sales mix this quarter, 0- to 4-year-old vehicles increased to approximately 77% compared to 75% in the fourth quarter of last year. Mid-size, large SUVs and trucks as a percentage of sales were flat, approximately 24% in both this year and last year's fourth quarter, which is up slightly from 23% in the third quarter. SG&A for the fourth quarter increased about 1% to $334 million. This growth reflects the 10% or 15-store increase in our store base since the beginning of the fourth quarter of last year, largely offset by a decrease of $14 million or $97 per unit in share-based compensation expense.
During the fourth quarter, we opened 5 stores. 3 were in new markets, 2 in Boston and 1 in Peoria, Illinois. We also opened our sixth store in Atlanta and a third store in St. Louis. In the first quarter, we expect to open 2 new stores in new markets, Springfield, Illinois and our first store in San Francisco.
Before I turn it back over to Tom, I want to take a minute to talk about how it's an exciting time for CarMax. Looking back over the past 23 years, we couldn't be more proud of the progress that we've made. Our store base has grown to 158 stores. And as Tom mentioned earlier, we sold over 1 million vehicles this fiscal year for the first time ever. Our customers continue to give us high marks for excellent customer service, and we have a world-class culture. We continue to execute our growth plan and currently plan to open 15 stores in fiscal 2017 while also focusing on returning value to our shareholders through our share repurchase plan. But we are never satisfied, and for those of you who have followed us for a long time, you know that this is the case.
For our customers, we have to be able to meet them where and how they want to do business. Nearly 90% of our customers have visited one of our digital properties prior to the purchase. And by the end of fiscal 2016, over half of our total visits came from our mobile site or mobile applications. We need to ensure that these customers receive the same superior customer experience online that they've always received in our store. We are currently in the process of rolling out a new adaptive and more personalized website redesign, and we expect it will be fully rolled out by the end of this month. We will also continue to test different components of the selling process online to better understand our customers' needs. We're also never satisfied with our execution. We will continue to focus on becoming more efficient in reducing waste throughout the company. We will continue to equip our associates with the tools that they need to make their job easier. Let me give you 2 quick examples of enhancements that we're developing. One is a mobile appraisal platform. Remember we appraise more than 2 million vehicles a year, and this will help our buyers reduce our appraisal time and increase accuracy. Another example is an improved transportation system that will help us realize efficiencies when moving the millions of vehicles that we ship annually. It is this kind of continuous improvement that has driven our success in the past and that will support our innovations in the future.
Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks very much, Bill and Tom. And with that, we'll open it up for questions. Operator?
componenttext: Thanks very much, Bill and Tom. And with that, we'll open it up for questions. Operator?

componenttext: So the question I have. I wanted to just talk about gross profit for a minute. Clearly, that's been a big focus of investors in light of what some of your competitors have been talking about, declining gross profits. Now if we look at the numbers, the report -- the results you reported today, so gross profit was down slightly. I know, Tom, you can say -- probably say it's noise with the $39 year-on-year which...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016

componenttext: I am.

componenttext: Yes. What's your next question?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: The bigger question is, if you look at the drivers of that, kind of the puts and takes behind gross profit, have those changed at all? And are you seeing any type of pressures out there that maybe -- within your gross profit in used vehicles space that ma
componenttext: The bigger question is, if you look at the drivers of that, kind of the puts and takes behind gross profit, have those changed at all? And are you seeing any type of pressures out there that maybe -- within your gross profit in used vehicles space that may be more maybe reflective of some of the pressures that others are seeing or -- and you're handling those better?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean I think it's an overall inventory management process for us, and I think it starts with by having the right car in the right place at the right time. And that allows us to be able to deliver an exceptional value to the customer. And some of what I
componenttext: I mean I think it's an overall inventory management process for us, and I think it starts with by having the right car in the right place at the right time. And that allows us to be able to deliver an exceptional value to the customer. And some of what I talked about last quarter of -- we thought some big SUVs were a little expensive, so we didn't buy them. Or we didn't buy as many. And that allows us to manage our margin, I think, very efficiently. We transfer cars at customer request. It's about 1/3 of our sales, so that allows us to turn our inventory quickly. I think our turns help us manage our margins pretty well. And it also allows us to continue to test the margin variability. We're big enough now that we can test pockets and markets and different types of products all across the country and learn a lot about price elasticity. And then that's reflected in the ultimate margins that we achieve and the sales that we get. So I'm very pleased with the quarter and with the results and a positive comp facing one of our tougher comparisons last year. And yes, I think we can get better at this as time goes along. I think we're better at managing our inventory and our margins now than we were a few years ago. And with continued use of external and internal data and training and development of the process, I think we'll just continue to get better at it. So I'm pretty pleased with the progress that we've made and the results we've been able to deliver.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next version comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.
componenttext: Your next version comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, a question that we get asked a lot, so I'll throw it at you. There seems to be some thought process that perhaps the new car dealers have figured out a way to be more aggressive on their gross profit per car targets and make it up in some other p
componenttext: I guess, a question that we get asked a lot, so I'll throw it at you. There seems to be some thought process that perhaps the new car dealers have figured out a way to be more aggressive on their gross profit per car targets and make it up in some other part of their business and therefore become more of a competitive threat to you kind of by undercutting prices. I'm just -- it's a pervasive thought on Wall Street at this point, and I'm just wondering if you have any commentary or any context you could give us on that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think the biggest thing to look at is just our results and our volumes. During the quarter, our average stores sold around 340 cars a month per store. That's across the entire chain, including new stores. If you look at used car sales, our used ca
componenttext: Well, I think the biggest thing to look at is just our results and our volumes. During the quarter, our average stores sold around 340 cars a month per store. That's across the entire chain, including new stores. If you look at used car sales, our used car sales, compared to the -- I'm only going to use the public new car deals as an example here. There are many more franchise deals, as you know, but we sold more used cars during the year than the next 4 competitors combined, so I feel like our consumer offer is clearly resonating with consumers. And we're able to grow our business year after year. We once again comped our stores by 2.5% for the full year, a very good number for a company of our size. And I think, given the choice, consumers still, after they shop around, pick us more often than not. So I think the results speak for themselves. If you look at franchise dealers' total for the year: Used car sales were up by 2% across all the franchise dealers. And I think you have to look at it on a broader scale and not just focus on the publicly traded auto retailers because they're a very small sliver of used car sales in the U.S.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Looking for an opinion. So why do you think you guys are seeing a dip in credit apps at the low end of the spectrum?
componenttext: Looking for an opinion. So why do you think you guys are seeing a dip in credit apps at the low end of the spectrum?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Scot, I'm not sure that we really know, but I'm not sure that that's not good for us. If you look at our mix of sales in Tier 3 in this quarter, we were down 2 points. So we're 17% of our sales last year's fourth quarter, 15% this year's fourth quarter. A
componenttext: Scot, I'm not sure that we really know, but I'm not sure that that's not good for us. If you look at our mix of sales in Tier 3 in this quarter, we were down 2 points. So we're 17% of our sales last year's fourth quarter, 15% this year's fourth quarter. As you know, that's a less-profitable slice of business for us. It's one that we are very comfortable being in, one that I have said in the past I think we provide the best possible deal for customers in that credit segment. And we're very happy to be able to deliver a great consumer experience and a high-quality car to those customers. But if you look at a base from which to grow your business, if you had a little higher credit profile, it's not the worst thing. You've been around long enough to know that, that percent of sales for us was at one point nonexistent. And it's gone from 2% to, I think, as high in 1 year as 19%. It might have been our highest full year. So we're down a couple points for the year. You could argue that, that loss of credit apps, of volume of apps hurts comps by a little bit, which it does but it doesn't hurt profits by as much as it hurts the comp. So we continue to build our brand. We continue to advertise to get any consumer to want to come to CarMax, but it's not that bad if it shifts a couple of points in the other direction. But in terms of explaining the volume of applications, it's very difficult to do.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you. And just for context: Is the Tier 2 guys still kind of dipping down? Because that was something that you had suggested previously, where the Tier 2 guys were scooping up some of the stuff that would historically have flown in the Tier 3 bucket.
componenttext: Got you. And just for context: Is the Tier 2 guys still kind of dipping down? Because that was something that you had suggested previously, where the Tier 2 guys were scooping up some of the stuff that would historically have flown in the Tier 3 bucket.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scot, I think that's -- I would say that we continue to see some pretty aggressive behavior from our Tier 2 lenders. And that combined with the lower number of low-credit applications, both of those impact Tier 3s' ability to get customers, right? I
componenttext: Yes, Scot, I think that's -- I would say that we continue to see some pretty aggressive behavior from our Tier 2 lenders. And that combined with the lower number of low-credit applications, both of those impact Tier 3s' ability to get customers, right? I mean the byproduct of that is that what you're seeing might be a little bit less than what you're seeing before. Tier 2, by the way, is down slightly this quarter year-over-year as well, but -- and as you saw, CAF was up. And other, meaning people who bring their own financing to the table, was up a couple points also. So that just goes, it falls right in line with the fact that we're seeing a higher credit quality through the door that other is up even more than CAF.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I thanks, Scot, some of the shifting you're referring to is a reflection of our partners who are fantastic partners getting more and more experience with the CarMax origination channel and being more comfortable with how they originate. So that's noth
componenttext: And I thanks, Scot, some of the shifting you're referring to is a reflection of our partners who are fantastic partners getting more and more experience with the CarMax origination channel and being more comfortable with how they originate. So that's nothing but good for us.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's on the wholesale business. Wholesale volume growth decelerated to about 3 -- 2% or 3%. Are you seeing any impact at all from some of these emerging peer-to-peer remarketing channels? Or is there another dynamic at play?
componenttext: It's on the wholesale business. Wholesale volume growth decelerated to about 3 -- 2% or 3%. Are you seeing any impact at all from some of these emerging peer-to-peer remarketing channels? Or is there another dynamic at play?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know. I have said, and it has been true over time, that I think wholesale will grow approximately with sales over time that -- but it will never be exactly attached. If you look at us over a multiyear window, that has been true. It's very difficul
componenttext: I don't know. I have said, and it has been true over time, that I think wholesale will grow approximately with sales over time that -- but it will never be exactly attached. If you look at us over a multiyear window, that has been true. It's very difficult to evaluate where -- we had a buy rate of around 30% for the quarter. So that's about -- that's as high as it gets for us, and we're very pleased with that. Some of the peer-to-peer stuff you're referring to are still very, very small, particularly compared to our size; and then vary only in a few markets. So we haven't seen any impacts of any statistical significance that we could attribute directly.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And as a follow-up to Bill. You mentioned the mobile appraisal platform you're piloting or starting soon. Do you think that'll drive volume at wholesale as well?
componenttext: And as a follow-up to Bill. You mentioned the mobile appraisal platform you're piloting or starting soon. Do you think that'll drive volume at wholesale as well?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: The intention of the website isn't necessarily drop wholesale volume, other than highlight the appraisal process. So if we highlight the appraisal process, inherently that will end up driving some wholesale traffic.
componenttext: The intention of the website isn't necessarily drop wholesale volume, other than highlight the appraisal process. So if we highlight the appraisal process, inherently that will end up driving some wholesale traffic.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I want to ask you about the performance of your new stores. I know that our ability to measure them is not perfect, but it seems like the volume productivity per unit for the vintage that's opened over the past year is down. Is there something about timin
componenttext: I want to ask you about the performance of your new stores. I know that our ability to measure them is not perfect, but it seems like the volume productivity per unit for the vintage that's opened over the past year is down. Is there something about timing that would make a difference? Is there something about the markets that you're entering that would make a difference? Because it just seems like, anyway you slice that, the used vehicle units per average new opening are a bit lower than they've been in years past.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Remember we have small-format stores mixed in there too, which are a fraction of what some of our biggest stores are. And also, as a percent of our opening -- I mean, as a percent of our stores that we're opening each year, the last few years, that number
componenttext: Remember we have small-format stores mixed in there too, which are a fraction of what some of our biggest stores are. And also, as a percent of our opening -- I mean, as a percent of our stores that we're opening each year, the last few years, that number is actually going down because we've been consistent at that 14, 15 number. So this year, the amount of stores we opened as a percentage of the base has gone down, so you would expect the percentage of units delivered from the new stores to go down unless we increase the number of stores that we build and we change the profile of the size. What I would tell you is that we're continuing to open stores because they're delivering a great return. And remember that we have very long models for sales, 30-plus years. And we have some stores, we have a whole batch of stores now that are less than 5 years old and are still on their growth curves. So we're pleased with the performance of the new stores. That's why we keep opening them. And we think they're delivering a great return, but mathematically, it's not going to deliver as much to the total because it's less of the base. And then there are -- some of our big, old stores are very big.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'd follow up by saying that, even if you adjust for store size, which we do, and you adjust for the role that newer stores have in the mix as a percent of the base, you do all the math, it looks like this less vintage from a unit perspective was
componenttext: I guess I'd follow up by saying that, even if you adjust for store size, which we do, and you adjust for the role that newer stores have in the mix as a percent of the base, you do all the math, it looks like this less vintage from a unit perspective was a little off. So if you think about some of the new markets like Boston and you just tell us what you see, is the unit count kind of in like-sized stores different from it had been? And if you think the trajectory in some of those markets is going to be different, why would that be the case?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I haven't looked at it. We really don't -- we look at it on a -- when we build a store, do we think it's on pace to deliver a great return? And we're comfortable with the stores we've been building. Boston has been open for 4 or 5 months. We would n
componenttext: Well, I haven't looked at it. We really don't -- we look at it on a -- when we build a store, do we think it's on pace to deliver a great return? And we're comfortable with the stores we've been building. Boston has been open for 4 or 5 months. We would never make any determination on any market after 4 or 5 months, having done this for 23 years. We're -- I can say we're pleased with the openings, and that's why we keep building them.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of James Albertine with Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of James Albertine with Stifel.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to understand. I don't think I heard a comment about, and apologies if I missed it, comment around traffic for the quarter. And what I'm trying to get at here is, as your online traffic grows, how do you think that impacts consumer's decision to
componenttext: I wanted to understand. I don't think I heard a comment about, and apologies if I missed it, comment around traffic for the quarter. And what I'm trying to get at here is, as your online traffic grows, how do you think that impacts consumer's decision to visit stores or multiple stores? And do you think, and in fact, there could be some cannibalization going on as it relates to that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, there's -- I didn't mention traffic specifically. I did mention that our comps for the quarter were driven by conversion. So our traffic through the door was down slightly. And our traffic -- and our conversion was up slightly, delivering a 0.7% com
componenttext: Well, there's -- I didn't mention traffic specifically. I did mention that our comps for the quarter were driven by conversion. So our traffic through the door was down slightly. And our traffic -- and our conversion was up slightly, delivering a 0.7% comp for the quarter. In terms of the goal of the website and the goal of driving traffic, it's twofold. One is to drive just raw traffic, and the other one is to improve the likelihood of the traffic that shows up to buy a car. So if a customer -- as Bill mentioned, if a customer wants to do more of the process from home, they have those tools available on our website. They can be more prepared when they show up. And to be honest with you, it doesn't matter to us whether we get a few less customers who are a lot more likely to buy or more customers that are just as equally likely to buy. So it's very difficult to measure that, but it's kind of a multifaceted goal with the website. It's people are doing a lot of research online. There's a lot of data out there that's telling you that people are visiting less stores than they used to before they buy a car, so it's really, really important that our website provides a great education for the customer. And when they show up, they're more likely to buy. So that's kind of a goal of the website. It's to educate and then to deliver customers to the store, and hopefully, they're more likely to buy.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that color. If I may, just a follow-up on that topic. Do you envision a point in which the entire transaction will be possible online? And as it relates to that, is there anything that you're seeing either among competitors or among your own co
componenttext: Appreciate that color. If I may, just a follow-up on that topic. Do you envision a point in which the entire transaction will be possible online? And as it relates to that, is there anything that you're seeing either among competitors or among your own consumers and what they're telling you they desire that would accelerate spending around online versus your anticipated spending maybe a quarter or a few quarters ago?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Bill mentioned enhancements to the website and continuing to improve our mobile experience for our customers. So if you look at where we're spending our dollars, there's no doubt it's shifting towards mobile. It's shifting towards the website becaus
componenttext: Well, Bill mentioned enhancements to the website and continuing to improve our mobile experience for our customers. So if you look at where we're spending our dollars, there's no doubt it's shifting towards mobile. It's shifting towards the website because that's where our customers are. That's where we need to make sure that we meet them however they want to be met. And we want to make sure that they have the capabilities to do parts of the transaction or all of the transaction online. I will tell you that the average customer at CarMax has a trade-in. The average customer at CarMax needs a loan, has to go through a finance process, sometimes has negative equity. And it's not as easy to do a $20,000 transaction that is multifaceted, which oftentimes includes appraising the car that they're driving; and do the entire transaction online. I'm not saying that we won't do that and we won't have those capabilities, but that's a sliver of the customers that we actually deal with. And what we've -- we're really, really good at in our stores is helping people find the right car that they need in the budget that they can afford; matching them up with the right credit offer; making sure we give them a fair offer for their trade-in, which almost always requires looking at the car and making a fair offer after you've assessed its condition. So we are going to continue to drive towards giving the consumer more and more capability to do whatever they want to do online. And it may someday include consummating the whole transaction, but there is a large segment of customers who really can't do the whole transaction online due to those other pieces that I mentioned.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Montani with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Montani with Evercore ISI.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just want to ask about the comp side of things and what it is maybe that you're seeing out there that can help the comps to continue to sequentially accelerate. When you think about the 0.7%, it's definitely better than what we were looking for. It's en
componenttext: I just want to ask about the comp side of things and what it is maybe that you're seeing out there that can help the comps to continue to sequentially accelerate. When you think about the 0.7%, it's definitely better than what we were looking for. It's encouraging, but do we need more used car price declines from Manheim? Or how should we think about the leverage that is in place to get to 4% plus?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Again, that's a -- there are multiple things that go into stores comping and the comp base. Remember we continue to build stores back into existing markets, which hurts comps. We continue to -- as Bill mentioned, we continue to invest in our website to dr
componenttext: Again, that's a -- there are multiple things that go into stores comping and the comp base. Remember we continue to build stores back into existing markets, which hurts comps. We continue to -- as Bill mentioned, we continue to invest in our website to drive more customers to our store. We continue to advertise to build our brand. I feel like everything that we do as a company, working on efficiencies, trying to lower our costs, trying to keep our prices competitive, will deliver comps over a long period of time. I think we've shown the ability to grow a very big base of business over a very long period of time. And I expect to be able to do that in the future, but there isn't really one button that you push to drive comps. I talked earlier about margin management and inventory management and having the right car in the right place at the right time. All those things contribute to comps, and those are things that we're all -- that we're focused on as a company to continue to improve.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just in terms of the quarter where we saw the GPUs come down a little bit but the comps accelerate a bit, I mean, how should we think about that tradeoff then going forward? How would you describe the fourth quarter on those 2 metrics and the ba
componenttext: Okay. And just in terms of the quarter where we saw the GPUs come down a little bit but the comps accelerate a bit, I mean, how should we think about that tradeoff then going forward? How would you describe the fourth quarter on those 2 metrics and the balance thereof?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: As with the first question: We've managed our margins pretty consistently over a period of time. I think the margins were down $39-ish for the quarter year-over-year. That's within our level of ability to manage. So I've always said we would -- we try to
componenttext: As with the first question: We've managed our margins pretty consistently over a period of time. I think the margins were down $39-ish for the quarter year-over-year. That's within our level of ability to manage. So I've always said we would -- we try to do as much price testing as we can and we try to balance margin and sales. And we're pretty pleased with the result for the quarter, but that's how we'll continue to look at it going forward.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Hoselton with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Hoselton with KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on your retirement; and Bill, your promotion.
componenttext: Congratulations on your retirement; and Bill, your promotion.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you.
componenttext: Thank you.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Brett.
componenttext: Thank you, Brett.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask you about gross profit per unit. So at my family's dealerships, we're going to do over 5,000 used cars this year. I can tell you, if you picked up the phone and you called anybody at our dealerships today, they would look forward to or be ve
componenttext: Wanted to ask you about gross profit per unit. So at my family's dealerships, we're going to do over 5,000 used cars this year. I can tell you, if you picked up the phone and you called anybody at our dealerships today, they would look forward to or be very pleased if the Manheim Index went down. They'd be very pleased because that means our costs for goods sold would go down. Therefore, the gross profit would likely go up because the spread between new car prices and used car prices would increase, and the volume will go up because of simple price elasticity of demand. And so higher gross profit, higher volume equals better total gross profit. That is a simple idea, simple argument that, for some reason -- I'm not [indiscernible]. My question to you is the only thing that kind of argues against that is that, if I look back at your results historically, it appears as though, during periods of time when gross -- or when the Manheim Index inflected somewhat, your gross profit per unit actually went down a little bit, which just kind of countered what happens at our dealerships. And I'm wondering, do you have any idea -- or first of all, what's your sense of what's going to happen to your gross profit per unit and your volume when the Manheim Index or if the Manheim Index goes down? And then secondly, can you explain what appears, at least to my mind, to be a bit of an anomaly that took place kind of in that -- before the last downturn?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not really sure where you ended up there, but our margin...
componenttext: I'm not really sure where you ended up there, but our margin...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, let me simplify.
componenttext: Well, let me simplify.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll just say -- I'll answer it. Our margin dollars have been very consistent. When the Manheim Index goes down and we can buy cars cheaper, we want to give our customers a better deal. So we have chosen, whether it's right or wrong, to not increase our m
componenttext: I'll just say -- I'll answer it. Our margin dollars have been very consistent. When the Manheim Index goes down and we can buy cars cheaper, we want to give our customers a better deal. So we have chosen, whether it's right or wrong, to not increase our margins when our prices go down because we want to give our customers a better deal, and we're building our business over a very, very long period of time and we want them to leave and say, "Why, I got a really fantastic deal. The next time I buy a car, I want to buy it from CarMax " So you can argue with our motives, but when our ability to buy a car is cheaper, we have chosen to pass those savings onto our customers as opposed to taking it into margin. That's just what we've done. The biggest example I can give you is during the recession, our average retail price dropped by over $2,000 in 3 months, and we kept our margins -- and we bought cars cheaper over that period of time by that same amount, and we chose to keep our margins flat. That's just a decision that we made. I think we gave a whole bunch of customers a great deal, and hopefully, made customers for life. That's how we've chosen to run our business. It doesn't mean that we'll do it exactly that way going forward. But when we have the ability to buy cars cheaper, we pass those savings onto our customers.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So maybe the simple question would be if the Manheim Index were to go down by 1%, 2%, 3%, 5%, or something along those lines, you do not anticipate that your gross profit per unit is going to go down. You probably would maintain that and just simply
componenttext: Okay. So maybe the simple question would be if the Manheim Index were to go down by 1%, 2%, 3%, 5%, or something along those lines, you do not anticipate that your gross profit per unit is going to go down. You probably would maintain that and just simply increase your volumes. Is that conceptually how to think about them?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Every market condition has different variables, and we evaluate all of them and we try to make what's -- the decisions that are in the best interest of our customers and our shareholders. So I can't tell you exactly what's going to look like going forward
componenttext: Every market condition has different variables, and we evaluate all of them and we try to make what's -- the decisions that are in the best interest of our customers and our shareholders. So I can't tell you exactly what's going to look like going forward. You can look at our history. And we watch depreciation go up, down, Manheim Index go all over the place, and we've managed our business very consistently through that time, and each time we see a downturn or an uptick or appreciation or depreciation, we evaluate all the variables, and we try to make the best decision we can.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I guess, maybe asking it a different way, you do not anticipate making less gross profit when the Manheim Index goes down?
componenttext: Yes. So I guess, maybe asking it a different way, you do not anticipate making less gross profit when the Manheim Index goes down?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just answered that question.
componenttext: I just answered that question.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of Rod Lache with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of Rod Lache with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's actually Mike Levin, on for Rod. Congratulations again, Tom, on your retirement and Bill on your promotion. I think, over time, your guys' sales have correlated much better with new car sales versus used cars. And we're looking at expectations for ne
componenttext: It's actually Mike Levin, on for Rod. Congratulations again, Tom, on your retirement and Bill on your promotion. I think, over time, your guys' sales have correlated much better with new car sales versus used cars. And we're looking at expectations for new car SAAR in the U.S. moving forward. Most people are expecting sort of a plateauing demand environment. Just wanted to kind of get your thoughts around how you think about CarMax's growth within that sort of plateauing SAAR.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I've always -- I've said this before that I think that largely, we move directionally with SAAR, but it's not an exact science. And making a forward-looking prediction on SAAR is something that's -- that's not something that we really do. And what w
componenttext: Well, I've always -- I've said this before that I think that largely, we move directionally with SAAR, but it's not an exact science. And making a forward-looking prediction on SAAR is something that's -- that's not something that we really do. And what we focus on is trying to deliver the best deal and the best consumer offer that we can each and every day. And I can't really comment on what's going to happen over the next 12 or 24 months, depending on movement in SAAR. I think it's nice to see new car sales back up to where they were pre-recession. If you actually track new car sales and correlate it with population growth, I think the SAAR is still pretty low. So there's lots of different estimates about what's going to happen over the next year. We're just going to try and do the best job we can based on the conditions that we see.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. And then just within some of the pool data, we've seen losses and delinquencies tick up slightly. Just wanted to kind of get your thoughts on where we are in terms of credit availability. Are things beginning to tighten? And how -- when rates are m
componenttext: Great. And then just within some of the pool data, we've seen losses and delinquencies tick up slightly. Just wanted to kind of get your thoughts on where we are in terms of credit availability. Are things beginning to tighten? And how -- when rates are moving up, how do you kind of see that impacting both the CAF business and your ability to finance your customers moving forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, I guess I can only speak specifically to what we've seen through year end. And if you're asking about CAF portfolio, there's nothing going on there that we see that caused us any concern, and it's been pretty much business as usual. With regard to
componenttext: Right, I guess I can only speak specifically to what we've seen through year end. And if you're asking about CAF portfolio, there's nothing going on there that we see that caused us any concern, and it's been pretty much business as usual. With regard to the partners, there's a reason we have a number of them because we want to keep a broad spectrum of credit available to our customers. We continue to see greater than 90% of customers who submit an application and get some kind of approval in our stores. So the way I would characterize, it's greater than 90%. The way I would characterize our availability through the fourth quarter is as good as ever. And as Tom mentioned, we pick a long-term perspective with our partners. We try to be a good partner. We believe we've developed an origination channel that is superior to others as far as originating loans for new cars, for used cars and new cars due to the transparency and the integrity of the channel. It's proven out in the past that our partners have seen better performance on their pool originating out of CarMax than elsewhere. We've seen in the past that they preferred to allocate capital to us when times have gotten tough. And as we look forward, we would hope that our work and our long-term relationships and the integrity of the channel would make it such that we continue to see that kind of preference for CarMax.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think -- does that answer question about availability or...
componenttext: I think -- does that answer question about availability or...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so. I'll get back in queue.
componenttext: Yes, I think so. I'll get back in queue.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy with Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy with Bank of America.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Liz Suzuki, on for John. Just looking at the different buckets for SG&A, what portion is generally associated with existing stores versus new stores, and what is typically comprised by advertising and stock-based comp? Just trying to think, going
componenttext: This is Liz Suzuki, on for John. Just looking at the different buckets for SG&A, what portion is generally associated with existing stores versus new stores, and what is typically comprised by advertising and stock-based comp? Just trying to think, going forward, about how we should think about operating leverage backing out the impact of stock-based comp and new store openings.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Liz, I don't know that we've divided it, that we've talked about it that way before. So I'm not sure I can answer that. I mean, what percent -- what do -- can you ask the question again?
componenttext: Liz, I don't know that we've divided it, that we've talked about it that way before. So I'm not sure I can answer that. I mean, what percent -- what do -- can you ask the question again?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, I was just thinking about like what percentage of SG&A is generally associated with new stores if you're opening 15 or so per year versus your existing stores and just trying to think about leverage going forward.
componenttext: Sure. Yes, I was just thinking about like what percentage of SG&A is generally associated with new stores if you're opening 15 or so per year versus your existing stores and just trying to think about leverage going forward.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I can't give you the exact percentage, but -- because I don't have it handy, but there's no doubt that new stores on a per-unit basis are significantly SG&A inefficient compared to existing stores because they're new, because they have higher adverti
componenttext: Yes, I can't give you the exact percentage, but -- because I don't have it handy, but there's no doubt that new stores on a per-unit basis are significantly SG&A inefficient compared to existing stores because they're new, because they have higher advertising expense to start, because they're not mature. So if you think about the newer stores, there's no question that they're much more inefficient from an SG&A standpoint on a per-unit basis than the older stores. And when you want -- you talk about leverage. We've always talked about while we're growing the business, while we're spending the CapEx that we're spending to build 15 stores a year, we need a few points of comps to leverage SG&A at that growth rate. I don't know if that provides the color you're looking for.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Liz, another way to look at it is, if you look back over time and you see the growth in SG&A, around half of it is coming from new stores and the rest is coming from...
componenttext: Liz, another way to look at it is, if you look back over time and you see the growth in SG&A, around half of it is coming from new stores and the rest is coming from...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of the growth.
componenttext: Of the growth.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Of the growth itself, yes.
componenttext: Of the growth itself, yes.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King & Associates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question about SUV inventory availability. The expectations are that we're going to see more vehicles coming into the market from off lease and other sources as we move through the year and maybe price starts to come down. As you're going through t
componenttext: Just a question about SUV inventory availability. The expectations are that we're going to see more vehicles coming into the market from off lease and other sources as we move through the year and maybe price starts to come down. As you're going through the auctions, are you seeing an indication of that yet, and to what extent can you maybe source maybe a little bit more this through consumers, and any leverage you may be able to pull there?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can only comment through February, and SUVs have always been a big percentage of our mix. During the quarter, as Bill mentioned, mid-size and large SUVs were around 24%, roughly 1/4 of our sales. I think, as I've said before, with the high volume of off
componenttext: I can only comment through February, and SUVs have always been a big percentage of our mix. During the quarter, as Bill mentioned, mid-size and large SUVs were around 24%, roughly 1/4 of our sales. I think, as I've said before, with the high volume of off-lease product, that means there's going to be a high-volume of off-lease product coming back into the market at some point. And I think that there is an opportunity or a chance that, that will create some great deals and some great opportunities to buy, which will allow us to then turn around and give great deals to our customers, but that's no different than any other segment of our inventory. We're very optimistic. We turn our inventory very quickly, and we try pass on the best deal we possibly can to our customers. So it's still 1/4 -- it was 1/4 of our sales during the quarter. If we see lease volumes, lease turn in start to pick up, which I would expect that they will, like they always do. When you see such a high percentage of new cars that are leased, we'll be the ones that are standing there able to take advantage of that, and provide great deals to our customers.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you seeing any significant change in the mix that you're sourcing from consumers versus wholesale?
componenttext: Are you seeing any significant change in the mix that you're sourcing from consumers versus wholesale?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, you know that a lot of -- a big percentage that we buy comes directly from consumers, and the rest comes from auctions and other. So when you see a 24% mix of SUVs, that's probably about the same from both, ish.
componenttext: No, I mean, you know that a lot of -- a big percentage that we buy comes directly from consumers, and the rest comes from auctions and other. So when you see a 24% mix of SUVs, that's probably about the same from both, ish.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question first relates to the balance between market share and profitability. If you could benchmark your results against the industry according to NADA. Well, I appreciate that you gained market share overall for the year. For the last couple of quart
componenttext: My question first relates to the balance between market share and profitability. If you could benchmark your results against the industry according to NADA. Well, I appreciate that you gained market share overall for the year. For the last couple of quarters, it appears that you've lost market share, particularly when you benchmark against comparable stores. As you think about balancing that relative to profitability, going forward, what do you favor? Do you favor maintaining market share or taking a little bit of hit on profitability?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's a good question, and it's a tough question. I think to use the word optimal is the way I would go, and I'm not really sure what that is. I will tell you, I don't know where you get your data, but we've never been able to get market share data that
componenttext: That's a good question, and it's a tough question. I think to use the word optimal is the way I would go, and I'm not really sure what that is. I will tell you, I don't know where you get your data, but we've never been able to get market share data that was accurate on any short-term window of time. I'm not even sure how accurate it is over a longer period of time. It is so fragmented nationally. There's 40 million cars sold annually, roughly 1/3 are sold from customer to customer, and it's very challenging to figure out share. I think just the fragmentation alone makes it very, very difficult. As big as we are, and I noted some of those numbers earlier, we are a tiny share of 0 to 10-year-old cars nationally, somewhere in the 2% range. So I don't know that focusing on share is the right place to spend your energy because it's so difficult to ascertain what share actually is. And again, the business is so fragmented, you could be as big as we are and have just a fractional share. Even in the markets that we're in of 0 to 10-year-old cars, we think it's around 5. But remember too that, for us, we self-select out of a bunch of inventory that's included in the denominator. We don't retail anything over 120,000 miles. So there's a lot of cars that are 0 to 10-year-old over 120,000 miles. We still make an offer on those cars. We buy them, and we sell them through our auction. That doesn't count as share. But we sold 400,000 cars last year that don't count in share. They just happen to go through our auctions. So we're evaluating how to think about this going forward, Seth. So it's a very good question, but there's such fragmentation. I don't know really know how to think about it. We're just trying to optimize our sales. We're trying to grow our business. We're trying to comp our stores and deliver a great return for our shareholders.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, fair enough. Just as a follow-up, if you look at your profit per unit, obviously, it declined pretty substantially relative to the last few years on a year-over-year basis. You may see that as noise, but do you see that as a driver potentially to bo
componenttext: Okay, fair enough. Just as a follow-up, if you look at your profit per unit, obviously, it declined pretty substantially relative to the last few years on a year-over-year basis. You may see that as noise, but do you see that as a driver potentially to boost your sales going forward? And would you be more willing to see further declines in order to boost your sales?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, Seth, do you say gross margin?
componenttext: I'm sorry, Seth, do you say gross margin?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Gross profit per vehicle.
componenttext: Gross profit per vehicle.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, it was down -- like I said, it was down less than $40, and that's within kind of our ability to manage. And as I've always said, we'll do what we think is in the best interest of our customers and our shareholders. And I can't really tell you
componenttext: Yes, I mean, it was down -- like I said, it was down less than $40, and that's within kind of our ability to manage. And as I've always said, we'll do what we think is in the best interest of our customers and our shareholders. And I can't really tell you what we're going to do with the gross margins going forward other than we've been pretty consistent with it over the last several years, and have been able to deliver comps at the same time. So...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain with Morgan Stanley.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had a question about GPU as it relates to the source of inventory. When we think about the retail inventory channel, it looks like you probably source as much from auctions as you do through in-store appraiser, but the auction channel being a lot -- rel
componenttext: I had a question about GPU as it relates to the source of inventory. When we think about the retail inventory channel, it looks like you probably source as much from auctions as you do through in-store appraiser, but the auction channel being a lot -- relatively a lot less profitable. So with a lot of this increase, and off lease supply expected to show up at auctions or franchise dealers, is there a way for you to offset any GPU pressure resulting from it?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, a lot of those cars also show up in the auction too, remember. So a lot of customers who are coming off-lease will shop at our store, and if we can -- if we make them an offer that gets them out of their car, and makes them a little bit of money a l
componenttext: Well, a lot of those cars also show up in the auction too, remember. So a lot of customers who are coming off-lease will shop at our store, and if we can -- if we make them an offer that gets them out of their car, and makes them a little bit of money a lot of times because we see a lot of lease trade-ins come to our stores in the form of appraisals. So I can't give you an exact answer, but what I can tell you is our percent of cars that we sell that we retail, which we call self-sufficiency, has been in the low-30s, and it's been as high as, I think, the low-50s, and it moves around over time, depending on a whole bunch of different variables. And what we've gotten, I think, pretty good at is being able to manage our margins despite the fact that we expect some movement there. So I can't predict exactly what's going to happen when leases -- when lease volumes at the auction pick up, but that's not just lease volumes at the auction. Remember, it's all these cars coming back into the marketplace in a number of different ways.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rick Nelson with Stephens.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rick Nelson with Stephens.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Nick Zangler, in for Rick. Just building off that question. Earlier, you mentioned that some trucks, crossover SUVs were too expensive to buy last quarter. Are you still finding that to be the case? I mean, obviously, this product category continu
componenttext: This is Nick Zangler, in for Rick. Just building off that question. Earlier, you mentioned that some trucks, crossover SUVs were too expensive to buy last quarter. Are you still finding that to be the case? I mean, obviously, this product category continues to be in high demand. And just given that, are you able to get the truck crossover SUV inventory that you want?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: As I said, it's 1/4 of our sales. I mean, it's a huge chunk of sales. And I'd say the answer is largely yes. I talked about it last quarter. I thought it would had a fractional impact on us and I was mostly focused on larger SUVs that were just very, very
componenttext: As I said, it's 1/4 of our sales. I mean, it's a huge chunk of sales. And I'd say the answer is largely yes. I talked about it last quarter. I thought it would had a fractional impact on us and I was mostly focused on larger SUVs that were just very, very expensive. But if you look at the Manheim Index through from then to now, prices have come down a little bit. But we're always going to try to do what we think is the best value for our customers, but it -- I mean, it's a huge chunk of our sales.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: But yes, given that, but do you attribute any of the traffic decline to having to a lack of truck SUV inventory, I guess?
componenttext: But yes, given that, but do you attribute any of the traffic decline to having to a lack of truck SUV inventory, I guess?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's almost impossible to do that, but I would say no.
componenttext: It's almost impossible to do that, but I would say no.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Whiston with Morningstar.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Whiston with Morningstar.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Going back to the off-lease topic for a moment. What about on the dealer side? I know that made a lot of more emphasis on trying to retail rather than auction themselves and I know that they can't corner the market. But are you concerned that it could cau
componenttext: Going back to the off-lease topic for a moment. What about on the dealer side? I know that made a lot of more emphasis on trying to retail rather than auction themselves and I know that they can't corner the market. But are you concerned that it could cause you guys to not get quite as much as a high roll inventory over the next few year, as you normally would in this part of the cycle?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can only go by what's happened in the past, and it has never inhibited us before. It's usually the cars are more organized at the auction.
componenttext: I can only go by what's happened in the past, and it has never inhibited us before. It's usually the cars are more organized at the auction.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And going back to an earlier question on online versus brick-and-mortar, I wanted to look at that more from the perspective of these startups like shift. They compete more in the non-store front, test -- bring the vehicle to the consumer's home with
componenttext: Okay. And going back to an earlier question on online versus brick-and-mortar, I wanted to look at that more from the perspective of these startups like shift. They compete more in the non-store front, test -- bring the vehicle to the consumer's home with the sales associate. I'm sure you want to stay more on the brick and mortar side with an online experience to get -- to drive store traffic, but is this format something that you're just kind of dismissing for now because they're so small relative to you? Or do you think that's a type of the experience you would want to offer your customers down the road with a much larger selection?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, we actually just -- we recently tested home delivery. So we've done some home delivery on a very small test in a market. We'll continue to evaluate it going forward. Anything that we see anybody doing that we think would benefit our customers, we're g
componenttext: No, we actually just -- we recently tested home delivery. So we've done some home delivery on a very small test in a market. We'll continue to evaluate it going forward. Anything that we see anybody doing that we think would benefit our customers, we're going to evaluate whether or not it makes sense for us. As I mentioned earlier, the one thing to remember is many, many, many transactions involve the acquisition of the customer's existing car, something we're very, very good at, and I think it gives us a competitive advantage. Some of these smaller online players are connecting consumer to consumer without actually taking any of the inventory. And while -- without taking any ownership of the inventory, we actually think have 50,000 online is a huge advantage for us in providing a great selection for customers in a multifaceted selection when they get into their finance options and find out maybe that they can't quite afford the car that they thought. So I don't think anybody is in a better position than we are to deliver more and more of the transaction online and/or even delivering to someone's home than CarMax can because we have the infrastructure in place. As I said earlier, I'm not sure how big a piece of our total sales it will be, but we're going to be in a position to do whatever the customer wants us to do.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky with KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Congratulations on your retirement, Tom, and welcome aboard, Bill. I wanted to ask you a little bit of a small details question. SG&A expense. You mentioned you were rolling out a new website through the fiscal 2015. It should be fully rolled out by the e
componenttext: Congratulations on your retirement, Tom, and welcome aboard, Bill. I wanted to ask you a little bit of a small details question. SG&A expense. You mentioned you were rolling out a new website through the fiscal 2015. It should be fully rolled out by the end of this month. One would imagine it was probably a bit of a headwind to the SG&A cost. Can we expect an improvement as this initiative is finished, and can we expect it to maybe even drive a tailwind?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Really, that's just -- Bill talked about the website redesign. That's one initiative within our spend. We think we can continue to deliver a great value to our customers, and continue to deliver our return to our shareholders and invest at the level that
componenttext: Really, that's just -- Bill talked about the website redesign. That's one initiative within our spend. We think we can continue to deliver a great value to our customers, and continue to deliver our return to our shareholders and invest at the level that we need to make the improvements that we think are necessary to grow the business. So is there significant investment in IT? Yes, but there was the last 10 years also, and we expect it to be a big investment for us to go -- going forward. As we said, we want to make sure we can meet the customer where they want to be met. But we think within our big bucket of SG&A spend, we can both invest and deliver a good return for our shareholders.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016

componenttext: Two very quick questions for you. It looks like your compensation expense per used vehicle unit, even excluding stock-based comp, was down a bit. Is there any change in comp practices or with incentive compensation, a piece would move up the needle there?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016

componenttext: There's a number of different things, Matt. I think we had -- as you can look at this year is a little bit weaker than last year. There's some less incentive compensation that -- that adds [indiscernible] on top of that..

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any reversals as part of that or just lower accruals over the course of the quarter?
componenttext: Any reversals as part of that or just lower accruals over the course of the quarter?
