componenttext: It's just been a weaker year relative to plan.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Fair enough. And then my second and last question. Any change in the stance of your sub-prime providers and the standards that they are bringing to the market change? And I know your traffic is down in some of the lower quality credit or regions. But in t
componenttext: Fair enough. And then my second and last question. Any change in the stance of your sub-prime providers and the standards that they are bringing to the market change? And I know your traffic is down in some of the lower quality credit or regions. But in terms of their willingness kind of the standards that they are upholding as they extend credit, anything you've seen there?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt, as I said earlier, I can only speak to what we've seen through year end, and we've been happy with the performance of our Tier 3 partners. They've done a great job for us. I would say that their conversion on applications is a little bit down.
componenttext: Yes, Matt, as I said earlier, I can only speak to what we've seen through year end, and we've been happy with the performance of our Tier 3 partners. They've done a great job for us. I would say that their conversion on applications is a little bit down. But if we look at a like type of credit that we're seeing come through the door, that their behavior is been very consistent over the course of the year. So while we may not see them converting as many people because their offers might be weaker, that's more of a byproduct of the fact that what they're seeing is weaker than how their behave has been. As far as how they go forward, we want them to run a business that's profitable and sustainable, so that they can support our customers, and we'll keep an eye on for the long term.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rod Lache with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rod Lache with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask on CapEx. You'd say that the 4 50, which is a pretty meaningful year-over-year increases, has a lot do with timing of land acquisitions and construction activity. How much of the year-over-year increase can we kind of think of as grow
componenttext: I just wanted to ask on CapEx. You'd say that the 4 50, which is a pretty meaningful year-over-year increases, has a lot do with timing of land acquisitions and construction activity. How much of the year-over-year increase can we kind of think of as growth in kind of core CapEx versus timing? And then, subsequently, should we think about CapEx being down into fiscal 2018?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, almost all of the increase is timing, and we would expect to not be as high the following year.
componenttext: Yes, almost all of the increase is timing, and we would expect to not be as high the following year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. So then maybe that same magnitude come back down to sort of where we've been running and...
componenttext: Got it. So then maybe that same magnitude come back down to sort of where we've been running and...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: We couldn't give you an exact number, but yes, we don't expect it to be that number the following year.
componenttext: We couldn't give you an exact number, but yes, we don't expect it to be that number the following year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, remember, Rod, these deals takes a long time to put together. And we had a few of them slip from this year into next year that we would expected to just cough the money up on this year. And if things take longer than expected, you might get concentra
componenttext: Yes, remember, Rod, these deals takes a long time to put together. And we had a few of them slip from this year into next year that we would expected to just cough the money up on this year. And if things take longer than expected, you might get concentrated in 1 year versus the other. And if things accelerate, you find opportunities that you need to close on faster, the same can be true, but...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I think that because it were -- there's 15-ish store-year pace, you need to really be working on 16-ish pieces of property to deliver that. So when you get a CapEx number from us, it's our best estimate of the next 12 months. But as Tom said, the
componenttext: Yes, and I think that because it were -- there's 15-ish store-year pace, you need to really be working on 16-ish pieces of property to deliver that. So when you get a CapEx number from us, it's our best estimate of the next 12 months. But as Tom said, there's some timing. There's some shifting back and forth. But this differential between the year that we're telling you about, which is the upcoming year compared to last year, is almost all timing.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King & Associates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question also was on CapEx. And you've been able to, over time, reduce your overall cost of new stores, reducing the footprint through more efficiency. I was wondering if you could just maybe update us on what the trends are there. Are you still able t
componenttext: My question also was on CapEx. And you've been able to, over time, reduce your overall cost of new stores, reducing the footprint through more efficiency. I was wondering if you could just maybe update us on what the trends are there. Are you still able to get maybe a little bit less cost on an average per store basis? And how should we think about that when looking at your CapEx?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: The big piece you left out there is the land part of it, and that's not something we really have a lot of control over. But in terms of value engineering our store, so that they're both as efficient to build as possible, and then as efficient to run as po
componenttext: The big piece you left out there is the land part of it, and that's not something we really have a lot of control over. But in terms of value engineering our store, so that they're both as efficient to build as possible, and then as efficient to run as possible, those are the things we're hyper focused on. But when you look at our openings for the last couple of years and the next couple of years, we're going into some pretty expensive big metro markets. We've opened Philadelphia, St. Louis and Boston and Denver in the last couple of years. And in the next couple, we have San Francisco and Seattle coming. So often times, in a place like that, the land acquisition price is going to overwhelm the store build in some cases. So we're really focused on building as efficient we can. But the answer is I think we are building a more efficient box than we used to, but it's hard to really discern when you look at the total CapEx.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Hoselton with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Hoselton with KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick follow-up questions. One, can you provide us with an update of your sub-prime pilot, kind of where you're at? Do you have a particular direction that you think you're heading at this point? And then secondly, can you provide us with just some
componenttext: Just 2 quick follow-up questions. One, can you provide us with an update of your sub-prime pilot, kind of where you're at? Do you have a particular direction that you think you're heading at this point? And then secondly, can you provide us with just some very rough examples of where your market share is at and maybe in some of your mature markets?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll take the sub-prime one. As I said in my comments and in the release, we continue to be comfortable with where we're at, and we're going to continue at the same pace with Tier 3 volume, which is about 5% of the Tier 3 volume that we sell throughout th
componenttext: I'll take the sub-prime one. As I said in my comments and in the release, we continue to be comfortable with where we're at, and we're going to continue at the same pace with Tier 3 volume, which is about 5% of the Tier 3 volume that we sell throughout the stores. The sub-prime test, we haven't learned anything that scares us about it. In fact, we believe it's profitable business. But there's more to the equation around risk and what we want to do with the company going forward. So I think the way to characterize it is it's going to be -- it's about 1% or less of our total portfolio. But all the reasons that we decided to go into this test are still holding true, and we need to continue to get knowledge about the space and these customers. And we're going to make sure that we're in a position that we can mitigate risk to the extent that we need to. And from that perspective, I think we're comfortable kind of steady as she goes.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: And I'm sorry, your second question was?
componenttext: And I'm sorry, your second question was?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So your overall market share across the United States is 1% to 2%. Can you provide specific examples of where your market share might be in mature markets?
componenttext: So your overall market share across the United States is 1% to 2%. Can you provide specific examples of where your market share might be in mature markets?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. So again, I talked about the challenges around market share, but it's about 2% if you look at it nationally, which includes the places that we're not. It's about 5% on average, remember, of 0 to 10-year-old cars. And I talked some about the challeng
componenttext: Sure. So again, I talked about the challenges around market share, but it's about 2% if you look at it nationally, which includes the places that we're not. It's about 5% on average, remember, of 0 to 10-year-old cars. And I talked some about the challenges of the denominator. It's about 5% in the markets that we're in, and it's between 10% and 15% in our most mature markets. So it is no doubt that there's a ramping and a growing over time that's a combination of comp sales and adding stores into new markets. So we've seen, in our older markets that we can be in the double digits on share of 0 to 10-year-old cars.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: So let me ask you maybe just maybe a broader conceptual question. So let's say, in your mature markets, you're in the 10% to 15% range, your next competitor, I'm going to guess, is maybe less than 1% of the market. So it seems as though you, to be blunt,
componenttext: So let me ask you maybe just maybe a broader conceptual question. So let's say, in your mature markets, you're in the 10% to 15% range, your next competitor, I'm going to guess, is maybe less than 1% of the market. So it seems as though you, to be blunt, have an impenetrable near monopoly in your mature markets. Would you disagree with that or would you say that, look, we really feel very strongly that we've got a very, very strong model?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we have a very, very strong model. I think monopoly would be a word I wouldn't use.
componenttext: I think we have a very, very strong model. I think monopoly would be a word I wouldn't use.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair.
componenttext: That's fair.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: But I mean, our average numbers speak for themselves. As I said earlier, our average stores, so this is our average, including all of our new stores in the quarter, sold about 340 cars a month. The average new car dealer, who -- generally are the next big
componenttext: But I mean, our average numbers speak for themselves. As I said earlier, our average stores, so this is our average, including all of our new stores in the quarter, sold about 340 cars a month. The average new car dealer, who -- generally are the next biggest, and there's variability by market, there's some places where there's independents that have some significant sales. But generally, new car dealers that sell used cars, we would consider the next biggest, and the average nationally is around 40 or 50 cars a month. So the size differential is kind of true for us in most places.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q4 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 07, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Well, again, Tom, congratulations on your retirement. Bill, congratulations. I'd tell you, Tom, you have built a tremendous franchise here. So congratulations.

componenttext:
Thank you, and really, I really didn't do anything. I was along for the ride with a bunch of really great people, and I'm still going to be here a little while longer. 
So but listen, that's all we have today. Thank you, guys, very much for joining the call, and thanks to all of our associates at CarMax for delivering such a great customer experience, and we'll talk to you next quarter. Thanks.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Victoria, and I will be are conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax fiscal 2017 first quarter earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions].Thank you. I would now like to turn
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Victoria, and I will be are conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax fiscal 2017 first quarter earnings conference call. [Operator Instructions].
Thank you. I would now like to turn the call over to Katharine Kenny, Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Victoria, and good morning. Thank you, all, for joining our fiscal 2017 first quarter Earnings Conference Call. On the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our Chief Executive Operating Officer; Bill Nash, President; and Tom Reedy, our Executiv
componenttext:
Thank you, Victoria, and good morning. Thank you, all, for joining our fiscal 2017 first quarter Earnings Conference Call. On the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our Chief Executive Operating Officer; Bill Nash, President; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we made pursuant to the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them. For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 29, 2016, with the SEC.
And as always, [Operator Instructions]. Before I turn it over to Tom, I just want to say, how about those Cavs? Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katharine, our -- who has a hometown of Cleveland as you can tell. Good morning, everyone thanks for joining the call today. As usual, I'll start with a quick overview of the key drivers of the quarter, Tom Reedy will then give some more detail
componenttext:
Thank you, Katharine, our -- who has a hometown of Cleveland as you can tell. Good morning, everyone thanks for joining the call today. As usual, I'll start with a quick overview of the key drivers of the quarter, Tom Reedy will then give some more detail around financing and we'll turn over to Bill Nash will share some additional information regarding the quarter.
First quarter fiscal 2017 was a challenging one for us, total revenues increased by 2.8%, used unit comps were slightly positive and total used units grew 4%. Comp units were driven by an improvement in conversion, which offset a modest decrease in traffic. We do believe that the decline in traffic is both predominately and disproportionately a result of the decrease in Tier 3 sales, given the fact that Tier 3 conversion has historically been significantly lower than our non-Tier 3 conversion.
For the non-Tier 3 customer base, comp units actually rose by 3.6%. Total web traffic increased by 7%, wholesale units grew by 1.8%, CAF quarterly income fell 7.7% to $101 million, net income for the first quarter declined by 3.6% to $175 million, and EPS rose 4.7% to $0.90.
During the first quarter, we bought back 2.6 million shares at a cost of $132 million.
I'll now turn the call over to Tom to talk about finance. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. This quarter, consistent with last 2 quarters, we continue to experience a year-over-year increase in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and a decline in applications across th
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. This quarter, consistent with last 2 quarters, we continue to experience a year-over-year increase in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and a decline in applications across the lower end.
Consequently, we saw growth in the percentage of sales financed by CAF. We also saw a growth in the share of sales where customers paid cash or brought their own financing. Cash net penetration was up over 1 percentage point to 43.9% compared with 42.7% in last year's first quarter.
Net loans originated in the quarter rose 6% year-over-year to $1.4 billion due to a combination of CarMax's sales growth and the higher penetration of CAF. Tier 2 financing, as a percent of sales, fell slightly year-over-year to 17.4% compared to 18%, due to the lower applicant flow, which was partially offset by stronger conversion in that space.
Tier 3 financing as a percent of sales declined to 11.9% compared to 14.7% in the first quarter of fiscal 2016, due to a commission of lower applicant volume and some measurable credit timing by your third-party lenders.
As Tom mentioned, CAF income of $101 million represented a decrease of approximately 8% compared to the first quarter of fiscal 2016. This was due to a higher provision for loan losses, a lower interest margin, partially offset by 12% growth in average managed receivables to $9.7 billion. The increase in the provision for loan losses in the first quarter reflected the favorability we commented on in last year's first quarter, selling favorable experience in the current quarter as well as the growth in the receivables. Given last year's favorability, much of the year-over-year increase in the provision was expected. However, we did have some unbearable loss experience as this quarter reflecting several factors, including a drop in recovery rate.
Our ending allowance for loan losses at $104 million was 1.05% of ending managers receivables compared to 0.94% in last year's first quarter at 0.99% last quarter. This los reservist within our range of expectations given our origination strategy, which includes our Tier 3 activity.
For loans originated during the quarter, the weighted average contract rate charged to customers was 7.5%, similar to the 7.4% in last year's first quarter. Total interest margin declined to 5.9% of average minimum receivables compared to 6.3% in the first quarter of last year, but that's consistent with the last couple of quarters.
Interest expense in the quarter rose to $11 million -- turning over to CarMax overall now. Interest expense in the quarter rose to $11 million compared to $7 million in the first quarter of FY '16. This was partially due to higher average debt levels that more than half of the increase was a result of the completion of lease extensions related to some of our stores as we discussed in our last 10-K filing.
During the first quarter, we executed a private debt placement of $500 million. We sold $300 million of the deal in the first quarter, which was primarily used to reduce our outstanding revolver balance. And we'll fund the remaining $200 million sometime in the second quarter.
We also repurchased 2.6 million shares for $132 million. And at quarter end, we had $1.3 billion remaining under the current authorization.
I'll turn it over to Bill.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Tom. Good morning. As a percentage of our sales mix this quarter, 0- to 4-year-old vehicles remained essentially flat compared to last year at approximately 77%. Midsized and large SUVs and trucks as a percentage of sales increased by over
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Tom. Good morning. As a percentage of our sales mix this quarter, 0- to 4-year-old vehicles remained essentially flat compared to last year at approximately 77%. Midsized and large SUVs and trucks as a percentage of sales increased by over 2% to approximately 25% in this first quarter compared to last year's first quarter, remained flat compared to the fourth quarter.
SG&A expense for the first quarter increased 8.7% to $380 million. This growth was primarily reflects the 11% or 16 store increase in our store base since the beginning of the first quarter of last year, and a $7 million increase or $36 per unit in share-based compensation expense.
Another $3 million increase in cost or roughly $18 a unit, was related to hail damage incurred in several of our Texas markets during the quarter. In total, our SG&A per unit increased by $97 to $2,223.
During our last call, I highlight some of the advancements we're making to improve the customer experience in driving efficiency. Specifically, I mentioned that we will be rolling out a new adaptive and more personalized website. The new website was fully rolled out in April, it combines an upgraded and enhanced design with a seamless experience across all devices. We have also upgraded the entire site to state-of-the-art technology platform. This will allow us to more quickly innovate, test new capabilities and personalize the experience based on the customer's individual preferences.
We will also continue to test different components of selling process online to better understand our customer needs. One of the new capabilities that we're currently testing is offering our customers online financing. Being prequalified for financing, before-the-store visit helps build the customer confidence and will make that in-store shopping experience faster and more enjoyable. Our plan is to initially roll it out to 10 stores.
We continue to believe that no one's in a better position at CarMax to deliver more of the transaction online or even delivered the car to the homes. No one can match our existing infrastructure, our national footprint, our inventory scale and our brand strength. The ability to combine state-of-the-art online experience, with the exceptional customer service our associates are known for, is what will set us apart from our competitors.
During the first quarter, we opened 2 stores, both in new markets, 1 and Springfield, Illinois and 1 in San Francisco. We plan to open 13 other stores during the fiscal year. Subsequent to the end of the first quarter, we opened a store in El Paso, another new market for us. During the second quarter, we expect to open 2 more stores, 1 in Bristol, Tennessee, which is another new market for us, and the other will be our third store in the Boston market.
Now we'll open up the call for questions. Operator?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just maybe a longer-term question, just to kind of follow-up, follow-up on what you were just talking about the enhanced website. Do you foresee a time where your store count is not necessarily growing as quickly as you're expecting right now, but you're
componenttext: Just maybe a longer-term question, just to kind of follow-up, follow-up on what you were just talking about the enhanced website. Do you foresee a time where your store count is not necessarily growing as quickly as you're expecting right now, but you're reaching a broader set of consumers? So quite simplistically, I mean, do need as many stores to cover a market as you do now if you kind of increased this physical presence? And can you go a lot more asset-light as of the business emerges over time?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. I think it's important that we do both very well. So I think in the short-term, we don't have any intentions of changing up our growth as far as the fiscal stores, as we said, in the past. 13 to 16 stores is what we've committed to for this yea
componenttext: Yes, John. I think it's important that we do both very well. So I think in the short-term, we don't have any intentions of changing up our growth as far as the fiscal stores, as we said, in the past. 13 to 16 stores is what we've committed to for this year and next year. And we think that's to be ultimately successful, you need to have a really good presence in both. And so I think for us, it's going to be combination of continuing to expand our offering online, and then continuing to evolve our in-store process. Could we get to a point down the road, where that may change up? That's hard to tell at this point.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Any reference on having an impact on your showroom traffic? Are they at this point?
componenttext: Any reference on having an impact on your showroom traffic? Are they at this point?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, when you think about traffic, foot traffic, it's broadly known that consumers are being much more informed because they come into the store. so they do a lot of the research upfront. In our case, we know 9 out of 10 of our consumers that end up p
componenttext: I think, when you think about traffic, foot traffic, it's broadly known that consumers are being much more informed because they come into the store. so they do a lot of the research upfront. In our case, we know 9 out of 10 of our consumers that end up purchasing from us do some homework ahead of time, from -- on CarMax.com. So what we do think is they're coming in more informed. And as we look out and try to continue to get comps comes, we're going to be focused both on traffic, both in store traffic to the web, and then equally focused on conversion.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my primary question is on the cap side. And we did see, obviously, a pickup in the loan loss reserves. Where -- how would you expect that to trend for the balance of the year given some of the unfavorable change that you saw happening during the c
componenttext: I guess my primary question is on the cap side. And we did see, obviously, a pickup in the loan loss reserves. Where -- how would you expect that to trend for the balance of the year given some of the unfavorable change that you saw happening during the course of the quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scot. One thing I will point out is when we booked in the quarter, and is now booked in reserve, is a 12-month look forward on losses. And our negative experience during the quarter is baked into our forecast direct for the rest of the year. So to th
componenttext: Yes, Scot. One thing I will point out is when we booked in the quarter, and is now booked in reserve, is a 12-month look forward on losses. And our negative experience during the quarter is baked into our forecast direct for the rest of the year. So to the extent things were to worsen or improve, we would adjust accordingly. But at this point, everything we know about the environment, including the experience we had in this quarter and having loss coming a little hot is baked into that forward-looking estimate. When you see the increase in the provision for loan losses is a combination of both our experience in the quarter versus our expectation of what we have booked, and an adjustment to the overall portfolio based on what we've learned. So it's as I said at this point, I think, everything that we've learned based on our methodology is baked in.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when you kind of peel back the onion a little bit, Tom, is it more recent vintages or is it older vintages or is it kind of a across the board?
componenttext: So when you kind of peel back the onion a little bit, Tom, is it more recent vintages or is it older vintages or is it kind of a across the board?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a combination of things, Scot. In general, if you step back and look at it, last year's experience was very favorable. So I don't think we would have expected to have a repeat of that. That's kind of the first point. We also seem pretty signi
componenttext: I think it's a combination of things, Scot. In general, if you step back and look at it, last year's experience was very favorable. So I don't think we would have expected to have a repeat of that. That's kind of the first point. We also seem pretty significant growth in the portfolio, which means losses are going to step-up. And then also in the last 2 years, we have expanded on the credit front a bit. If you remember, back in 2013, we got much more aggressive with customers at the very high-end of credit, offering very low rates to the highest credit quality customers. That had an impact of kind of bringing down our expected losses on the portfolio. Over the last 2 years though, we have expanding at the lower end of what has done some testing and some, I guess, prudent expansion, in an effort to bring our targeted cumulative net loss, back in line with where we've try to run it, at that 2% to 2.5%, which a very highly financeable portfolio. I think it's fair to say that activity in the last couple of years, we have gotten a bit more aggressive internationally. And we get compensated for that with higher rates. And some of that has -- that would -- if you would have maybe expectations of that will increase told us in the portfolio. But we did have some unfavorable experience in the quarter, as I mentioned, due to -- partially due to the expansion, partially due to the wholesale recovery rate.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Robert Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Robert Baird.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: And my question is just a follow-up on the prequalifying buyers online. Could you share more detail on what is required to do that? How long it takes? And how you're plan to handle sort of a disappointing outcome from someone who doesn't get what they want?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So like I said, we're currently just testing it, getting ready to put it in 10 stores, really what you wanted to is, we're going to a prequalify them or they come into the store. We have the sales consultant involved in the process. So if someone's d
componenttext: Yes. So like I said, we're currently just testing it, getting ready to put it in 10 stores, really what you wanted to is, we're going to a prequalify them or they come into the store. We have the sales consultant involved in the process. So if someone's decline, we can contact the customer. And again, the goal will be not only to give them and approval but to also transition them into the store at this point.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Fessler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Fessler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you think about the lower subprime penetration, this is a bit of an acceleration in the decline year-on-year in terms of penetration and some of the [indiscernible] Do you expect the clients to persist at this level? Do you feel like your a third-party
componenttext: If you think about the lower subprime penetration, this is a bit of an acceleration in the decline year-on-year in terms of penetration and some of the [indiscernible] Do you expect the clients to persist at this level? Do you feel like your a third-party providers are seeing similar experience to you? Or in the process of pulling back up further? Do you feel like we've reached a stable level here?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt. It's hard to say what we expect in the future. I've always said our goal is to have sustainable partners that are there for our customers and could have a wide range of financing. In the quarter though, we did see 1 line in particular pullback
componenttext: Yes, Matt. It's hard to say what we expect in the future. I've always said our goal is to have sustainable partners that are there for our customers and could have a wide range of financing. In the quarter though, we did see 1 line in particular pullback and was sent there. You've seen them out in the public domain talking about how they are pulling back inside and prime auto, letting other business to other folks. So it's not inconsistent with what they've been saying in the public domain. So as far as what they will do going forward, I could say we saw a couple of different things happened during the quarter. And it feel like it stabilized during the quarter. But looking forward, is their business, they're going to manage their portfolio if they see fit. And if they determine the need to dial back or get more aggressive, they're going to do that. I think Matt ... [indiscernible] a long time, that subprime as a percentage of our total sales has, at 1 point, it was pretty much 0. It's been as high as 19 in a year and then, I think last year, we ended at 16 or 16 for the year. So whatever it ends up is going to be a result of a whole bunch of different factors, lender behavior, applicant flow, but what we've always talked about what this phase is, we believe each customer is almost 100% incremental. Remember also that these point-of-sale are also significant the less profitable. That's one of the reasons we wanted to point out that if you take out the decline of 2 points or 2.5 points, whatever it was in the quarter, then the rest of our business actually grew by 3.6%. And if you look at our mix of business as a base from which to grow, this is actually a better base from which to grow than if we go back when 19% of our sales were Tier 3. Again, we believe that 100% of it or almost 100% of it is a quintal because of the way we flow financing from lender to lender. But at the same time, it's going to move around based on a whole bunch of different factors.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Totally understood. If I just follow-up briefly on this point. To the extent that Tier 2 extensions fell a bit, and you talked about more consumers coming in with their own other cash or their own source of credit. Is there that are there other competitor
componenttext: Totally understood. If I just follow-up briefly on this point. To the extent that Tier 2 extensions fell a bit, and you talked about more consumers coming in with their own other cash or their own source of credit. Is there that are there other competitors, we're kind of hearing 2 different things in a sense, to some degree, interest among low end discount or the willingness to extend credit, to the low income consumers. On the other hand, it does seem perhaps on this competing right on the middle part of the market or other consumers who might otherwise shop through Tier 2. So any kind of holistic comments whether the competition is increasing in any part of the credit spectrum?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, firstly, do remember that traffic of that fight goal score applicant is down. So you kind of start with traffic, I'll let him Tom comment on competition.
componenttext: Well, firstly, do remember that traffic of that fight goal score applicant is down. So you kind of start with traffic, I'll let him Tom comment on competition.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as Tier 2 goes, Matt, I think we mentioned last quarter that we thought some of the Tier 3 degradation was due to their Tier 2's aggressiveness or at least, the competitiveness. We have not seen any degradation in the quality of offers that th
componenttext: Yes. As far as Tier 2 goes, Matt, I think we mentioned last quarter that we thought some of the Tier 3 degradation was due to their Tier 2's aggressiveness or at least, the competitiveness. We have not seen any degradation in the quality of offers that the -- our Tier 2 partners are providing or the aggressiveness compared or even their conversion to still rate, which is in fact, it's better than it has been in the past couple of years. It's just they're not seeing quite the same volume they were before. So the decline in Tier 2, I would completely on this flow of traffic, we're very happy with how they've been performing in the quarter. We were looking on that but...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the final follow-up, to the extent that Tier 3 traffic is down, or do you use consumers essentially anticipating a lot of credit availability given that this has been perhaps, brewing the market for a little while? Or is that customer funding a better
componenttext: And the final follow-up, to the extent that Tier 3 traffic is down, or do you use consumers essentially anticipating a lot of credit availability given that this has been perhaps, brewing the market for a little while? Or is that customer funding a better deal [indiscernible] the buyer pay your account or somewhere like that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really -- that's almost impossible for us to tell, Matt.
componenttext: It's really -- that's almost impossible for us to tell, Matt.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttextpreview: I can give you a little color on the recovery rate. It was down about 5.0 year-over-year. So it's 55-ish last year, 50 this year.
componenttext: I can give you a little color on the recovery rate. It was down about 5.0 year-over-year. So it's 55-ish last year, 50 this year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. Thank you. And then if I could also, can you provide the -- an update on the CAF Tier 3 pilot that you all have been doing? What was the penetration there? How was it trending? And related question, given that the Tier 3 penetration rate is
componenttext: Okay, got it. Thank you. And then if I could also, can you provide the -- an update on the CAF Tier 3 pilot that you all have been doing? What was the penetration there? How was it trending? And related question, given that the Tier 3 penetration rate is down, do you feel the need to add additional lenders in that space or take on additional originations in that space?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as our Tier 3 activity, I would characterize it as steady as she goes. We're comfortable continuing at the same pace that we've been running at, which is roughly 5% of the Tier 3 volume, getting done at the stores. There's really no news ther
componenttext: Sure. As far as our Tier 3 activity, I would characterize it as steady as she goes. We're comfortable continuing at the same pace that we've been running at, which is roughly 5% of the Tier 3 volume, getting done at the stores. There's really no news there. I think the rationale for doing this program is still good, it still holds true. It's not about driving additional sales, it's more about knowledge, risk mitigation and some profitability. As far as looking at our other Tier 3 lenders, we will do that from time to time. We have -- we test lenders when it makes sense. That space though is a little different than the Tier 2 space. I think there's fewer people that are equipped to do it on a national scale. And we're very concerned about making sure we're doing, we're working with partners who are experienced, credible and already have a sustainable business and be there. So we're not going to be interested in bringing a new player in that is too risky.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could just, lastly, ask the penetration from your website, I was there recently and saw a low 40% range of SUV truck, kind of cross over and van versus sedans and obviously, high-50s. When you look at new vehicle SAAR, it's basically the inverse,
componenttext: And if I could just, lastly, ask the penetration from your website, I was there recently and saw a low 40% range of SUV truck, kind of cross over and van versus sedans and obviously, high-50s. When you look at new vehicle SAAR, it's basically the inverse, with 60% kind of SUV and truck. Can you guys give us kind of what that average number would've been for you all during the quarter because just from what I can gather, that could've been a several hundred at headwind to demand as well. If you assume the same dynamics in the used market as you get on new.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you asking if our net should be as same as new?
componenttext: Are you asking if our net should be as same as new?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just asking for the quarter, what's a fair way to look at your SUV and truck mix, Tom, broadly speaking, as included crossovers? And if you ...
componenttext: I'm just asking for the quarter, what's a fair way to look at your SUV and truck mix, Tom, broadly speaking, as included crossovers? And if you ...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We haven't looked at it like that, I mean, recently, so I couldn't give that number a couple my head, but I will tell you is we have always been a demand driven inventory model. So what you see on our -- and we're big enough and have enough scale that has
componenttext: We haven't looked at it like that, I mean, recently, so I couldn't give that number a couple my head, but I will tell you is we have always been a demand driven inventory model. So what you see on our -- and we're big enough and have enough scale that has inventory turns. We're pretty good at going out and finding it. Occasionally, there's some pockets where we don't think it's a great deal for our customers so we might be in the light in a particular area. But what you see as an overall percent of sales for the company is largely driven by consumer demand and our inventory turns. On a pace of 600,000-ish cars a year, about half of which we have to by offsite and half of which we buy to the appraisal lane approximately, we're going to buy what customers are buying from us and replenish at that same pace. So I don't expect us to match up exactly with new car sales.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Levin with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Levin with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to kind of see what you guys were seeing in terms of the ramp-up of immature store base, less than 5 years old, that's in the comps at this point. Maybe it's about 30% of your store base. How are those maturing and kind of ramping up at this poin
componenttext: I wanted to kind of see what you guys were seeing in terms of the ramp-up of immature store base, less than 5 years old, that's in the comps at this point. Maybe it's about 30% of your store base. How are those maturing and kind of ramping up at this point in terms of their support of same-store sales, and leveraging SG&A at this point? Or are they still kind of lagging in a bit with drag?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think if you -- first, our leverage in SG&A in any given quarter, that's going to largely driven by comes in that quarter, particularly for our company that's in a growth mode like we have been over the last several years and plan to be over the next
componenttext: So I think if you -- first, our leverage in SG&A in any given quarter, that's going to largely driven by comes in that quarter, particularly for our company that's in a growth mode like we have been over the last several years and plan to be over the next several. But in terms of the performance of the newer stores, I even take a step back and you look at since we restarted growth in 2011, so fiscal 2011, we've increased our store count by 50%. So we have about 100 stores. We have a little over 100 now and that same time for our net earnings are up by 65% and our EPS is up by 84%. So, I mean, we really stepped back and look at it that way, they are clearly delivering outsized returns and returns that justify continuing to build stores. So we're very pleased with the performance of the stores. they're at or above our financial expectation as a group. And I'm blocking out the question over a longer period of time of 5 years, go back to 2011, I look at it again, the numbers are store base up 50%, net earnings up 65%, and EPS up 84%.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And it was the first quarter, you guys held gross profit per used units flat on a year-over-year basis in about a year. Just wondering what you're seeing there in terms of the gives and takes versus adding some more volume?
componenttext: Got it. And it was the first quarter, you guys held gross profit per used units flat on a year-over-year basis in about a year. Just wondering what you're seeing there in terms of the gives and takes versus adding some more volume?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think what we all -- a couple of dollars, year-over-year quarter, last quarter, we were about it $39 off [ph], we said there's a range. We think this is an area where we excel from an inventory management standpoint and feel like we can continue
componenttext: Yes. So I think what we all -- a couple of dollars, year-over-year quarter, last quarter, we were about it $39 off [ph], we said there's a range. We think this is an area where we excel from an inventory management standpoint and feel like we can continue that range, staying in that range and keep it fairly tight. Now that being said, we're possibly be testing and the looking at trade-offs if you lower the gross profit, what's the sales, you get back from that? All of the idea of looking also which at your total gross profit you can get to. So again, we'll continue to test but we feel like we're we are right now is still the same, sustainable.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just lastly, it was interesting to see that direct expense at CAF move up sequentially in Q1. We've seen it usually seasonally take tick down from 4Q to Q1. Is there anything in particular to read through there? And is this kind of the le
componenttext: Got it. And then just lastly, it was interesting to see that direct expense at CAF move up sequentially in Q1. We've seen it usually seasonally take tick down from 4Q to Q1. Is there anything in particular to read through there? And is this kind of the level we should expect going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's some stock based impact as well just like there is in the -- but there's nothing extraordinary going on.
componenttext: There's some stock based impact as well just like there is in the -- but there's nothing extraordinary going on.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky with KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We wanted to ask a couple of questions on a Tier 3 a little bit more into that. If you were to put a weight impact on lower Tier 3 traffic versus lower application approval rates, as you mentioned, some of your partners pulling back, how would you weigh t
componenttext: We wanted to ask a couple of questions on a Tier 3 a little bit more into that. If you were to put a weight impact on lower Tier 3 traffic versus lower application approval rates, as you mentioned, some of your partners pulling back, how would you weigh that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And let me be a little more clear, it's not approval rate. We -- if you look at the percent of customers that are getting up in approval of some kind in the stores that's well above 90%, what we're seeing is the decline -- a degradation in, I guess,
componenttext: Sure. And let me be a little more clear, it's not approval rate. We -- if you look at the percent of customers that are getting up in approval of some kind in the stores that's well above 90%, what we're seeing is the decline -- a degradation in, I guess, the quality of the offers, meaning they might be asking for a little bit more money down or they're asking for stipulations, in particular, leasing a step up in that with one of the lenders an increase in asking for proof of income, asking for proof of residence, asking for proof of phone number, things like that. So it's not really a change in the number of approvals, but the quality of approvals and therefore, the ability the customer to accept or the willingness for the customer to accept it. And as far as the ratio, I think I would say that I can't  -- we don't want to be super excited about it because it's not easy to calculate. But I think the preponderance of the change is due to the change in behavior, call it, 2/3 and 1/3 to the traffic. And I think there's, I mentioned, traffic earlier as it relates to this space. I not giving too many specifics, what I would said was, we convert these customers at a significantly lower rate than we do non-Tier 3 customer. So it just think about it that way, it takes more flow of customers to sell 1 car than it does to sell 1 car of a non-Tier 3 customers. So if we're down by 2.5 points in Tier 3 percent of sales, it represents a disproportionately higher percentage of traffic than the sale that it generates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That make sense. Did you see any geographical concentration in lower traffic and subprime?
componenttext: That make sense. Did you see any geographical concentration in lower traffic and subprime?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't comment on geography.
componenttext: Yes, we don't comment on geography.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is the wholesale business. We've seen some softening trends there for the last couple of quarters in terms of wholesale to retail unit ratio as well as profit per unit. Can you give us a sense of what's driving some of that softness? And how y
componenttext: My question is the wholesale business. We've seen some softening trends there for the last couple of quarters in terms of wholesale to retail unit ratio as well as profit per unit. Can you give us a sense of what's driving some of that softness? And how you expect the business to perform through the balance of the year?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Seth. I think if you look out long-term for us, wholesale and retail pretty much grow about the same pace. And this time, in this quarter, retail grew about 4, wholesale grew about 2. We don't feel like there's anything really extraordinary to note e
componenttext: Yes, Seth. I think if you look out long-term for us, wholesale and retail pretty much grow about the same pace. And this time, in this quarter, retail grew about 4, wholesale grew about 2. We don't feel like there's anything really extraordinary to note even the profit, the gross profit margins off a little bit. But again, just like the retail side, that's within a range and there's really nothing extraordinary to note from that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. What is your buy ratio? How is that been trending? And do you see more competition to acquire vehicles?

componenttext: Yes. The buy rate is still around 20%, which has been historical high. It's similar to what it was last quarter, if you get that again this quarter. So I would say that we haven't seen any indication where customers are choosing to take their vehicles other places and having purchased by other dealers.

componenttext: Oh yes, that's very difficult for us to ascertain with our customer base. I can tell you that we have, we have continued to see very, very strong attendance in our auctions and very, very strong sell-through rates. We talked about this before and these numbers really haven't moved very much, we're at 98%, 99%-ish sell-through rate through the auctions, turning our inventory 1 35 times a year. Our ratio, so our dealer ratio has been very, very strong. I think it's 1.3:1. Some of the strongest ratios we've seen. We haven't seen any softening in the demand through our auctions, but you can then relate back at some of the things that we're hearing about it in Tier 3.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain with Morgan Stanley.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. The first one on CAF, and going back to something you mentioned earlier. You mentioned you were a bit more aggressive in the last 2 years with the CAF [indiscernible] was in that leading to some increase in loan-loss provisions. And
componenttext: A couple of questions. The first one on CAF, and going back to something you mentioned earlier. You mentioned you were a bit more aggressive in the last 2 years with the CAF [indiscernible] was in that leading to some increase in loan-loss provisions. And yet, when we look at the securitization, the average FICO score there has been impressively been around 700. So just trying to reconcile the 2 if you can provide some color there.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think I may have not done a great job explaining it earlier. But in 2013, we began getting more aggressive with the high FICO customers. Our current lowest invest rate is still below 2% today. So what we saw as an increase in the volume of people at a v
componenttext: I think I may have not done a great job explaining it earlier. But in 2013, we began getting more aggressive with the high FICO customers. Our current lowest invest rate is still below 2% today. So what we saw as an increase in the volume of people at a very highest end of the credit spectrum, which is -- have the effect of potential to bringing down our loss expectations. And so over the last 2 years, we've been trying to manage back towards a range that we're comfortable with our long time in the securitization market. So you can almost think of that as a bit of a barbell affect. You wouldn't see a dramatic change, step down in the overall FICO because we're adding it at the top end and the lower end.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then a question on traffic. A superstore, obviously, helps with the conversion rate but traffic is been an issue for a few quarters now. And at the same time, also industry leader sales are growing at a healthy clip. So is that because of
componenttext: Understood. And then a question on traffic. A superstore, obviously, helps with the conversion rate but traffic is been an issue for a few quarters now. And at the same time, also industry leader sales are growing at a healthy clip. So is that because of these aggregate websites taking traffic elsewhere? And if so, would you consider having a bigger presence on aggregated websites?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would actually consider any website, and we've tried several, we've been on all of the big ones. We're on -- we continue to test, I think all of our cars are currently on Car Gurus. So we test all the aggregators and we'll use anything that helps us dr
componenttext: We would actually consider any website, and we've tried several, we've been on all of the big ones. We're on -- we continue to test, I think all of our cars are currently on Car Gurus. So we test all the aggregators and we'll use anything that helps us drive incremental sales and delivers a good return. One additional comment on traffic, Bill mentioned some of these earlier, is it's been widely reporting the customers are visiting less stores before they buy. So it only makes sense that customers who show up, would be more likely to buy. And as I've said, we think comps will be driven by traffic and conversion. It's not going to always line up and it doesn't matter to us, which way to get it. So a lot of efforts we're making around developing a new website, giving the customer more digital capability are -- those efforts are to make sure that customers get more information, do more research, are more prepared. It's clear that that's what they want to do and we went of in a position to do that for them. So when they show up, they're more likely to buy.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: I think, this quarter, we feel like it was driven by the recovery -- it's a combination of both but the recovery rate probably had a little more weight this quarter. And as far as any specifics around customers, we really don't have anything.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then over the recovery rate going down, is that simply a function of the Mannheim or overall wholesale prices softening up a little bit during the quarter? Or were there some mix issues as well? Are you getting more sedans versus SUVs in the cha
componenttext: Okay. And then over the recovery rate going down, is that simply a function of the Mannheim or overall wholesale prices softening up a little bit during the quarter? Or were there some mix issues as well? Are you getting more sedans versus SUVs in the charge-off mix?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it's just -- it's a by-product of overall pricing and the wholesale market as you probably know, when we resell cars, we typically sell them off at our auctions and we realize whatever the auction market is delivering at that point in time. An
componenttext: No, I think it's just -- it's a by-product of overall pricing and the wholesale market as you probably know, when we resell cars, we typically sell them off at our auctions and we realize whatever the auction market is delivering at that point in time. And as I said, year-over-year, we're down about 5 points in that wholesale recovery rate. And we never really see much mix impact on the recovery that's always because it's a pretty big sample, it's generally going to be a macro trend that's going to impact the recovery rate.

componenttext: We've talked about these volume in the past. And this past year, leases were 32% of used cars -- of new car sales, roughly. That means you'll see that flow come back in the next 3 years, 2 or 3 years. We've seen some increase this year, but I think we'll see big increases in lease terms in the next couple of years. Not so much this year so far.

componenttext: So my first question relates to stock comp. The number was up big year-on-year. Last year, Q1, have been a pretty good number too. componenttext: Yes, what you got to look at, Matt, is the year-over-year change in the stock price. And the change in a number of folks that are getting.

componenttext: Is it the year-over-year change in the stock price because year-on-year, kind of today, to exactly a year get stuff down more than 20%. componenttext: It's largely related to our restricted stock program that the majority of our associates get because those are going to fluctuate with the market value of the stock. And what you have to look at is not the year-over-year stock price but the year-over-year change in stock price during the particular quarter.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: Got it. Okay. So to the extent that you might have started lower and moved higher that would've been [indiscernible] Okay, we can follow up. componenttext: Yes. I think to what Tom said earlier, we're going to get the mix in there based off of consumer demand. Are we are able to get that inventory? And we feel like you're able to get it? I still think it's probably a little bit high. But again, we're not having an issue or troubles sourcing it.

componenttext: And then finally, a question on one financial detail. So you have this new disclosure on the other revenue and gross profit item essentially. The new vehicles plus the service piece is baked in there. So the year-on-year increase and other gross profit is a bit bigger than what we can track explicitly to the higher warranty revenue and the lower third-party fees. I think you take those out and there's still a few million dollars. Is that all related to presumably lower losses or better gross on new plus higher service gross profit? Or is there anything else from the number that would have been a little bit higher?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: Matt, I think you hit it on the head. The gap are up a bit better than sales because we've got some more margin in there. But -- and obviously, the finance penetration is causing us to be favorable. There's some service favorability in there, that makes -- that's pretty much make the difference.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: My question is also around SG&A. That line number was much higher than anyone anticipated. And if you could just maybe tell us how much of that you expect to stay and continue, of course, the higher store count? And how much of that be something specific to the quarter than we can expect to improve going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think there was an increase about $30 million and a large portion of that is attributable to new stores and store growth as a growth company I'm in. I highlighted in the opening comment, we had about $7 million or $32 per unit on share based comp. And t
componenttext: I think there was an increase about $30 million and a large portion of that is attributable to new stores and store growth as a growth company I'm in. I highlighted in the opening comment, we had about $7 million or $32 per unit on share based comp. And then we also have a one time, where we had some hail damage in some of our Texas stores, that was about $18 per unit increase as well.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to talk a bit, if I could, about the work you've been doing on the website. I think there was a relaunch in April, and what have you seen from that might be encouraging are incremental to justify, kind of, the investments in the work that you
componenttext: Just wanted to talk a bit, if I could, about the work you've been doing on the website. I think there was a relaunch in April, and what have you seen from that might be encouraging are incremental to justify, kind of, the investments in the work that you all have been doing?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I think it's a little early on but what I'll tell you is one of the big drivers that we're looking for is what we call lead. So it's points to our customer either even e-mails us, sets an appointment, calls us, and our goal with a new website is t
componenttext: Yes, so I think it's a little early on but what I'll tell you is one of the big drivers that we're looking for is what we call lead. So it's points to our customer either even e-mails us, sets an appointment, calls us, and our goal with a new website is to make sure that we generate more leads because leads are highly correlated to sales. So ultimately, you want to drive traffic, traffic will then drive the leads. We're at the point now where we're trying to figure out how those leads convert and comparison to the old website. We feel good about the leads it's generating. But again, we're trying to understand the conversion of those leads.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then also, can you update on to thinking around the home delivery testing? And then when might we be in a position to get a full transaction done online if that [indiscernible]
componenttext: And then also, can you update on to thinking around the home delivery testing? And then when might we be in a position to get a full transaction done online if that [indiscernible]

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Home delivery, we referenced that in the last call. We did do a test, we've since pulled back on the test, we're looking at how to better operationalize that and we'll be coming out with another test later this fall on the home delivery. As far as the ful
componenttext: Home delivery, we referenced that in the last call. We did do a test, we've since pulled back on the test, we're looking at how to better operationalize that and we'll be coming out with another test later this fall on the home delivery. As far as the full transaction online, that's something that we'll continue to explore. Like I said earlier today, we started looking online financing as a component of that. And again, part of that will also be driven by the consumer demand and need for doing the whole transaction online as well as making sure that we stay within the state restrictions of what can be done online, what can't be done online.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so we have a follow-up question from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And so we have a follow-up question from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I did have a question regarding buyback expectations. I thought the general plan was to do a pretty steady run rate quarter-after-quarter but obviously, the buyback was a little bit softer than I think the pattern we've seen recently. What's the general i
componenttext: I did have a question regarding buyback expectations. I thought the general plan was to do a pretty steady run rate quarter-after-quarter but obviously, the buyback was a little bit softer than I think the pattern we've seen recently. What's the general idea of moving forward? If it can't be more of an opportunistic pattern? Or should be a relatively steady run rate from what we just saw in 1Q?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scot. I think our goal as you talked about before, is to be kind of a steady player in there, but we're going to have latitude around how aggressive we are based on where the stock prices and our view of valuation. As we talked about, we're targeting
componenttext: Yes, Scot. I think our goal as you talked about before, is to be kind of a steady player in there, but we're going to have latitude around how aggressive we are based on where the stock prices and our view of valuation. As we talked about, we're targeting a certain capital structure that debt-to-capital, excluding the nonrecourse stuff and account receivables of kind of 35% to 45%. We -- a quarter or so ago, we got up to the bottom end of that range. So it would be natural to see a little bit of a tapering off as we've move from a mode of moving to the -- a newer capital structure, a more leverage capital structure to one of maintaining that capital structure. That said, with the amount of cash that we have generated and becoming all things being equal, the amount of cash we generate, the amount of growth we're doing, we would expect to continue to need to repurchase shares and add debt into the capital structure to maintain that. So I would say, our expectation is to be in the market on a pretty consistent basis going forward, but we do have some parameters around our program that allows us to be more or less aggressive to any market conditions.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the change of pace is more a function of kind of getting to that lower end of the cap structure rather than your assessment of the value of the stocks, that does what you just said, Tom, regarding being opportunistic?
componenttext: Okay. So the change of pace is more a function of kind of getting to that lower end of the cap structure rather than your assessment of the value of the stocks, that does what you just said, Tom, regarding being opportunistic?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, going from moving toward the capital structure to maintaining it. So that would have a natural change of pace. But as I said, we're -- I think we ended the quarter a little bit below this quarter. So we've got that latitude of [ph] sub-10 points that
componenttext: Yes, going from moving toward the capital structure to maintaining it. So that would have a natural change of pace. But as I said, we're -- I think we ended the quarter a little bit below this quarter. So we've got that latitude of [ph] sub-10 points that we will be working then.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You're next follow-up comes from the line of Mike Levin with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: You're next follow-up comes from the line of Mike Levin with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to kind of get your feelings around the recovery rates that have been down on auto IBS across the market and for you guys, this quarter. Is that playing a role in some of that tightening standards that you're seeing? How do you think that's ki
componenttext: Just wanted to kind of get your feelings around the recovery rates that have been down on auto IBS across the market and for you guys, this quarter. Is that playing a role in some of that tightening standards that you're seeing? How do you think that's kind of going to progress going forward in terms of credit availability, and cost of borrowing for your securitizations?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I would point to -- we've been doing securitization, independent securitizations for over 13 years now and we've been able to manage through a lot of different market conditions, including recovery rates that are lower than what they are today. T
componenttext: I guess, I would point to -- we've been doing securitization, independent securitizations for over 13 years now and we've been able to manage through a lot of different market conditions, including recovery rates that are lower than what they are today. That said, the structure and the enhancement of the deal might need to be modified if lots, if the perceived losses in the rating agency size change. What that usually means though is the change in the over collateralization to get built some of the deals and builds over time, I mean, we get money back a little bit slower. But in general, we been maintaining a pretty solid program though a lot of different environments. As far as our partner lenders, I have [indiscernible] asked them about how they view that and their tightening but again, they I think, probably more of the impact is what they're experiencing in their portfolio than the overall wholesale market.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And if I remember correctly, a couple of years ago, when Santander did some pulling back, you guys added some lenders to the platform. Are you considering that now as well?
componenttext: Got it. And if I remember correctly, a couple of years ago, when Santander did some pulling back, you guys added some lenders to the platform. Are you considering that now as well?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I mentioned earlier, we would -- we'll test partners to the extent that it makes sense for us. But as I also said, in this pace, I think we need to be much more careful about who we're doing business with and make sure that we have established par
componenttext: Yes. As I mentioned earlier, we would -- we'll test partners to the extent that it makes sense for us. But as I also said, in this pace, I think we need to be much more careful about who we're doing business with and make sure that we have established partners that can be reliable source of financing for our customers for a longer period of time. I know it's been talked to a lot of players out there that are behaving aggressively, Santander has talked about that as well that they're willing to let some of them get the business. But we're very focused on -- in the right place for our customers and [indiscernible] as I said, we'll test as appropriate, but not many people have the national scale that we would need.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: I was hoping to follow-up on your CapEx guidance plan. I think last quarter, you took it up [indiscernible] the year. Can you kind of explain that again, kind of, how you said playing out the course of the year and what exactly that relates to?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think and you saw a step-up a bit a burst in recent years, a lot of that is due to timing of what we expect land acquisitions to do over the next year. I really wouldn't read into it too much as far as existing stores or anything. We -- we're worki
componenttext: Yes, I think and you saw a step-up a bit a burst in recent years, a lot of that is due to timing of what we expect land acquisitions to do over the next year. I really wouldn't read into it too much as far as existing stores or anything. We -- we're working on a pipeline of many, many different locations, the next 3 to 4 years growth, and our ability to acquire land is different in every situation. And I think as we look forward this year, we just bought a little bit heavier land acquisition than we've done in the past. And there's a lot of timing in there too as well so if you look at the tail end of this year, there'll be significant investment in the openings coming years that are coming the following year. So that's just our best guess, that timing over the next 12 months.
