componenttext: Okay. And then 1 follow-up. Just want to get your overall thoughts in the whole awfully supply that's surging. I mean you're already sourcing about 77% of your units [indiscernible], which was really impressive. Is there a reason to think that the added off-lease supply would actually accelerate that mix? Or is it really just, instead of sourcing trading [indiscernible] outsourcing off the lease supply like would a bit, how do you think about that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I kind of think they're unrelated. We're try to drive as much as we can to our own appraisal lane. I think when they off lease supply starts to come back, like Tom said earlier, we haven't seen a big off lease supply coming back into the auction hous
componenttext: Yes, I kind of think they're unrelated. We're try to drive as much as we can to our own appraisal lane. I think when they off lease supply starts to come back, like Tom said earlier, we haven't seen a big off lease supply coming back into the auction houses but certainly, when it does come back in, we'll be in a position to buy them because we turn our inventory so quickly. There are good deals -- we'll be able to realize those good deals for our customers. So we kind of think around separately, appraisal lane versus off-site. But historically, when there's been a big lease volume and it comes back at the sale, we're usually in a pretty good position to take advantage of it. And just on a side note, it does organize the cars a lot better at the auction.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how does the organization help? Can you maybe just walk through that? You can play in better or?
componenttext: And how does the organization help? Can you maybe just walk through that? You can play in better or?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Any given year, there's going to be -- people are getting out of their car in let's say, every 3, 4, 5 years. Well, when it's leasing, it's pretty programmed that they're going to get out of a certain time. And it's a lot of those cars go back throu
componenttext: Sure. Any given year, there's going to be -- people are getting out of their car in let's say, every 3, 4, 5 years. Well, when it's leasing, it's pretty programmed that they're going to get out of a certain time. And it's a lot of those cars go back through whoever the lessor was. And then the lessors, then run big, long lanes at the auction as opposed to those same cars, which might end up at the auction otherwise are spread out. And G Mac could be running 1,000 cars in a row.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax Fiscal 2017 First Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions].
Thank you. I would now like to turn the call over to Katharine Kenny, Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Victoria, and good morning. Thank you, all, for joining our fiscal 2017 first quarter earnings conference call. On the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our Chief Executive Officer; Bill Nash, President; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice Pre
componenttext:
Thank you, Victoria, and good morning. Thank you, all, for joining our fiscal 2017 first quarter earnings conference call. On the call with me today are Tom Folliard, our Chief Executive Officer; Bill Nash, President; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we made pursuant to the Safe Harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them. For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 29, 2016, with the SEC.
As always, [Operator Instructions]. Before I turn it over to Tom, I just want to say, how about those Cavs? Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katharine, our -- who has a hometown of Cleveland as you can tell. Good morning, everyone, thanks for joining the call today. As usual, I'll start with a quick overview of the key drivers of the quarter, Tom Reedy will then give some more detai
componenttext:
Thank you, Katharine, our -- who has a hometown of Cleveland as you can tell. Good morning, everyone, thanks for joining the call today. As usual, I'll start with a quick overview of the key drivers of the quarter, Tom Reedy will then give some more detail on our financing and we'll turn over to Bill Nash, who will share some additional information regarding the quarter.
First quarter fiscal 2017 was a challenging one for us, total revenues increased by 2.8%, used unit comps were slightly positive and total used units grew 4%. Comp units were driven by an improvement in conversion, which offset a modest decrease in traffic. We do believe that the decline in traffic is both predominately and disproportionately a result of the decrease in Tier 3 sales, given the fact that Tier 3 conversion has historically been significantly lower than our non-Tier 3 conversion.
For the non-Tier 3 customer base, comp units actually rose by 3.6%. Total web traffic increased by 7%, wholesale units grew by 1.8%, CAF quarterly income fell 7.7% to $101 million, and net income for the first quarter declined by 3.6% to $175 million, and EPS rose 4.7% to $0.90.
During the first quarter, we bought back 2.6 million shares at a cost of $132 million.
I'll now turn the call over to Tom to talk about finance. Tom?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. This quarter, consistent with last 2 quarters, we continue to experience a year-over-year increase in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and a decline in applications across th
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. Good morning, everybody. This quarter, consistent with last 2 quarters, we continue to experience a year-over-year increase in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and a decline in applications across the lower end.
Consequently, we saw growth in the percentage of sales financed by CAF. We also saw a growth in the share of sales where customers paid cash or brought their own financing. CAF net penetration was up over 1 percentage point to 43.9% compared with 42.7% in last year's first quarter.
Net loans originated in the quarter rose 6% year-over-year to $1.4 billion due to a combination of CarMax's sales growth and the higher penetration of CAF. Tier 2 financing, as a percent of sales, fell slightly year-over-year to 17.4% compared to 18%, due to lower applicant flow, which was partially offset by stronger conversion in that space.
Tier 3 financing as a percent of sales declined to 11.9% compared to 14.7% in the first quarter of fiscal 2016 due to a combination of lower applicant volume and some measurable credit typing by your third-party lenders.
As Tom mentioned, CAF income of $101 million represented a decrease of approximately 8% compared to the first quarter of fiscal 2016. This was due to a higher provision for loan losses, a lower interest margin, partially offset by 12% growth in average managed receivables to $9.7 billion. The increase in the provision for loan losses in the first quarter reflected the favorability we commented on in last year's first quarter, selling favorable experience in the current quarter as well as the growth in the receivables. Given last year's favorability, much of the year-over-year increase in the provision was expected. However, we did have some unfavorable loss experience this quarter reflecting several factors, including a drop in wholesale recovery rate.
Our ending allowance for loan losses at $104 million was 1.05% of ending managed receivables compared to 0.94% in last year's first quarter and 0.99% last quarter. This loss reserve is within our range of expectations given our origination strategy, which includes our Tier 3 activity.
For loans originated during the quarter, the weighted average contract rate charge to customers was 7.5%, similar to the 7.4% in last year's first quarter. Total interest margin declined to 5.9% of average managed receivables compared to 6.3% in the first quarter of last year, but that's consistent with the last couple of quarters.
Interest expense in the quarter rose to $11 million -- turning over to CarMax overall now. Interest expense in the quarter rose to $11 million compared to $7 million in the first quarter of FY '16. This was partially due to higher average debt levels, but more than half of the increase was a result of the completion of lease extensions related to some of our stores as we discussed in our last 10-K filing.
During the first quarter, we executed a private debt placement of $500 million. We sold $300 million of the deal in the first quarter, which was primarily used to reduce our outstanding revolver balance. And we'll fund the remaining $200 million sometime in the second quarter.
We also repurchased 2.6 million shares for $132 million. And at quarter end, we had $1.3 billion remaining under the current authorization.
I'll turn it over to Bill.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Tom. Good morning. As a percentage of our sales mix this quarter, 0- to 4-year-old vehicles remained essentially flat compared to last year at approximately 77%. Midsized and large SUVs and trucks as a percentage of sales increased by over
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Tom. Good morning. As a percentage of our sales mix this quarter, 0- to 4-year-old vehicles remained essentially flat compared to last year at approximately 77%. Midsized and large SUVs and trucks as a percentage of sales increased by over 2% to approximately 25% in this first quarter compared to last year's first quarter, but remained flat compared to the fourth quarter.
SG&A expense for the first quarter increased 8.7% to $380 million. This growth primarily reflects the 11% or 16 store increase in our store base since the beginning of the first quarter of last year, and a $7 million increase or $36 per unit in share-based compensation expense.
Another $3 million increase in cost or roughly $18 a unit was related to hail damage incurred in several of our Texas markets during the quarter. In total, our SG&A per unit increased by $97 to $2,223.
During our last call, I highlighted some of the advancements we're making to improve the customer experience and drive efficiency. Specifically, I mentioned that we would be rolling out a new adaptive and more personalized website. The new website was fully rolled out in April, it combines an upgraded and enhanced design with a seamless experience across all devices. We have also upgraded the entire site to state-of-the-art technology platform. This will allow us to more quickly innovate, test new capabilities and personalize the experience based on the customer's individual preferences.
We will also continue to test different components of the selling process online to better understand our customer needs. One of the new capabilities that we're currently testing is offering our customers online financing. Being prequalified for financing, before-the-store visit helps build the customers' confidence and will make the in-store shopping experience faster and more enjoyable. Our plan is to initially roll it out to 10 stores.
We continue to believe that no one's in a better position than CarMax to deliver more of the transaction online or even deliver the car to the homes. No one can match our existing infrastructure, our national footprint, our inventory scale and our brand strength. The ability to combine state-of-the-art online experience, with the exceptional customer service our associates are known for, is what will set us apart from our competitors.
During the first quarter, we opened 2 stores, both in new markets,  one in Springfield, Illinois and one in San Francisco. We plan to open 13 other stores during the fiscal year. Subsequent to the end of the first quarter, we opened a store in El Paso, another new market for us. During the second quarter, we expect to open 2 more stores, one in Bristol, Tennessee, which is another new market for us, and the other will be our third store in the Boston market.
Now we'll open up the call for questions. Operator?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just maybe a longer-term question, just to kind of follow-up on what you were just talking about the using enhanced website. Do you foresee a time where your store count is not necessarily growing as quickly as you're expecting right now, but you're reach
componenttext: Just maybe a longer-term question, just to kind of follow-up on what you were just talking about the using enhanced website. Do you foresee a time where your store count is not necessarily growing as quickly as you're expecting right now, but you're reaching a broader set of consumers? And quite simplistically, I mean, do need as many stores to cover a market as you do now if you kind of increase this physical presence? And can you go a lot more asset-light as the business emerges over time?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. I think it's important that we do both very well. So I think in the short term, we don't have any intentions of changing up our growth as far as the fiscal stores, as we said, in the past, 13 to 16 stores is what we've committed to for this yea
componenttext: Yes, John. I think it's important that we do both very well. So I think in the short term, we don't have any intentions of changing up our growth as far as the fiscal stores, as we said, in the past, 13 to 16 stores is what we've committed to for this year and next year. And we think that to be ultimately successful, you need to have a really good presence in both. And so I think for us, it's going to be combination of continuing to expand our offering online, and then continuing to evolve our in-store process. Could we get to a point down the road, where that may change up that's hard to tell at this point.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And these efforts aren't having an impact on your showroom traffic? Are they at this point?
componenttext: And these efforts aren't having an impact on your showroom traffic? Are they at this point?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think, when you think about traffic, foot traffic, it's broadly known that consumers are being much more informed before they come into the store. So they're doing a lot of the research upfront. In our case, we know 9 out of 10 of our consumers that
componenttext: No, I think, when you think about traffic, foot traffic, it's broadly known that consumers are being much more informed before they come into the store. So they're doing a lot of the research upfront. In our case, we know 9 out of 10 of our consumers that end up purchasing from us do some homework ahead of time, from -- on carmax.com. So what we do think is they're coming in more informed. And as we look out and try to continue to get comps, we're going to be focused both on traffic, both in-store traffic to the web, and then equally focused on conversion.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess my primary question is on the cap side. And we did see, obviously, a pickup in the loan loss reserves. Where -- how would you expect that to trend for the balance of the year, given some of the unfavorable change that you saw happen during the cou
componenttext: I guess my primary question is on the cap side. And we did see, obviously, a pickup in the loan loss reserves. Where -- how would you expect that to trend for the balance of the year, given some of the unfavorable change that you saw happen during the course of the quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scot. One thing I would point out is that what we booked in the quarter, and has now booked in reserve, is a 12-month look-forward on losses. And our negative experience during the quarter is baked into our forecast for the rest of the year. So to th
componenttext: Yes, Scot. One thing I would point out is that what we booked in the quarter, and has now booked in reserve, is a 12-month look-forward on losses. And our negative experience during the quarter is baked into our forecast for the rest of the year. So to the extent things were to worsen or improve, we would adjust accordingly. But at this point, everything we know about the environment, including the experience we had in this quarter and having losses come in a little hot is baked into that forward-looking estimate. When you see the increase in that provision for loan losses, it's a combination of both our experience in the quarter versus our expectation of what we have booked, and an adjustment to the overall portfolio based on what we've learned. So it's as I said at this point, I think, everything that we've learned based on methodology is baked in.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So when you kind of peel back the onion a little bit, Tom, is it more recent vintages or is it older vintages or is it kind of a across the board?
componenttext: So when you kind of peel back the onion a little bit, Tom, is it more recent vintages or is it older vintages or is it kind of a across the board?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's a combination of things, Scot. In general, if you step back and look at it, last year's experience was very favorable. So I don't think we would have expected to have a repeat of that. That's kind of the first point. We have also seen a prett
componenttext: I think it's a combination of things, Scot. In general, if you step back and look at it, last year's experience was very favorable. So I don't think we would have expected to have a repeat of that. That's kind of the first point. We have also seen a pretty significant growth in the portfolio, which means losses are going to step-up. And then also in the last 2 years, we have expanded on the credit front a bit. If you remember, back in 2013, we got much more aggressive with customers at the very high end of credit, offering very low rates to the highest credit quality customers. That had an impact of kind of bringing down our expected losses on the portfolio. Over the last 2 years though, we have been expanding at the lower end of what CAF has done with some testing and some, I guess, of a prudent expansion, in an effort to bring our targeted cumulative net loss, back in line with where we've try to run it, at 2% to 2.5%, which is a very highly financeable portfolio itself. I think it's fair to say that activity in the last couple of years, we have gotten a bit more aggressive intentionally. And we get compensated for that with higher rates. And some of that has -- that would -- if you would have, maybe expectation of that would increase losses in the portfolio. But we did have some unfavorable experience in the quarter, as I mentioned, due to -- partially due to the expansion, partially due to the wholesale recovery rate.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Robert Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Robert Baird.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: And my question is just a follow-up on the prequalifying buyers online. Could you share more detail on what is required to do that? How long it takes? And how you're planning to handle sort of a disappointing outcome if someone doesn't get what they want?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So like I said, we're currently just testing it, getting ready to put it in 10 stores, really what we wanted to do is, we're going to prequalify them or they come into the store. We have the sales consultant involved in the process. So if someone's d
componenttext: Yes. So like I said, we're currently just testing it, getting ready to put it in 10 stores, really what we wanted to do is, we're going to prequalify them or they come into the store. We have the sales consultant involved in the process. So if someone's decline, we can contact -- we'll contact the customer. And again, the goal will be not only to give them an approval, but to also transition them into the store at this point.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: If you think about the lower sub-prime penetration, this is a bit of an acceleration in the decline year-on-year in terms of penetration and [indiscernible]. Do you expect declines to persist at this level? Do you feel that your third-party providers are
componenttext: If you think about the lower sub-prime penetration, this is a bit of an acceleration in the decline year-on-year in terms of penetration and [indiscernible]. Do you expect declines to persist at this level? Do you feel that your third-party providers are seeing similar experience to you and are in the process of pulling back up further? Do you feel like you've reached the stable level here?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Matt. It's hard to say what we expect in the future. As I've always said our goal is to have sustainable partners that are there for our customers and can provide a wide range of financing. In the quarter though, we did -- we see one line of particul
componenttext: Yes, Matt. It's hard to say what we expect in the future. As I've always said our goal is to have sustainable partners that are there for our customers and can provide a wide range of financing. In the quarter though, we did -- we see one line of particular pullback, it was Santander. I mean, you've seen them out in the public domain talking about how they are pulling back in sub-prime auto, letting other business go to other folks. So it's not inconsistent with what they've been saying in the public domain. So as far as what they will do going forward, I could say we saw a couple of different things happen during the quarter. And feel like it stabilized during the quarter. But looking forward, it's their business, they're going to manage their portfolio if they see fit. And if they determine the need to dial back or get more aggressive, that they're going to do that.  I think Matt, we've followed it a long time. You know that sub-prime as a percentage of our total sales has, at one point, it was pretty much 0. It's been as high as 19% in a year and then, I think last year, we ended at 16% or 16% for the year. So where ever it ends up, is going to be a result of a whole bunch of different factors, lender behavior, applicant flow, but what we've always talked about with this phase is, we believe each customer is almost 100% incremental. Remember also that these points of sale are also significantly less profitable. That's one of the reasons we wanted to point out that if you take out the decline of 2 points or 2.5 points, whatever it was in the quarter, that the rest of our business actually grew by 3.6%. And if you look at our mix of business as a base from which to grow, this is actually a better base from which to grow than if we go back when 19% of our sales were Tier 3. Again, we believe that 100% of it or almost 100% of it is incremental because of the way we flow financing from lender to lender. But at the same time, it's going to move around based on a whole bunch of different factors.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Totally understood. If I can just follow-up very briefly on this point. To the extent that Tier 2 extensions fell a bit, and you talked about more consumers coming in with their own -- cash or their own sources of credit. Is there -- are there competitors
componenttext: Totally understood. If I can just follow-up very briefly on this point. To the extent that Tier 2 extensions fell a bit, and you talked about more consumers coming in with their own -- cash or their own sources of credit. Is there -- are there competitors, we're kind of hearing 2 different things in a sense, to some degree, interest among low end is down and the willingness to extend credit to the low-end consumers is down. On the other hand, it does seem like perhaps some of this competing away, I don't know if this is the middle part of the market or other consumers who might otherwise shop through Tier 2. So any kind of holistic comments on whether the competition is increasing in any part of the credit spectrum?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, firstly, to remember that traffic of that FICO score applicant is down, where you kind of starts with traffic, I'll let Tom comment on competition.
componenttext: Well, firstly, to remember that traffic of that FICO score applicant is down, where you kind of starts with traffic, I'll let Tom comment on competition.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As far as Tier 2 goes, Matt, I think we mentioned last quarter that we thought some of the Tier 3 degradation was due to their Tier 2's aggressiveness or at least, the competitiveness. We have not seen any degradation in the quality of offers that th
componenttext: Yes. As far as Tier 2 goes, Matt, I think we mentioned last quarter that we thought some of the Tier 3 degradation was due to their Tier 2's aggressiveness or at least, the competitiveness. We have not seen any degradation in the quality of offers that the Tier -- our Tier 2 partners are providing or the aggressiveness or even their conversion to sale rate, which is in fact, it's better than it has been in the past couple of years. It's just they're not seeing quite the same volume they were before. So the decline in Tier 2, I would say completely on the flow of traffic, and we're very happy with how they've been performing in the quarter. We were looking out on that, but...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And the final follow-up, to the extent that Tier 3 traffic is down, or these consumers essentially anticipating a lot of credit availability given that this has been perhaps brewing the market for a little while? Or is that customer finding a better deal
componenttext: And the final follow-up, to the extent that Tier 3 traffic is down, or these consumers essentially anticipating a lot of credit availability given that this has been perhaps brewing the market for a little while? Or is that customer finding a better deal elsewhere saying that buy here or pay here channel or somewhat like that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's really -- that's almost impossible for us to tell, Matt.
componenttext: It's really -- that's almost impossible for us to tell, Matt.

And a related question, given that the Tier 3 penetration rate is down, do you feel the need to add additional lenders in that space or take on additional originations in that space?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far as our Tier 3 activity, I would characterize it as steady as she goes. We're comfortable continuing at the same pace that we've been running at, which is roughly 5% of the Tier 3 volume, getting done at the stores. So there's really no news t
componenttext: Sure. As far as our Tier 3 activity, I would characterize it as steady as she goes. We're comfortable continuing at the same pace that we've been running at, which is roughly 5% of the Tier 3 volume, getting done at the stores. So there's really no news there. I think the rationale for doing this program is still good, and still holds true. It's not about driving additional sales, it's more about knowledge, risk mitigation and some profitability. As far as looking at other Tier 3 lenders, we will do that from time to time. We have -- we test lenders when it makes sense. That space though is a little different than the Tier 2 space. I think there's fewer people that are equipped to do it on a national scale. And we're very concerned about making sure we're doing, we're working with partners who are experienced, credible and are going to have a sustainable business and be there. So we're not going to be interested in bringing a new player in that is too risky.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could just, lastly, ask the penetration from your website, I was there recently and saw a low 40% range of SUV truck, kind of cross over and van versus sedans and being obviously, high-50s. When you look at new vehicle SAAR, it's basically the in
componenttext: And if I could just, lastly, ask the penetration from your website, I was there recently and saw a low 40% range of SUV truck, kind of cross over and van versus sedans and being obviously, high-50s. When you look at new vehicle SAAR, it's basically the inverse, with 60% kind of SUV and truck. Can you guys give, kind of what that average number would've been for you all during the quarter because just from what I can gather, that could have been a several hundreds of headwind to demand as well. If you assume the same dynamics in the used market as you get on new.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Are you asking if our net should be the same as new?
componenttext: Are you asking if our net should be the same as new?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm just asking for the quarter, what's a fair way to look at your SUV and truck mix, Tom, broadly speaking, if you included crossovers? And if you ...
componenttext: I'm just asking for the quarter, what's a fair way to look at your SUV and truck mix, Tom, broadly speaking, if you included crossovers? And if you ...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right now, we haven't looked at it like that, I mean, recently so I couldn't give that number to you on the top of my head, what I will tell you is, we have always been a demand driven inventory model. So what you see on our -- and we're big enough and ha
componenttext: Right now, we haven't looked at it like that, I mean, recently so I couldn't give that number to you on the top of my head, what I will tell you is, we have always been a demand driven inventory model. So what you see on our -- and we're big enough and have enough scale that has inventory turns. We're pretty good at going out and finding it. Occasionally, there's some pockets where we don't think it's a great deal for our customers so we might be a little light in a particular area. But what you see as a overall percent of sales for the company is largely driven by consumer demand and our inventory turns. On a pace of 600,000-ish cars a year, about half of which we have to buy offsite and half of which we buy through the appraisal line approximately, we're going to buy what customers are buying from us and replenish at that same pace. So I don't expect us to match up exactly with new car sales.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Levin with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Levin with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to kind of see what you guys were seeing in terms of the ramp-up of immature store base, less than 5 years old, that's in the comps at this point. Maybe it's about 30% of your store base. How are those maturing and kind of ramping up at this poin
componenttext: I wanted to kind of see what you guys were seeing in terms of the ramp-up of immature store base, less than 5 years old, that's in the comps at this point. Maybe it's about 30% of your store base. How are those maturing and kind of ramping up at this point in terms of their support of same-store sales, and leveraging SG&A at this point? Or are they still kind of lagging in a bit of a drag?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I think if you -- first, our leverage in SG&A in any given quarter, that's going to largely be driven by comp in that quarter, particularly for a company that's in a growth mode like we have been over the last several years and plan to be over the next
componenttext: So I think if you -- first, our leverage in SG&A in any given quarter, that's going to largely be driven by comp in that quarter, particularly for a company that's in a growth mode like we have been over the last several years and plan to be over the next several. But in terms of the performance of the newer stores, and if you take a step back and you look at since we restarted growth in 2011 so fiscal 2011, we've increased our store count by 50%. So we had about 100 stores. We have a little over 150 now and over that same time frame, our net earnings are up by 65% and our EPS is up by 84%. So, I mean, I think if we really step back and look at it that way, they are clearly delivering outsized returns and returns that justify continuing to build stores. So we're very pleased with the performance of the stores. They're at or above our financial expectations as a group. And I'm glad that you asked a question over a longer period of time of 5 years, go back to 2011, I look at it again, the numbers are store base up 50%, net earnings up 65%, and EPS up 84%.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And it was the first quarter, you guys held gross profit per used units flat on a year-over-year basis in about a year. Just wondering what you're seeing there in terms of the gives and takes versus adding some more volume?
componenttext: Got it. And it was the first quarter, you guys held gross profit per used units flat on a year-over-year basis in about a year. Just wondering what you're seeing there in terms of the gives and takes versus adding some more volume?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think what we all -- a couple of dollars, year-over-year quarter, last quarter, we were about $39 off, and we've said there's a range. We think this is an area where we excel from an inventory management standpoint and feel like that we can cont
componenttext: Yes. So I think what we all -- a couple of dollars, year-over-year quarter, last quarter, we were about $39 off, and we've said there's a range. We think this is an area where we excel from an inventory management standpoint and feel like that we can continue that range, staying in that range and keep it fairly tight. Now that being said, we'll constantly be testing and looking at trade-offs if you lower the gross profit, what's the sales that you get back from that? All of the idea of looking also with your total gross profit is that you can get to. So again, we'll continue to test, but we feel like where we are right now is still the same, sustainable.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then just lastly, it was interesting to see that direct expense at CAF move up sequentially in Q1. We've seen it usually seasonally takes a tick down from 4Q to Q1. Is there anything in particular to read through there? And is this kind of the
componenttext: Got it. And then just lastly, it was interesting to see that direct expense at CAF move up sequentially in Q1. We've seen it usually seasonally takes a tick down from 4Q to Q1. Is there anything in particular to read through there? And is this kind of the level we should expect going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: There's some stock-based comp impact there as well just like there's in the -- but there's nothing extraordinary going on.
componenttext: There's some stock-based comp impact there as well just like there's in the -- but there's nothing extraordinary going on.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Irina Hodakovsky with KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We wanted to ask a couple of questions on the Tier 3 a little bit more into that. If you were to put a weight impact on lower Tier 3 traffic versus lower application approval rates, as you mentioned, some of your partners pulling back, how would you weigh
componenttext: We wanted to ask a couple of questions on the Tier 3 a little bit more into that. If you were to put a weight impact on lower Tier 3 traffic versus lower application approval rates, as you mentioned, some of your partners pulling back, how would you weigh that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. And let me be a little more clear, it's not approval rate. We -- if you look at the percent of customers that are getting up in approval of some kind in the stores that's well above 90%, what we're seeing is a decline -- a degradation in, I guess, I
componenttext: Sure. And let me be a little more clear, it's not approval rate. We -- if you look at the percent of customers that are getting up in approval of some kind in the stores that's well above 90%, what we're seeing is a decline -- a degradation in, I guess, I would the quality of the offers, meaning they might be asking for a little bit more money down or they're asking for stipulations, in particular, leasing a step up in that with one of the lenders an increase in asking for proof of income, asking for proof of residence, asking for proof of phone number and things like that. So it's not really a change in the number of approvals, but the quality of approvals and therefore, the ability the customer to accept or the willingness for the customer to accept it. And as far as the ratio, I think I would say that I can't  -- we don't want to be super excited about it because it's not easy to calculate. But I think the preponderance of the change is due to the change in behavior, call it, 2/3 and 1/3 to the traffic. And I think there's, I mentioned, traffic earlier as it relates to the space  And without giving too many specifics, what I said was, we convert these customers at a significantly lower rate than we do non-Tier 3 customer. So if you just think about it that way, it takes more flow of customers to sell 1 car than it does to sell 1 car of a non-Tier 3 customers. So if we're down by 2.5 points in Tier 3 percent of sales, it represents a disproportionately higher percentage of traffic than the sale that it generates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That make sense. Did you see any geographical concentration in lower traffic and subprime?
componenttext: That make sense. Did you see any geographical concentration in lower traffic and subprime?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we don't comment on geography.
componenttext: Yes, we don't comment on geography.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question is the wholesale business. We've seen some softening trends there for the last couple of quarters in terms of wholesale to retail unit ratio as well as profit per unit. Can you give us a sense of what's driving some of that softness? And how y
componenttext: My question is the wholesale business. We've seen some softening trends there for the last couple of quarters in terms of wholesale to retail unit ratio as well as profit per unit. Can you give us a sense of what's driving some of that softness? And how you expect the business to perform through the balance of the year?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Seth. I think if you look out long term for us, wholesale and retail pretty much grow at about the same pace. And this time, in this quarter, retail grew about 4%, wholesale grew about 2%. We don't feel like there's anything really extraordinary to n
componenttext: Yes, Seth. I think if you look out long term for us, wholesale and retail pretty much grow at about the same pace. And this time, in this quarter, retail grew about 4%, wholesale grew about 2%. We don't feel like there's anything really extraordinary to note even the profit, the gross profit margins off a little bit. But again, just like the retail side, that's within a range and there's really nothing extraordinary to note from that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. What is your buy ratio? How has that been trending? And do you see more competition to acquire vehicles?
componenttext: Okay. What is your buy ratio? How has that been trending? And do you see more competition to acquire vehicles?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. That the buy rate is still around 30%, which has been historical high. It's similar to what it was last quarter, if you get that again this quarter. So I would say that we haven't seen any indication where customers are choosing to take their vehicle
componenttext: Yes. That the buy rate is still around 30%, which has been historical high. It's similar to what it was last quarter, if you get that again this quarter. So I would say that we haven't seen any indication where customers are choosing to take their vehicles other places and having purchased by other dealers.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is there a way to size up the exposure on the wholesale side of the business to subprime?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure your question, Rick. Are you saying the...
componenttext: I'm not sure your question, Rick. Are you saying the...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It would seem here the customers that participate in the wholesale auctions, higher mileage, older vehicles, would be perhaps even more dependent on subprime finance for them to stimulate sales.
componenttext: It would seem here the customers that participate in the wholesale auctions, higher mileage, older vehicles, would be perhaps even more dependent on subprime finance for them to stimulate sales.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Oh yes, that's very difficult for us to ascertain with our customer base. I can tell you that we have, we have continued to see very, very strong attendance at our auctions and very, very strong sell-through rates. We talked about this before and these nu
componenttext: Oh yes, that's very difficult for us to ascertain with our customer base. I can tell you that we have, we have continued to see very, very strong attendance at our auctions and very, very strong sell-through rates. We talked about this before and these numbers really haven't moved very much, we're 98%, 99%-ish sell-through rate through the auctions, turning our inventory 135 times a year. Our ratio, so our dealer ratio has been very, very strong. I think it's 1.3:1. Some of the strongest ratios we've seen. We haven't seen any softening in the demand through our auctions, but you could then relate back to the some of the things that we're hearing about in Tier 3.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain with Morgan Stanley.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: A couple of questions. The first one on CAF, and going back to something you said earlier, you mentioned you were a bit more aggressive in the last 2 years with your CAF offers and that's leading to some increase in loan-loss provision. And yet, when we l
componenttext: A couple of questions. The first one on CAF, and going back to something you said earlier, you mentioned you were a bit more aggressive in the last 2 years with your CAF offers and that's leading to some increase in loan-loss provision. And yet, when we look at the securitization, the average FICO score there has been impressively been around 700. So just trying to reconcile the 2 if you can provide some color there.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, I may not have done a great job explaining it earlier. But in 2013, we began getting more aggressive with the high FICO customers. Our current lowest invest rate is still below 2% today. So what we saw is an increase in the volume of people at th
componenttext: I think, I may not have done a great job explaining it earlier. But in 2013, we began getting more aggressive with the high FICO customers. Our current lowest invest rate is still below 2% today. So what we saw is an increase in the volume of people at the very highest end of the credit spectrum, which is -- have the effect of potentially bringing down our loss expectations. And so over the last 2 years, we've been trying to manage back towards a range that we're comfortable -- we've been comfortable with for a long time in the securitization market. So you can almost think of that as a bit of a barbell affect. You wouldn't see a dramatic change, step down in the overall FICO because we're adding it at the top end and the lower end.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. And then a question on traffic. A superstore, obviously, helps with the conversion rate, but traffic has been an issue for a few quarters now. And at the same time, latest report suggests industry retail sales are growing at a healthy clip. So
componenttext: Understood. And then a question on traffic. A superstore, obviously, helps with the conversion rate, but traffic has been an issue for a few quarters now. And at the same time, latest report suggests industry retail sales are growing at a healthy clip. So is that because of these aggregate websites taking traffic elsewhere? And if so, would you consider having a bigger presence on aggregated websites?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We would actually consider any website, and we've tried several, we've been on all of the big ones. We're on -- where we continue to test, I think all of our cars are currently on Car Gurus. So we tested all the aggregators and we'll use anything that hel
componenttext: We would actually consider any website, and we've tried several, we've been on all of the big ones. We're on -- where we continue to test, I think all of our cars are currently on Car Gurus. So we tested all the aggregators and we'll use anything that helps us drive incremental sales and delivers a good return. One additional comment on traffic, Bill mentioned some of this earlier, is it's been widely reported that customers are visiting less stores before they buy. So it only makes sense that customers who show up, would be more likely to buy. And as I've said, we think comps will be driven by traffic and conversion. It's not going to always line up and it doesn't matter to us, which way we get it. So lot of the efforts we're making around developing a new website, giving the customer more digital capability are -- those efforts are to make sure that customers get more information, do more research, are more prepared. It's clear that that's what they want to do and we want to be in a position to do that for them. So when they show up, they're more likely to buy.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King Associates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: The charge-off, the increase in charge-off, was there any particular concentration in the profile of customers that you saw with these charge-offs? Or was this more driven by the lower recovery rates since this is a net number?
componenttext: The charge-off, the increase in charge-off, was there any particular concentration in the profile of customers that you saw with these charge-offs? Or was this more driven by the lower recovery rates since this is a net number?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, this quarter, we feel like it was driven by the recovery -- it's a combination of both, but the recovery rate probably had a little more weight this quarter. And as far as any specifics around customers, we really don't have anything.
componenttext: Yes. I think, this quarter, we feel like it was driven by the recovery -- it's a combination of both, but the recovery rate probably had a little more weight this quarter. And as far as any specifics around customers, we really don't have anything.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then over the recovery rate going down, is that simply a function of the Manheim or overall wholesale prices softening up a little bit during the quarter? Or were there some mix issues as well? Are you getting more sedans versus SUVs in the char
componenttext: Okay. And then over the recovery rate going down, is that simply a function of the Manheim or overall wholesale prices softening up a little bit during the quarter? Or were there some mix issues as well? Are you getting more sedans versus SUVs in the charge-off mix?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think it's just -- it's a by-product of overall pricing and the wholesale market as you probably know, when we resell cars, we typically sell them off at our auctions and we realize whatever the auction market is delivering at that point in time. An
componenttext: No, I think it's just -- it's a by-product of overall pricing and the wholesale market as you probably know, when we resell cars, we typically sell them off at our auctions and we realize whatever the auction market is delivering at that point in time. And as I said, year-over-year, we're down about 5 points in that wholesale recovery rate. And we never really see much mix impact on the recovery rate that's always because it's a pretty big sample, it's generally going to be a macro trend that's going to impact the recovery rate.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of David Whiston with MorningStar.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of David Whiston with MorningStar.

componenttext: Just wanted to go back, I think, to an answer on earlier question, I was trying to ascertain why applications in traffic are falling at the lower end of the credit spectrum. And it sounds like you're really just not sure, is that fair?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's fair.
componenttext: That's fair.

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

componenttext: Okay. And then on auction prices, would you say, are there any particular areas that are rather are still too high, in your opinion? Are you spending a huge fall off as more vehicles come off lease?

componenttext: Correct.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: We've talked about these volume in the past. And this past year, leases were 32% of used cars -- new car sales, roughly. That means you'll see that flow come back in the next 3 years, 2 or 3 years. We've seen some increase this year, but I think we'll see
componenttext: We've talked about these volume in the past. And this past year, leases were 32% of used cars -- new car sales, roughly. That means you'll see that flow come back in the next 3 years, 2 or 3 years. We've seen some increase this year, but I think we'll see big increases in lease turn-ins in the next couple of years. Not so much this year so far.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And we do have a follow-up question from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And we do have a follow-up question from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So my first question relates to stock comp. The number was up big year-on-year. Last year, Q1, had been a pretty good number too. If you look back over time, there hasn't necessarily been that much seasonality of the stock comp, and at the moment of time,
componenttext: So my first question relates to stock comp. The number was up big year-on-year. Last year, Q1, had been a pretty good number too. If you look back over time, there hasn't necessarily been that much seasonality of the stock comp, and at the moment of time, the stock has been under some pressure as a bit surprised to see the number increase so much over anything you had in the past. So can you talk about what that related to, please?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, what you got to look at, Matt, is the year-over-year change in the stock price. So I'm not sure what exactly what happened in the year ago quarter, but that the lion share of the difference is going to be arising from the difference in the change thi
componenttext: Yes, what you got to look at, Matt, is the year-over-year change in the stock price. So I'm not sure what exactly what happened in the year ago quarter, but that the lion share of the difference is going to be arising from the difference in the change this year versus the change last year's first quarter. And the change in a number of folks that are getting.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is it the year-on-year change in the stock price because year-on-year, kind of today, to exactly a year ago stuff down more than 20%. So is it magnitude of comp that's being dumped through stock? Is it -- does it have to do with exercise prices on options
componenttext: Is it the year-on-year change in the stock price because year-on-year, kind of today, to exactly a year ago stuff down more than 20%. So is it magnitude of comp that's being dumped through stock? Is it -- does it have to do with exercise prices on options? What would the number be, what would the driver be when we take the dollars up so much?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's largely related to our restricted stock program that the majority of our associates get because those are going to fluctuate with the market value of the stock. And what you have to look at is not the year-over-year stock price, but the year-over-yea
componenttext: It's largely related to our restricted stock program that the majority of our associates get because those are going to fluctuate with the market value of the stock. And what you have to look at is not the year-over-year stock price, but the year-over-year change in stock price during the particular quarter.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. So to the extent that you might have started lower and moved higher that would have moved higher. Okay, we can follow up. It's a very big number and frankly, I think most of the shortfalls versus consensus probably could be traced to that li
componenttext: Got it. Okay. So to the extent that you might have started lower and moved higher that would have moved higher. Okay, we can follow up. It's a very big number and frankly, I think most of the shortfalls versus consensus probably could be traced to that line item. Another question, since I have you. The SUVs as a percent of the mix recovered nicely, and do you feel like your ability to buy those cars at prices that you like is essentially back or the markets normalizing? Is your ability to navigate those dynamics improved as we've moved into 2016 here?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think to what Tom said earlier, we're going to get the mix in there based off of consumer demand. Are we are able to get that inventory? And we feel like you're able to get it? I still think it's probably a little bit high. But again, we're not hav
componenttext: Yes. I think to what Tom said earlier, we're going to get the mix in there based off of consumer demand. Are we are able to get that inventory? And we feel like you're able to get it? I still think it's probably a little bit high. But again, we're not having an issue or troubles sourcing it.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then finally, a question on one financial detail. So you have this new disclosure on the other revenue and gross profit item essentially. The new vehicles plus the service piece is baked in there. So the year-on-year increase and other gross profit is
componenttext: And then finally, a question on one financial detail. So you have this new disclosure on the other revenue and gross profit item essentially. The new vehicles plus the service piece is baked in there. So the year-on-year increase and other gross profit is a bit bigger than what we can track explicitly to the higher warranty revenue and the lower third-party fees. I think you take those out and there's still a few million dollars. Is that all related to presumably lower losses or better grosses on new plus higher service gross profit? Or is there anything else from the number that would move it higher?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matt, I think you hit it on the head. The ESP and GAP are a little bit better than sales because we've got some more margin in there. But -- and obviously, the finance penetration is causing us to be favorable. There's some service favorability in there,
componenttext: Matt, I think you hit it on the head. The ESP and GAP are a little bit better than sales because we've got some more margin in there. But -- and obviously, the finance penetration is causing us to be favorable. There's some service favorability in there, that makes -- that pretty much makes up the difference.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: But nothing out of the ordinary? Nothing extraordinary one-time, et cetera?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think it's a little early on, but what I'll tell you is one of the big drivers that we're looking for is what we call lead. So it's point to our customer either e-mails us, sets an appointment, calls us, and our goal with the new website is to m
componenttext: Yes. So I think it's a little early on, but what I'll tell you is one of the big drivers that we're looking for is what we call lead. So it's point to our customer either e-mails us, sets an appointment, calls us, and our goal with the new website is to make sure that we generate more leads because leads are highly correlated to sales. So ultimately, you want to drive traffic, traffic will then drive the leads. We're at the point now where we're trying to figure out how those leads convert in comparison to the old website. We feel good about the leads it's generating. But again, we're trying to understand the conversion of those leads.

componenttext: Home delivery, we referenced that in the last call. We did do a test, we've since pulled back on the test, we're looking at how to better operationalize that and we'll be coming out with another test later this fall on the home delivery. As far as the full transaction online, that's something that we'll continue to explore. Like I said earlier today, we started looking online financing as a component of that. And again, part of that will also be driven by the consumer demand and need for doing the whole transaction online as well as making sure that we stay within the state restrictions of what can be done online, what can't be done online.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I did have a question regarding buyback expectations. I thought the general plan was to do a pretty steady run rate quarter-after-quarter, but obviously, the buyback was a little bit softer than I think the pattern we've seen recently. What's the general
componenttext: I did have a question regarding buyback expectations. I thought the general plan was to do a pretty steady run rate quarter-after-quarter, but obviously, the buyback was a little bit softer than I think the pattern we've seen recently. What's the general idea of moving forward? If it can't be more of an opportunistic pattern? Or should be a relatively steady run rate from what we just saw in 1Q?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Scot. I think our goal as you've talked about before, is to be kind of a steady player in there, but we're going to have some latitude around how aggressive we are based on where the stock prices and our view of valuation. As I -- we talked about, we
componenttext: Yes, Scot. I think our goal as you've talked about before, is to be kind of a steady player in there, but we're going to have some latitude around how aggressive we are based on where the stock prices and our view of valuation. As I -- we talked about, we're targeting a certain capital structure that debt-to-capital, excluding the nonrecourse stuff and account receivables of kind of 35% to 45%. We -- a quarter or so ago, we got up to the bottom end of that range. So it would be natural to see a little bit of a tapering off as we can move from a mode of moving to the -- a newer capital structure, a more leverage capital structure to one of maintaining that capital structure. That said, with the amount of cash that we have generating it and becoming all things being equal, the amount of cash we generate, the amount of growth we're doing, we would expect to continue to need to repurchase shares and add debt into the capital structure to maintain that. So I would say, our expectation is to be in the market on a pretty consistent basis going forward, but we do have some parameters around our program that allows to be more or less aggressive to any of market conditions.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So the change in pace is more a function of kind of getting to that lower end of the cap structure rather than your assessment of the value of the stocks, [indiscernible] you just said, Tom, regarding being opportunistic?
componenttext: Okay. So the change in pace is more a function of kind of getting to that lower end of the cap structure rather than your assessment of the value of the stocks, [indiscernible] you just said, Tom, regarding being opportunistic?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes, going from moving towards the capital structure to maintaining it. So that would have a natural change of pace. But as I said, we're -- I think we ended the quarter a little bit below this quarter. So we've got that latitude of some 10 points that we will be working with that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to kind of get your feelings around the recovery rates that have been down on auto ABS across the market and for you guys, this quarter. Is that playing a role in some of the tightening standards that you're seeing? How do you think that's kin
componenttext: Just wanted to kind of get your feelings around the recovery rates that have been down on auto ABS across the market and for you guys, this quarter. Is that playing a role in some of the tightening standards that you're seeing? How do you think that's kind of going to progress going forward in terms of credit availability, and cost of borrowing for your securitizations?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, I would point to -- we've been doing securitization, independent securitizations for over 13 years now and we've been able to manage through a lot of different market conditions, including recovery rates that are lower than what they are today. T
componenttext: I guess, I would point to -- we've been doing securitization, independent securitizations for over 13 years now and we've been able to manage through a lot of different market conditions, including recovery rates that are lower than what they are today. That said, the structure and the enhancement of the deal might need to be modified if loss, if the perceived losses in the rating agency size change. What that usually means though is the change in the over collateralization to get built some of the deals and builds over time, I mean, we get money back a little bit slower. But in general, we have been maintaining a pretty solid program through a lot of different environments. As far as our partner lenders, I just have asked them about how they view that and their tightening, but again, they -- I think, probably more of the impact is what they're experiencing in their portfolio than the overall wholesale market.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: Got it. And if I remember correctly, a couple of years ago, when Santander did some pulling back, you guys added some lenders to the platform. Are you considering that now as well?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016

componenttext: Yes. As I mentioned earlier, we would -- we'll test partners to the extent it makes sense for us. But as I also said, in this space, I think we need to be much more careful about who we're doing business with and make sure that we have established partners that can be a reliable source of financing for our customers over a longer period of time. I know there's -- it's been talked of a lot of new players out there that are behaving aggressively, Santander has talked about that as well that they're willing to let some of them get the business. But we're very focused on -- in the right place for our customers and as I said, we'll test as appropriate, but not many people have the national scale that we would need.

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think and you saw a step-up versus recent years, a lot of that is due to timing of what we expect land acquisitions to do over the next year. I really wouldn't read into it too much as far as the existing stores or anything. We -- we're working on
componenttext: Yes, I think and you saw a step-up versus recent years, a lot of that is due to timing of what we expect land acquisitions to do over the next year. I really wouldn't read into it too much as far as the existing stores or anything. We -- we're working on a pipeline of many, many different locations, the next 3 to 4 years of growth, and our ability to acquire land is different in every situation. And I think as we look forward this year, we just saw a little bit heavier land acquisition than we've done in the past. And there's a lot of timing in there too as well so if you look at the tail end of this year, there'll be significant investment in the openings that are coming the following years. So that's just our best guess, that timing over the next 12 months.

componenttext: Okay. Then a one follow-up. Just want to get your overall thoughts on the whole awfully supply that's surging. I mean you're already sourcing about 77% of your units [indiscernible], which was really impressive. Is there a reason to think that the added off-lease supply would actually accelerate that mix? Or is it really just, instead of sourcing trade-ins, you're now sourcing off-lease supply, like what -- how do you think about that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I kind of think they're unrelated. I mean we're going to drive -- try to drive as much as we can through our own appraisal lane -- I think when they off lease, supply starts to come back, like Tom said earlier, we haven't seen a big off-lease supply
componenttext: Yes, I kind of think they're unrelated. I mean we're going to drive -- try to drive as much as we can through our own appraisal lane -- I think when they off lease, supply starts to come back, like Tom said earlier, we haven't seen a big off-lease supply coming back into the auction houses, but certainly, when it does come back in, we'll be in a position to buy them because we turn inventory so quickly there are good deals -- we'll be able to realize those good deals for our customers. So we kind of think around separately, appraisal lane versus off-site. But historically, when there's been a big lease volume and it comes back at the sale, we're usually in a pretty good position to take advantage of it. And just on a side note, it does organize the cars a lot better at the auction.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And how does the organization help? Can you maybe just walk through that? You can play in better or?
componenttext: And how does the organization help? Can you maybe just walk through that? You can play in better or?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. In any given year, there's going to be -- people are getting out of their car, let's say, every 3, 4, 5 years. Well, when it's leasing, it's pretty programmed that they're going to get out at a certain time. And a lot of those cars go back through w
componenttext: Sure. In any given year, there's going to be -- people are getting out of their car, let's say, every 3, 4, 5 years. Well, when it's leasing, it's pretty programmed that they're going to get out at a certain time. And a lot of those cars go back through whoever the lessor was. And then those lessors, then run big, long lanes at the auction as opposed to those same cars, which might end up at the auction otherwise are spread out. And GMAC could be running 1,000 cars in a row.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q1 2017 Earnings Call, Jun 21, 2016
