headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax Fiscal 2017 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Thank you. I would now like to tur
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax Fiscal 2017 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] 
Thank you. I would now like to turn the call over to Katharine Kenny, Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Victoria, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our Fiscal 2017 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. On the call with me today is Bill Nash, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President
componenttext:
Thank you, Victoria, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our Fiscal 2017 Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. On the call with me today is Bill Nash, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO. 
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them. For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 28, 2016, filed with the SEC.
Before I turn the call over to Bill, [Operator Instructions] 
Bill?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Katharine, and good morning, everyone. First, I want to take a moment just to thank Tom Folliard for his significant contributions to CarMax over the last 23 years. We're very fortunate that he is still involved and will be our Chairman of our
componenttext:
Thank you, Katharine, and good morning, everyone. First, I want to take a moment just to thank Tom Folliard for his significant contributions to CarMax over the last 23 years. We're very fortunate that he is still involved and will be our Chairman of our Board. I'm looking forward to continuing to work with him. So Tom, if you're listening, which I'm sure you are, since I know there are no Boston sports teams playing at this time in the morning, thank you. Thank you from all of us here at CarMax.
Over these past few months, I spent a lot of time on the road, visiting our stores and talking with our associates. I am incredibly proud of them. Our 22,000 associates across the country are doing an awesome job, delivering the best car shopping experience in the industry. The success of our company is due to our great, and I'm committed to maintaining our strong workplace culture. I'm also very excited about the opportunity we have ahead of us. In addition to our great associates, we have a top-notch management team here at the home office, CarMax Auto Finance, and in all of our stores to lead us into the future. 
More than 20 years ago, CarMax was founded to fundamentally change the way used car buying is done. We have revolutionized the used car buying experience, and our brand offer continues to resonate with customers. Now we're focused on extending that revolutionary experience. We are in a unique position to leverage our core strength, which is the exceptional customer experience our associates are known for and extend it into a state-of-the-art online experience.
We've launched a new website. We're testing new online shopping capabilities, and we are continuing to build out a new technology infrastructure. All of these elements will ensure the entire car-buying process is simple and seamless, both online and in our stores. And we are confident that our systems and processes put us in the best position to drive scalability and efficient execution nationwide.
Keep in mind, we still only reach about 65% of the U.S. population. We're committed to our national expansion, and we'll open 15 stores this year and 13 to 16 stores next year. 
Now I'll take a few moments to review some of the highlights of our second quarter results before I turn the call over to Tom Reedy to address financing. Then I'll conclude with an update on some of our strategic initiatives. 
Our total used unit comps for the second quarter increased by over 3%, and total used units grew 7%. Total used unit comps were driven by strong improvement conversion, but it was partially offset by a decline in traffic. As we discussed last quarter, we believe our decrease in traffic was largely due to the continuation of less traffic from customers at the lower end of the credit spectrum. Used unit comps for our non-Tier 3 customers were significantly stronger this quarter at over 8%. 
When it comes our total web traffic, it increased 4% compared with the prior year quarter. Gross profit per used unit at 21 60 remain consistent with 21 66 in the second quarter of last year. Our wholesale units declined by 1.3% in the second quarter. Compared to the second quarter of last year we had 1 less Monday this quarter and approximately 55% of our auctions take place on Mondays. Excluding the effect of the calendar shift, we estimate this year is also vehicle unit sales growth would have been 1.4% year-over-year. 
Gross profit for wholesale units decreased to $870 compared to the gross profit per unit of $951 last second quarter. Last year's gross profit per unit was exceptionally strong, so it was a tough comparison. 
Let me cover a few other topics before I turn the call over to Tom. As a percentage of sales mix this quarter, 0 to 4-year-old vehicles fell to 76% compared to 79% last year as a result of higher customer demand from older and less expensive vehicles. 
On the expense side, SG&A for the second quarter increased 11% to $366 million. This growth partially reflects the 11% or 16-store increase in our store base since the beginning of the second quarter of last year and an $18 million increase in share-based compensation expense.
Included in the share-based compensation expense was approximately $7 million, which relates, like every quarter, to nonexecutive compensation units that are settled in cash. This expense is driven by the change in CarMax's stock price during a quarter versus the change in the previous year's quarter. So the expense in this second quarter was based on a $5 increase in price versus a decrease of $10 in last year's second quarter.
The other $11 million included in share-based compensation expense is related to the board's decision to modify certain equity awards previously granted to Tom Folliard. These modifications effectively treated Tom as a retiree, even though he's somewhat younger, but he's far exceeded the service requirement having been here for 23 years. These changes did not accelerate the original vesting of his awards or extend the original terms. 
Now, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. Consistent with recent quarters, we experienced a year-over-year increase in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and a decline across the lower end. This mix drove growth in th
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. Consistent with recent quarters, we experienced a year-over-year increase in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and a decline across the lower end. This mix drove growth in the percentage of sales financed by CAF and growth in sales from customers paid cash or brought their own financing.
CAF net penetration increased to 45.3% compared with 43.3% in last year's second quarter. Net loans originated in the quarter rose more than 8% year-over-year to $1.4 billion due to a combination of CarMax's sales growth and our higher penetration. Tier 2 penetration fell year-over-year in the quarter by about 1 percentage point to 16.2%. While our Tier 2 lenders performance based on what we see on the are conversion of customers to sales continued to be strong, they were impacted by the decrease in volume for lower-end credit applications as well. 
In addition to this lower volume, Tier 3 sales continued to be effective at credit tightening at one of our third-party lenders. Tier 3 sales mix was 9.5% of used unit sales compared to 13.7% in the same period last year. This level of decline does not represent further tightening from what we experienced starting in the middle of Q1 this year.
CAF income of $96 million represented a decrease of 2.3% compared to the second quarter of fiscal 2016. This was due to a higher provision for loan losses and a lower interest margin, partially offset by a 12% growth in average managed receivables to over $10 billion. 
The year-over-year increase in the provision for loan losses in the second quarter reflected some unfavorable experience in the current quarter, the growth in receivables and the additional allowance that we booked based on our Q1 experience. Our ending allowance for loan losses at $110 million was 1.08% of ending management receivables compared to 1.05% last quarter and 0.96% in prior year's second quarter. The allowance reflects the combination of both our experience in the quarter and adjustment for the overall portfolio based on what we've learned. This current level of loss reserve is consistent with our range of expectations given our origination strategy in our portfolio mix.
For loans originated during the quarter, the weighted average contract rate charged to customers was 7.4%, similar to 7.2% last year's second quarter. Total interest margin declined to 5.9% of average managed receivables compared to 6.2% in the second quarter of last year. The total interest margin, however, has been at about 5.9% for 3 consecutive quarters. 
Now switching gears from CAF to CarMax. Like last quarter, interest expense is up year-over-year to $14 million compared to $7 million in the second quarter of fiscal 2016. This was due to higher average debt levels, which as we've discussed, are a deliberate component of our capital structure strategy as well as the store lease extensions that we've previously discussed in our filings.
During the second quarter, we took down the remaining $200 million of the private debt deal we closed in Q1, and we repurchased 2.4 million shares for $126 million. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Bill.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. During the second quarter, we opened 3 stores: El Paso, Texas and Bristol, Tennessee, both of which were new market for us. We also open a third store in Boston. Subsequent to the end of the second quarter, we opened a store in Boise, Idaho,
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. During the second quarter, we opened 3 stores: El Paso, Texas and Bristol, Tennessee, both of which were new market for us. We also open a third store in Boston. Subsequent to the end of the second quarter, we opened a store in Boise, Idaho, another new market for us. During the third quarter, we expect to open 5 more stores, 4 will be in current markets, including Philadelphia, Orlando and 2 in San Francisco. The fifth will be in Grand Rapids, a new market for us. 
Last quarter, I talked about how we are testing different online components of the selling process to better understand and meet our customers' needs. I'd like to give you an update on those efforts.
I previously shared with you that we had rolled out a new adaptive, more intuitive website. The new website combines an upgraded and enhanced design with a seamless experience across all devices. We also upgraded the entire site to a state-of-the-art technology platform, which will allow us to more quickly innovate, test new capabilities and personalize the experience. This is the first full quarter with the new website in place, and we are pleased with the performance so far. We've seen a positive response based on increased engagement activity such as inventory searches, viewing of car page details and creating personalized accounts. With our new site, we have to continue to drive leads and convert more customers from the website to store and finally to a sale.
Second, we've been testing an online financing capability to help our customers get prequalified for a loan before they choose a specific vehicle. Taking the prequalified for financing from any computer or mobile device, and then finish their shopping experience more quickly in the store. We've expanded the pilot to 13 stores, and we are encouraged by the customer response. We are looking forward to rolling out the finished product to all our stores in the next couple of months, and we will provide you with an update next quarter. 
Lastly, we've previously mentioned that we conducted a small test of home delivery. This allows the customers to shop for and buy a car at their convenience without coming into the store. We are now conducting another larger test in Charlotte, North Carolina. Through this test, we hope to learn the best ways to further operationalize this offering and deliver our hallmark exceptional customer service experience outside the store. We believe no one is in a better position to deliver as much of the car-buying experience online as the customer wants. We believe that we are uniquely positioned to give customers the ability to go between the digital experience and the in-store experience whenever and however they would like. CarMax is national footprint, unparalleled inventory and branch strength position us to continue to lead the industry. 
Now I'll open it up for questions. Victoria?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016

componenttext: Bill, welcome to the CEO role. So I guess a couple of questions I'll squish them together here. But first off, with respect to used car unit comps. So there was a lot of estimate for, I guess, a lot of noise with regard to forecast for the quarter. As I look at the results, call it a 3% used car unit comp was quite good in the sense that it suggested an acceleration from first quarter levels. So the question I have there is as you look at the dynamic behind that, can you help us identify what may have changed in the environment for CarMax here in Q2 versus Q1 to help the facilitate that acceleration be used car unit comps? Will be a follow-up.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So first of all, Brian, we are encouraged by the overall comps of that a little over 3%. We're equally encouraged that we got that even with the headwind that we faced in the Tier 3 space. So again if you look at just the noncore -- I'm sorry, the no
componenttext: Yes. So first of all, Brian, we are encouraged by the overall comps of that a little over 3%. We're equally encouraged that we got that even with the headwind that we faced in the Tier 3 space. So again if you look at just the noncore -- I'm sorry, the non-Tier 3 sales, it was really at 8% so we feel good about that. And I think really what you're saying is the culmination of a bunch of different initiatives and better execution at the store level. I can't pinpoint it to best one thing that's driving comps this quarter over last quarter. I think it's the culminations from the strategic initiatives that we've been talking about and I think also just better execution of the store level.

componenttext: Yes. I think on the supply side, I think the expectations were that it was going to be coming back more on full force at this point and continue on later into next year and the year after. We really haven't seen a big, huge increase in the supply of late-model cars. I think there is some coming out there, but we haven't seen the big increase that I think was originally expected. And we think it will come. And our external partners, being the options, I think they'll come later this into next year and even the year after.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And then my follow-up on the comp [indiscernible] with respect to the credit business the loan loss provision there, just help us understand that. I get it. They're still very small numbers, but the 1.4% here in the second quarter was up modestly year-on-year sequentially. But how should we think about that increases? Is it more one-time in nature or is there something happening in the business?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: What I can say, Brian, is that it incorporates everything we've learned about the portfolio to date. We can't speak to how things are going to migrate in the future. But I think it's important to point out that we've been in an environment of very favorab
componenttext: What I can say, Brian, is that it incorporates everything we've learned about the portfolio to date. We can't speak to how things are going to migrate in the future. But I think it's important to point out that we've been in an environment of very favorable, not just we, but the overall credit markets in general, have been in a very favorable loss environment for the last few years and last couple of years, at least. And it's not usually surprising to see things start to migrate a little bit differently. That said, all we can put into our provision is what we learned to date. We're not making any prognostications about the future and continued movement. And obviously, we will keep a close eye on it and adjust our strategies, if it merits that. I mean, as I think you pointed out, quarter-over-quarter, sequentially, it's not that big of an uptick. If you look year-over-year, it's a pretty significant jump, about -- but about half of that jump, we would have expected based on the fact that the portfolio has grown 12% and the experience that we had from -- in Q1, we incorporated into our provision for this quarter. So there was some unexpected unfavorable experience, but much of the change in the provision shouldn't be too unexpected even though it was a previous step-up.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess I'm going to ask 2 questions that really quickly. The sub-prime degradation you're seeing, Tom, can you talk whether that's more the applications or the approval side? Have you seen a little bit of both? And whether there's any stabilization you'r
componenttext: I guess I'm going to ask 2 questions that really quickly. The sub-prime degradation you're seeing, Tom, can you talk whether that's more the applications or the approval side? Have you seen a little bit of both? And whether there's any stabilization you're seeing in there?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, sure. I think I mentioned -- we're seeing it on both sides, right? If you can a look at our degradation year-over-year, we'd estimate that about 40% of the decline is due to application volume, and the remaining 60% is really due to a change in beha
componenttext: Sure, sure. I think I mentioned -- we're seeing it on both sides, right? If you can a look at our degradation year-over-year, we'd estimate that about 40% of the decline is due to application volume, and the remaining 60% is really due to a change in behavior with our lenders, one lender in particular. So as far as stabilization, I think what we saw happen last quarter was during the quarter, during Q1, Santander, who's been in the press about talking about how they're pulling back in different spaces. We saw change in behavior there in the middle of the quarter, so we didn't really get a full quarter's impact of it in Q1. But since May, we've seen stable performance in the Tier 3 space. That doesn't -- I'm not speaking to the future, but we've seen 4 months of stability, and this quarter reflects kind of a full quarter of the new world as it was since those changes. As far as the changes, it's more of the thing that we talked about in the past as we've seen changes in lender behavior our global approval rate is still well above 90%. But the quality of the offers and the attractiveness of those offers to the customers, it becomes worse if they're asking for more down or if they're asking for stipulations like proof of income, et cetera. And so that's the nature of the tightening that we've seen.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess as a follow-up to that, does this in anyway kind of change your attitude towards maybe expanding the CAF test and subprime? Or I know you're always testing other lenders. Is there anything you can do there to augment what's happening with Santande
componenttext: I guess as a follow-up to that, does this in anyway kind of change your attitude towards maybe expanding the CAF test and subprime? Or I know you're always testing other lenders. Is there anything you can do there to augment what's happening with Santander?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think, as you pointed out, we're obviously looking at testing other lenders. We got a test running right now, but it's not big enough to talk about. The interesting thing about this spaces that there's very few national players. It's a much more reg
componenttext: No, I think, as you pointed out, we're obviously looking at testing other lenders. We got a test running right now, but it's not big enough to talk about. The interesting thing about this spaces that there's very few national players. It's a much more regional space in the financing world. So we can't just additional lenders as far as CarMax Auto Finance, we're comfortable with our level of activity where it is. I mean, they're -- we're not Santander is not pulling out because of the delighted with what we're seeing in the portfolio. And when we think about that space, there's more to it than just the profit. There's impact on our brand. There's impact on our reputation with customers. And in this current environment, I think we're happier being thought of as a prime lender that has some activity in the Tier 3 space. We're learning from it. We're learning how to originate. We're learning how to service. We're learning how to perform, and we're building a track record in that space, but we haven't determined that it now is the time to go forward with anything greater. And if you remember when we first rolled this out a couple of years ago, we've said specifically that we were not interested in this space in order to augment sales at CarMax. It was more of a learning and potential profit plan. And then we would -- could be one of the several players in this space.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys did talk about seeing some slower traffic trends from lower credit quality customers last quarter as well. With more time to kind of analyze your data and the kind of surveys you're doing, do you have any more clarity on what may be driving that?
componenttext: You guys did talk about seeing some slower traffic trends from lower credit quality customers last quarter as well. With more time to kind of analyze your data and the kind of surveys you're doing, do you have any more clarity on what may be driving that? I'm trying to figure out are people kind of disqualifying themselves from even walking in because they know that they're going to be declined credit? Or is this just fewer footsteps coming from a certain portion of the consumer base?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's difficult to pry all that data, Scot. So unfortunately, I think we're not going to have a satisfying answer for you on that. We can really only comment on what we've seen in our stores. One thing we do believe is there is some correlation between the
componenttext: It's difficult to pry all that data, Scot. So unfortunately, I think we're not going to have a satisfying answer for you on that. We can really only comment on what we've seen in our stores. One thing we do believe is there is some correlation between the quality of offer that we're providing in the stores and the application volume because there's word-of-mouth in the customer space. The quality of offer is currently down year-over-year, and it has declined over the last several quarters. But...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: When you say quality of offer, you're talking about terms?
componenttext: When you say quality of offer, you're talking about terms?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm talking about terms, not whether they're approved or not but whether they're approved in [indiscernible] $100,000 [ph] down or is there something else. What we've observed in the stores is a reduction in those applications, call it the below 600 FICO
componenttext: I'm talking about terms, not whether they're approved or not but whether they're approved in [indiscernible] $100,000 [ph] down or is there something else. What we've observed in the stores is a reduction in those applications, call it the below 600 FICO level and continued increases in the volume applications on the high end. Now I can't speak to what other people are experiencing, but we have seen some communications from other retailers that this particular segment of customer is a bit challenged today. So to the extent that might planned the things, it's there. But we ask about that and what you might do about it as we think about the hypothesis of what could be driving this, it's not apparent tested. There's a course or a change our action in the segment that will be appropriate. Remember, we've always talked about this business I think incremental, and we already invested $1,000 per car into this channel in order to realize half, 1/3 to 1/2 of the profit of the Tier 2 or a CAF deal. So we can speculate that what our lenders like to see more money from us in order to be more aggressive. I'm sure they would say they'd try. But I don't think we're interested in increasing or decreasing our margin any further on this space. And we're certainly not interested in increasing prices to subsidize our Tier 3 partners. That's just not a good business for us. I think the investments will discuss in our online capabilities and customer experience are a high priority for us. And looking at the business, absent the effect of the Tier 3 space, we're not -- we're pretty pleased with the momentum we see at the 8% comps. And in the longer term, growing off of the base of 45% CAF and 10% Tier 3 is a much more profitable equation, than what we're seeing in Tier 3 near 20% a couple of years ago. So I don't now, what's it's make of the overall environment. But like I said, I don't think there's any action, of course, we will change to try to address phenomenon we're seeing.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I've got one question and one follow-up if you let me. We talked about traffic and some of the traffic declines. We haven't spoken a lot about the quality of traffic, not in terms of the creditworthiness, but in terms of how much research consumers have d
componenttext: I've got one question and one follow-up if you let me. We talked about traffic and some of the traffic declines. We haven't spoken a lot about the quality of traffic, not in terms of the creditworthiness, but in terms of how much research consumers have done and one would think that the attachment rate of heavy web research is a transaction has grown substantially. So is traffic as relevant of a metric for you? I mean, that could be a function of why that could be why conversions rise the way it is. So are we that should be if you look the traffic at this moment in time, I will is as of the legacy of metric, but it doesn't seem to be aligning with your comps and perhaps that's the reason why.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Matt, I think that's a good point. I think we know that 9 out of 10 of our customers in the buying from us start their shopping experience online. They're coming in with better research already having been done. I think for us, store traffic is still i
componenttext: So Matt, I think that's a good point. I think we know that 9 out of 10 of our customers in the buying from us start their shopping experience online. They're coming in with better research already having been done. I think for us, store traffic is still important. And to your point, it has been kind of a legacy metric for us. But I think equally important as we need to be looking at web traffic. We need to be looking at leads. Leads are highly, in the past, have been highly correlated to sales. So I think, you have to step back and take a more holistic picture and not just look at traffic because I do think part of the reason conversion is up, I think it's from execution bounds. I think it's partly because people are coming in more informed and knowing what they want.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: My follow-up, really, is to kind of stop sale. All independent used car retailers are operating, I believe, with lesser restriction than franchise dealers at least when it relates to the franchise -- at least as it relates to the brands associated with th
componenttext: My follow-up, really, is to kind of stop sale. All independent used car retailers are operating, I believe, with lesser restriction than franchise dealers at least when it relates to the franchise -- at least as it relates to the brands associated with those dealers that typically sell. Are you getting a sense that this is taking your share higher? Are more customers coming to you because they can to get access to the cars they want at the franchise deal?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I mean that's really a hard thing to comment. I would say that we believe we're not necessarily getting something benefit from that. We're real proud of the transparency that we have when it comes to recalls. We've led the industry. If you shop online
componenttext: No. I mean that's really a hard thing to comment. I would say that we believe we're not necessarily getting something benefit from that. We're real proud of the transparency that we have when it comes to recalls. We've led the industry. If you shop online, you'll see you have the ability to check this website to see if there's any open recall. When you come in the stores, you can't buy a car without working through a sales consultant to understand are there any open recalls on these vehicles and if there are signing off on those recalls. So we feel good about that. And to your point, there are lots of other dealers out there selling vehicles with open recalls. I think that we do it in the most transparent way.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Bill, you mentioned that CarMax covers about 65% of the addressable U.S. market today. But what's your opportunity to invest in some of your digital initiatives? Could the pace of investment in those bricks-and-mortar stores slow in some of the out-years?
componenttext: Bill, you mentioned that CarMax covers about 65% of the addressable U.S. market today. But what's your opportunity to invest in some of your digital initiatives? Could the pace of investment in those bricks-and-mortar stores slow in some of the out-years?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. From what we said we'll probably a bit this we're committed to the national expansion. We've got 13 to 16 stores planned next year. Certainly, I think as we go forward, we'll look at the design of the stores and the design of the prototypes may chang
componenttext: Yes. From what we said we'll probably a bit this we're committed to the national expansion. We've got 13 to 16 stores planned next year. Certainly, I think as we go forward, we'll look at the design of the stores and the design of the prototypes may change. But at this point, we're still committed to a building brick-and-mortar facilities.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And just as a follow-up, how many states will allow you to use home delivery as part of that new service you pilot?
componenttext: And just as a follow-up, how many states will allow you to use home delivery as part of that new service you pilot?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I do know at that top of my head, Craig. I'd have to get back to you on that. With your earlier question, the other thing I would just reiterate is we think the advantage will be for us will be as we look forward, it's going to be a combination of having
componenttext: I do know at that top of my head, Craig. I'd have to get back to you on that. With your earlier question, the other thing I would just reiterate is we think the advantage will be for us will be as we look forward, it's going to be a combination of having that store presence but then also being able to do with transactions online and being able to combine those 2. And I think the ultimately successful I think we can be, we need to do both those really well. That's why we're so committed to building out facilities.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to touch on SG&A because it seems like a pretty good performance in the quarter. I mean, when we back out the increase in stock comp, there really wasn't much deleveraging, and we're looking at a store base that's almost 11% greater. Year-over
componenttext: Just wanted to touch on SG&A because it seems like a pretty good performance in the quarter. I mean, when we back out the increase in stock comp, there really wasn't much deleveraging, and we're looking at a store base that's almost 11% greater. Year-over-year, we're looking at investment in online opportunities and all your new efforts. That we're not seeing a deleveraging in SG&A. So just curious as we think about sort of all the buckets of potential increases in deleveraging that we usually would expect, how are they playing out in SG&A? And how do you think that should work going forward because it really is a very impressive performance. It really was no SG&A deleverage and traditionally we would look for, I got 7% to 8% increase in same-store sales to see this kind of performance. You put up a good number, 3.1%, but I mean it's not what we would have expected. It was a very good performance. Is there anything going on in your drifting in certain areas or sort of investment that not might be as great as we were thinking? .

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, this is Tom. One thing I'd point out if this is something we called out in the release that there's some other favorable things going on regarding incentive comp in this quarter that were larger than we've seen in prior quarters. And it's relatively
componenttext: John, this is Tom. One thing I'd point out if this is something we called out in the release that there's some other favorable things going on regarding incentive comp in this quarter that were larger than we've seen in prior quarters. And it's relatively in line, I mean, that stock-based comp was up quite a bit. But you kind of look at that and then the Folliard adjustment, they're of similar magnitude. So I wouldn't read into this that we're doing a better job with SG&A than we had in the past. We're investing comp and benefits if you kind of look at those 2 things absent those 2 things is in line with that 11% you see on the table in the graph. Store occupancy is up in line with our growth in stores. It's nothing really talk about there. Advertising looks light relative to last year. But that's because last year, we were in the midst of creating a new ad campaign that rolled out in Q3. So both Q2 and Q3 last year were heavy ad spending.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: John, the only thing I'd add to that. We still feel like we can leverage the mid-single-digit comps. And to Tom Reedy's point, we're continuing to invest in some of the technology and the digital experiences that I talked about earlier. Now that being sai
componenttext: John, the only thing I'd add to that. We still feel like we can leverage the mid-single-digit comps. And to Tom Reedy's point, we're continuing to invest in some of the technology and the digital experiences that I talked about earlier. Now that being said, look, we have an SG&A on a yearly basis over $1 billion, and we're certainly focused on continuing to look at opportunities and continuing to do things better to continue to leverage more in the future.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So maybe to put a finer point on it, you would say that roughly in the 5% to 7.5% range on same-store sales comps would be enough to create some small leverage on SG&A given all the efforts that are going on right now?
componenttext: So maybe to put a finer point on it, you would say that roughly in the 5% to 7.5% range on same-store sales comps would be enough to create some small leverage on SG&A given all the efforts that are going on right now?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think that's fair. I think we've seen some leverage in mid-single digit. I mean, 7 is pretty -- there's big. Once you start getting above that, that full of leverage, it gets pretty powerful so I would say at 7%, we feel pretty good.
componenttext: I think that's fair. I think we've seen some leverage in mid-single digit. I mean, 7 is pretty -- there's big. Once you start getting above that, that full of leverage, it gets pretty powerful so I would say at 7%, we feel pretty good.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So 5 plus or minus is kind of breakeven as we get above that, there is potential for some really good operating leverage that can get it?
componenttext: So 5 plus or minus is kind of breakeven as we get above that, there is potential for some really good operating leverage that can get it?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Will of them. We have invested it off.
componenttext: Will of them. We have invested it off.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's helpful. Just one quick follow-up. rates ratchet up on the cost side on CAF I mean, you guys increased the cost of the consumer, I think 20 bps. What is your comfort level in passing through the cost increase through to the customers so we don't se
componenttext: That's helpful. Just one quick follow-up. rates ratchet up on the cost side on CAF I mean, you guys increased the cost of the consumer, I think 20 bps. What is your comfort level in passing through the cost increase through to the customers so we don't see spreads certain of the continuous basis compress?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we're constantly testing CAF both up and down, depending on what we're seeing in the marketplace. And I think I've said this before on calls. The performance of the finance business is going to be somewhat market-driven. We have to be an attr
componenttext: Yes. I think we're constantly testing CAF both up and down, depending on what we're seeing in the marketplace. And I think I've said this before on calls. The performance of the finance business is going to be somewhat market-driven. We have to be an attractive alternative for our customers in financing or turning people off to CarMax. So if competition is aggressive and willing to accept a slightly lower spread than they are currently, we will have to adjust our offers over time to meet that competition and maintain -- make sure that we're still relevant to the customer. That said, if you look at the last 8 or 9 securitization deals, the spread has been pretty consistent in the mid-5s[ph], and that's not out of line with what we've seen a higher interest rate environment. So like I said, we've been in higher interest rate environments before where cost of funds have been higher. We've been able to spread the spreads we are today. What's really the wildcard is competition and how aggressive they get it and like I said, we'll have to be a market player in that's just part of being in the business.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of broad clash with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of broad clash with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Two questions. One is there have been a few anecdotal reports, I think Experian and a few others, talking about a trend of consumer shifting from the new market to the used market, just given just the inflation that's occurred in new car pricing. And I wa
componenttext: Two questions. One is there have been a few anecdotal reports, I think Experian and a few others, talking about a trend of consumer shifting from the new market to the used market, just given just the inflation that's occurred in new car pricing. And I was wondering if this is something that you're observing and whether that you feel is a trend that could be quite meaningful. Obviously seeing 8% comps in the prime side of things might support that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, yes, I have not heard that. I hope, it's the case. But I think part of what's helping is the prices of also because of gone down. Our ASP went down slightly. I think it's a factor of part of it is a shift from the 0 to 4 to a little bit older vehicle
componenttext: Yes, yes, I have not heard that. I hope, it's the case. But I think part of what's helping is the prices of also because of gone down. Our ASP went down slightly. I think it's a factor of part of it is a shift from the 0 to 4 to a little bit older vehicle for us. Part of it is a cheaper acquisition price as well with a little offset and the fact that our large SUVs as a percentage of mix are a little bit higher a couple of points higher than they were a year ago. But I have not heard what you're referencing.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just, I guess a follow-up on CAF. It's been a relatively modest increase in provisions. But just in terms of the trends that you're observing, is it -- is the decline mostly a function of frequency or is it severity as you're seeing some modest
componenttext: Okay. And just, I guess a follow-up on CAF. It's been a relatively modest increase in provisions. But just in terms of the trends that you're observing, is it -- is the decline mostly a function of frequency or is it severity as you're seeing some modest declines in used car prices?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think what we observe is a little bit of both. Last quarter, it was a little bit more severity if you look at kind of recovery rate year-over-year, it was more impactful last quarter. But at the end of the day, we just got to keep an eye on both of them
componenttext: I think what we observe is a little bit of both. Last quarter, it was a little bit more severity if you look at kind of recovery rate year-over-year, it was more impactful last quarter. But at the end of the day, we just got to keep an eye on both of them and we watch what's happening in the portfolio and we can adjust as we go.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Montini with Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Montini with Evercore ISI.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Wanted to ask, first, if I could. Can you just give an update on SUV and truck penetration this quarter versus a year ago? And then just talk about your ability to kind of source between those buckets and toggle between them as prices soften a little bit.
componenttext: Wanted to ask, first, if I could. Can you just give an update on SUV and truck penetration this quarter versus a year ago? And then just talk about your ability to kind of source between those buckets and toggle between them as prices soften a little bit.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So SUVs for us was up about 2 points. I think it was 25% of our mix, which is about 2 points higher than a year ago. And again, we were out in the market every week, every day, buying cars and if we feel like they're at a good price, we're certainly
componenttext: Yes. So SUVs for us was up about 2 points. I think it was 25% of our mix, which is about 2 points higher than a year ago. And again, we were out in the market every week, every day, buying cars and if we feel like they're at a good price, we're certainly going to buy them if that's what the customers are demanding. We want to make sure it's a good price and again, we sell what the consumer demand is on our lot. So as prices shift, that's pretty much standard operating procedure for us we're able to going to take advantage of those offers.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: If I could just follow up on some of the online initiatives that you have. One question there is what you're seeing in particular if you can share, Bill, around the rollout of home delivery that's encouraging and making expanded. And then the second quest
componenttext: If I could just follow up on some of the online initiatives that you have. One question there is what you're seeing in particular if you can share, Bill, around the rollout of home delivery that's encouraging and making expanded. And then the second question was, when you look at search engine optimization, if I do a Google Search for used cars, you all are coming up on Page 4. And it just doesn't make sense to me. So I guess the question is what kind of priority do you assign to search engine optimization and moving up that nonpaid list on Google?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: So on the home delivery, if you remember, we did a very limited test back in February. And the goal of that test was really to see does this resonate with our customers. And we felt like there is enough interest at the customers -- at the customer level t
componenttext: So on the home delivery, if you remember, we did a very limited test back in February. And the goal of that test was really to see does this resonate with our customers. And we felt like there is enough interest at the customers -- at the customer level that we have we decided okay, let's look at this, try to operational is a little bit better, and we had talked about coming back with the second test. It's really too early to give any results because we just started the second test just in the last couple of weeks. And again, the plan for this test is to understand how we've been able to operationalize it better. Can we operationalize it even more? And then really important that also is that we want to make sure that the experience meets our high standards of great customer service that we have in the store. So that's really what we're trying to understand with this piece. It's too early to really talk about any type of results. On the search engine optimization, obviously, the big part of the web redesign is making sure that when customers and search for us, that we come up organically. For those that's the best thing. When you don't have to pay for leading, you just automatically come up on the first page. And what I can tell you if I look at over a year ago -- about a year ago, if you search for us from generic terms, we didn't show up on the first page. We were, in some cases, several pages below the first page. And if you search something, you typically don't go many pages pass the first page. I'm pleased to tell you that we make great strides. And when you type in keywords now, we're on that first page, and our goal is to continue to climb that first page. So we're encouraged by the results and the progress that we've made since we've been working on it.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Hoselton with KeyBanc.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brett Hoselton with KeyBanc.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Irina Hodakovsky for Brett Hoselton. Most of the questions have been asked. I do want to ask kind of a basic question on the share buyback. You -- in your release, you stated you had $1.89 billion remaining open last quarter. The release
componenttext: This is actually Irina Hodakovsky for Brett Hoselton. Most of the questions have been asked. I do want to ask kind of a basic question on the share buyback. You -- in your release, you stated you had $1.89 billion remaining open last quarter. The release dated $1.27 billion. Has there been an increase? And what should we expect going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think our board authorized a $750 million increase last quarter, and we also took off the time limitations on the program. So I think, the message there is it's become a part of what we do. As far as on a go-forward basis, it we talk about having a
componenttext: Yes. I think our board authorized a $750 million increase last quarter, and we also took off the time limitations on the program. So I think, the message there is it's become a part of what we do. As far as on a go-forward basis, it we talk about having a target capital structure in kind of the adjusted debt to capital range of 35% to 45% both last quarter and this quarter, we're kind of scratching up on the bottom end of that and as I said last quarter, I think you can lift to be more than maintenance rather than a shifting to capital structure mode on a go-forward basis. That said, with the cash flow nature of the business as it stands today, we'll continue to generate significant cash, and we would expect to continue to buy back stock and continue to add debt to maintain that booked target. And as we've said before, we tried to do a little bit of enlightened averaging in. So I wouldn't read into volume in any given quarter. It may be dictated by our view evaluation versus where things are.

componenttext: I think in past quarters, we've observed that Tier 2 is clearly, from the maybe look at clearly behaving more aggressively, which is great for us than they were a year ago than when we look at conversion of the applications that they are seeing. So that would a fact of being another thing that impacts the volume that Tier 3 is seeing. But as I mentioned, Tier 2 is down a little bit as well just because of the overall mix shifts. So while they're behaving more aggressively and they're doing a great job for us, and we're happy with the partners we have in that space, less is filtering down to them because more of it is being caught by the high-end credit CAF.

componenttext: My first question is a little bit broader on the wholesale business. Wholesale gross profit down 10% year-over-year, how you see the calendar shift. But are there any other things you can point to which led to the decline? And how do you think it's going to perform going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So if you look at the wholesale margin GPU, I call it out earlier in my remarks. It's a very tough comparison. When I say tough comparison, last year's second quarter was the highest GPU for wholesale we've ever experienced as an organization. So I'm
componenttext: Yes. So if you look at the wholesale margin GPU, I call it out earlier in my remarks. It's a very tough comparison. When I say tough comparison, last year's second quarter was the highest GPU for wholesale we've ever experienced as an organization. So I'm sorry in the second quarter. So it was a very tough comparison. I think what you're seeing is the amount that we're at now is more representative of a typical second quarter. The other thing that I would point out is last year's second quarter, from a depreciation or appreciation standpoint, it was really stable. This year, it was a depreciating market. And you know, we aren't proactive. We're more reactive and we move as the market moves. We don't speculate. So I think it's a combined factor of tough comparison and also a different type of market this second quarter, which really is more representative of what we would typically see in the second quarter versus last year.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016

componenttext: Got it. Okay, that's helpful. And a follow-up question, Bill, the company has had a practice of trying to maintain gross profit per unit pretty flattish for the last 5 years or so. How do you think about the balancing of comps versus GPU going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I've been involved with the organization for a long time and we've held that $2,100 to $2,200 pretty consistent for multiple quarters. Like we talked about in the past, we're always willing and we're always trying if you give up in a bit of margin, y
componenttext: Yes. I've been involved with the organization for a long time and we've held that $2,100 to $2,200 pretty consistent for multiple quarters. Like we talked about in the past, we're always willing and we're always trying if you give up in a bit of margin, you make it up or in sales and that your total GPU or to your total gross profit goes up. We'll continue to test, but I also feel good about the fact that we're able to maintain that GPU. And as I think about levers to pull, if we want to make sure our price stays competitive, it's not just GPU, it's also acquisition price and it's also about the dollars that you put into a vehicle to get it to our quality standards. So again, I think our focus is going to be on acquisition price. It'll be on the reconditioning because again, we want to put more focus on the spread between what we buy our car and what a customer ultimately pays for it and we think that we feel good about where the margin is right now. We'll continue to test obviously, but we're really focused on acquisition cost and the amount that we put into it.

componenttext: Just a question on super stores. When you look at some of your peers, particularly on the franchise front, they're increasingly moving to a smaller-store format. Can you remind us again as to what the relative advantages of a superstore are in today's environment?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Paresh, what I would tell you is I actually haven't heard the superstore name in a long time. We used to have what we called super stores are at the mix of stores today are dramatically different than they were even 10, 15 years ago. And when I look
componenttext: Well, Paresh, what I would tell you is I actually haven't heard the superstore name in a long time. We used to have what we called super stores are at the mix of stores today are dramatically different than they were even 10, 15 years ago. And when I look at our stores today, we have small-format stores, which has been introduced in the last 5 years. We also have satellite stores that don't have production. We have satellite stores with production. We have bigger production stores and then typical-size CarMax stores. So I think what you've seen over time with us is that we've shifted our prototypes and our models depending on what the market is going in. And we don't open up just one standard store size.

componenttext: No, there's not a supply issue. Again, we are meeting the demand of our customers. And if our customers are looking for more older vehicles that are less expensive, then we're going to meet that need. So it's more driven also by the customer need than any supply issue.

componenttext: No. Like I said earlier, really excited and proud of what our associates do on a daily basis. They're job is not an easy job. Thank you, Victoria, and good morning, everyone. Thank you for joining our fiscal 2017 second quarter earnings conference call. On the call with me today is Bill Nash, our President and Chief Executive Officer; and Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995.
These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them. For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's Annual Report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 28, 2016, filed with the SEC. Bill?
