componenttext: Okay. And Bill, now that you've had some time to travel around the store base a bit, is there anything you want to change or improve about the operations or the company as a whole?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. Like I said earlier, I'm really excited and proud of what our associates do on a daily basis. Their job is not an easy job. And I -- when I go out the store, I see improvement, I see dedication to the company, I see everybody looking to figure out how
componenttext: No. Like I said earlier, I'm really excited and proud of what our associates do on a daily basis. Their job is not an easy job. And I -- when I go out the store, I see improvement, I see dedication to the company, I see everybody looking to figure out how can we execute better and do our jobs better and provide a better customer experience to our customers. So no, I think it's going great.

componenttext: Yes. We're going to continue to invest in that. And to my point earlier, we've spent over $1 billion. So our job is to make sure that we refocus some of that money so that it's not all incremental. But yes, we will continue to invest in this.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: And then secondly, you've spoken a bit about 0 to 4 and the age of cars that you're selling. I want to try to tie that in to the sources of used cars coming back on to the market. Presumably with the SAAR stabilizing or even slowing somewhat, transactions
componenttext: And then secondly, you've spoken a bit about 0 to 4 and the age of cars that you're selling. I want to try to tie that in to the sources of used cars coming back on to the market. Presumably with the SAAR stabilizing or even slowing somewhat, transactions emanating from consumers buying new cars are flattening out or moderating, but the institutional supply of cars coming off lease, I think, continues to grow. Are more of the cars that are hitting the market in the 0 to 4 coming through auction rather than through trade in the marketplace at large? And is that one of the factors that -- given your desire to maintain self-sufficiency at a fairly high rate, is that the one of the factors that could be impacting what you're selling? And if so, does that impact profitability at all? It doesn't seem to be doing so yet, but just to play that out.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. No, I don't think there's any big meaningful difference that we've seen through the appraisal lane or through the auctions as it relates to 0 to 4. I do think we're a little surprised we haven't seen more of it funnel back. But again, to my point ear
componenttext: Yes. No, I don't think there's any big meaningful difference that we've seen through the appraisal lane or through the auctions as it relates to 0 to 4. I do think we're a little surprised we haven't seen more of it funnel back. But again, to my point earlier, we think that that's coming, and it will be over multiple years. It certainly won't come back all at one time. And when we talk to our aux [ph] partners, they agree that there's probably a lot that will be coming back in next year and even the year after.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And that's our last question. I'd like to turn the call back over to the presenters for any closing remarks.
componenttext: Okay. And that's our last question. I'd like to turn the call back over to the presenters for any closing remarks.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q2 2017 Earnings Call, Sep 21, 2016
componenttextpreview: Great. Thank you, Victoria. In closing, again, I just want to thank all of our associates nationwide. They're doing an outstanding job, delivering an incredible customer experience every day. We would not be the successful company we are today without our
componenttext: Great. Thank you, Victoria. In closing, again, I just want to thank all of our associates nationwide. They're doing an outstanding job, delivering an incredible customer experience every day. We would not be the successful company we are today without our associates and their dedication to the customer. We have a long runway of growth ahead of us. No one is in a better position than we are to continue to give the customers the best car buying experience online or in the store. And we look forward to the opportunity to continue to lead the used car retailing industry. Thanks for your interest in CarMax and your support, and we'll talk again next quarter.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax Fiscal 2017 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call ove
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax Fiscal 2017 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Katharine Kenny, Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Thank you all for joining our fiscal third quarter earnings conference call. On the call with me today is Bill Nash, our President and Chief Executive Officer, who by the way, is very proud, along with Cliff Wood's and our man
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Thank you all for joining our fiscal third quarter earnings conference call. On the call with me today is Bill Nash, our President and Chief Executive Officer, who by the way, is very proud, along with Cliff Wood's and our many CarMax JMU alumni, of the Dukes, who are playing in the FCS National Championship. And of course, with us is Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them.
For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 29, 2016, filed with SEC. [Operator Instructions] 
Thank you so much. I'll turn the call over to Bill.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Katharine, I was not going to mention JMU since we're a little bit more team-agnostic now that Folliard has left. But since you did mention it, I'm excited about it, and I wish them well. For today's call, I will first review the
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Katharine, I was not going to mention JMU since we're a little bit more team-agnostic now that Folliard has left. But since you did mention it, I'm excited about it, and I wish them well. 
For today's call, I will first review the key highlights of the quarter, then I'll turn the call over to Tom Reedy to cover financing. And then I'll close the call before Q&A with a brief update on some of our new initiatives.
As you read in our press release this morning, our total used unit comps for the third quarter increased by 5.4%, and total used units grew by 9.1%. Total used unit comps were driven by a strong improvement in conversion as well as by a small increase in store traffic.  We believe the increase in used units was due to a variety of factors. These include improved store execution, our website redesign and related online capabilities, which have made it easier for our customers to submit leads. We continue to be very pleased with our core business as we again saw headwind from Tier 3 sales. We estimate used unit comps for our non-Tier 3 customers were again significantly stronger this quarter at 9.8%. 
Our total Web traffic was flat compared with the prior year quarter, while Web leads performed well in the quarter. We continue to see a positive response to the website with increased activity, such as engagement with a search tool and car pages as well as submitting leads. Our goal is to drive leads and convert more customers from the website to the store and finally, to a sale. 
Our wholesale units declined by approximately 2% in the third quarter. This was driven by a decrease in appraisal traffic, partially offset by the growth in our store base and a higher buy rate. The decline in industry new vehicle sales during the recession is affecting the supply of older vehicles. Remember, we saw this dynamic in our core retail business following the recession. 
We continue to maintain a consistent gross profit per used unit at $2,155 compared to $2,160 in the third quarter of last year. Gross profit per wholesale unit decreased to $900 compared to $949 in last year's third quarter. Again, as we reported in the second quarter, last year's wholesale gross profit per unit was the highest recorded in any third quarter. So like last quarter, it was again a tough comparison.
A few other topics before I turn the call over to Tom. As a percentage of our sales mix, 0 to 4-year-old vehicles fell this quarter to 78% compared to 81% last year, once again, as a result of higher customer demand for older and less expensive vehicles. SG&A expenses for the third quarter increased 5.7% to $357 million. This growth partially reflects the 12% or 18-store increase in our base since the beginning of the third quarter of last year. While we reported leverage of approximately $74 per unit, remember that our advertising expense in last year's third quarter was significantly higher due to the production and rollout of our new brand launch. Absent this increased spend in the prior year, leverage was modestly positive. Other overhead costs were up year-over-year, reflecting our continued investment in strategic initiatives. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. In recent quarters, we have discussed the trend of year-over-year increases in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and less application volume at the lower end, and we saw this
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. In recent quarters, we have discussed the trend of year-over-year increases in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and less application volume at the lower end, and we saw this continuing in the third quarter. We recently purchased credit bureau data related to auto credit inquiries in the marketplace, and our analysis of this data suggests that this trend is not unique to CarMax. This application mix drove growth in cash net penetration, which increased to 45% compared with 43.3% in last year's third quarter.
Net loans originated in the quarter rose more than 9% year-over-year to $1.3 billion due to a combination of CarMax sales growth and a higher penetration, partially offset by our lower average selling prices. In addition, as you'd expect, the higher credit mix applications [ph] drove growth in the portion of sales where customers paid cash or bought their own financing. 
Tier 2 penetration fell year-over-year in the quarter to 15.7% from 16.9%. But just as we said last quarter, our Tier 2 lenders continue to provide strong offers based on what we have observed in customer conversion. Tier 3 sales mix was 10.2% of used unit sales compared to 13.8% for the same period last year. This decrease in penetration continues to be due to the same factors credit hiking [ph] early in the year and lower application volumes.  Performance of our Tier 3 partners, however, has been consistent since the middle of Q1. 
GAAP income fell 3.2% to about $89 million compared to the third quarter of fiscal 2016, while average managed receivables grew by 11% to $10.3 billion. The provision for loan losses increased, and the portfolio interest margin decreased very modestly.
During the third quarter, we continue to see higher loss experience. Our ending allowance for loan losses at $115 million was 1.1% of ending managed receivables compared to 1.08% last quarter and 0.97% in last year's third quarter. This level of losses is a departure from our experience in recent years. However, losses in the last several years have been quite favorable. The current level of loan loss reserve is consistent with our range of expectations given our origination strategy and portfolio mix.
For loans originated during the quarter, the weighted average contract rate charged to customers was flat year-over-year at 7.3%. Total interest margin declined slightly to 5.8% of average managed receivables. This compared to 6% in the third quarter of last year and 5.9% sequentially from Q2. And during the quarter, we repurchased 3.8 million shares for $199 million. As of the end of Q3, we had $1.7 billion remaining in our stock repurchase authorization. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Bill.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. During the third quarter, we opened 6 stores, including 2 in new markets, Boise and Grand Rapids. We also opened 4 stores in existing markets: Philadelphia, Daytona and 2 in San Francisco. Late in the current fourth quarter, we expect to open
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. During the third quarter, we opened 6 stores, including 2 in new markets, Boise and Grand Rapids. We also opened 4 stores in existing markets: Philadelphia, Daytona and 2 in San Francisco. Late in the current fourth quarter, we expect to open 4 more stores: 2 in our Los Angeles market, 1 in Marietta [ph] and 1 centralized production option facilities this quarter both [ph] in Southern California. In addition, we plan to open 2 small format stores in the fourth quarter both in new markets: Boldo, Alabama [ph] and Albany, New York. 
Next, I'd like to give an update on our new online offerings and the tests we are conducting to continue to advance the customer experience. First, as we discussed last quarter, we've been testing a new online financing capability that has helped our customers get pre-qualified for a loan. When we talked at the end of the second quarter, we were piloting this product in 13 stores. Towards the end of Q3, we successfully rolled this new capability out to all stores nationwide, and we're pleased with the early results, which includes increased leads. 
Second, we continue to test our home delivery offering in Charlotte, North Carolina. As a reminder, home delivery allows the customers to shop for and buy a car at their convenience without coming into the store. We continue to learn about the customer demand and operational scalability while also ensuring it meets our standards for an exceptional experience. 
The last update is regarding a one store test we'll be conducting in the fourth quarter. We plan to test a new digital solution for customers who are interested in getting an appraisal value for their vehicle by submitting their vehicle information online without having to come into the store. These initiatives position CarMax to deliver more of the car buying experience online, and we remain committed to giving the customers the ability to go between the digital and in-store experience whenever and however they would like. 
While we are constantly working to innovate and improve the business, we are also very focused on being cost-conscious in eliminating waste across the entire organization. We continue to look for new opportunities to ensure we're going in a way that is in the best interest of our customers, associates and shareholders. 
Like last quarter, I remain confident that we will continue to lead the industry. We have 23 years of experience to build upon to help us excel into the future. With our great associates, our national footprint, our unparalleled inventory, brand strength and continued focus on improving the customer experience both online and in-store, no one is in a better position than CarMax to fully deliver the best car buying experience. 
With that, I will open up the call for questions. So, Victoria?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Sharon Zackfia with William Blair.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: A question on the search engine optimization that you've been working on, I think, earnestly this year. I guess I'm a little surprised that Web traffic is flattish given that. So can you give us an update kind of where you stand on search engine optimizat
componenttext: A question on the search engine optimization that you've been working on, I think, earnestly this year. I guess I'm a little surprised that Web traffic is flattish given that. So can you give us an update kind of where you stand on search engine optimization and how much of a driver that might really be going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Sharon. So SEO is a big focus for us. The things that we've done so far this year to really focus on that is, first of all, the website which we've talked about in the past. In addition to the website here recently, we've been working on som
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Sharon. So SEO is a big focus for us. The things that we've done so far this year to really focus on that is, first of all, the website which we've talked about in the past. In addition to the website here recently, we've been working on some of the design of the website to make sure that search engines can get the information in a quick, time-sensitive fashion so that they can pull all the relevant data down. So that's something that we've been working on here more recently. We've also been publishing some content that our customers want and expect. But this is an area -- now that we've got the website up, we've made some tweaks to it, this is an area that we think still has a lot of opportunity going forward.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question, I'm going to -- it's on used car unit comps. Two parts. I'm going to shove [ph] it together. First off, a number of retailers across the board have discussed some sales disruptions with [ph] their chains around the recent presidential electio
componenttext: My question, I'm going to -- it's on used car unit comps. Two parts. I'm going to shove [ph] it together. First off, a number of retailers across the board have discussed some sales disruptions with [ph] their chains around the recent presidential election. So I know it's not typical for CarMax to talk about inter-quarter trends, but I thought maybe you could at least -- maybe you could discuss that. And then the second question, also relating to car sales. You talked a lot about in the prepared comments about some of the internal initiatives. We've clearly seen a sequential improvement in used car unit comps over the past few quarters. From a market standpoint, has CarMax started to benefit yet from the supply of vehicles, including within the industry?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. So on the first question, I really don't have a comment on that and the Trump effect. On the second part of the question, as it relates to the supply, I absolutely think that we're starting to see the supply come back in the auctions, and I th
componenttext: Yes, Brian. So on the first question, I really don't have a comment on that and the Trump effect. On the second part of the question, as it relates to the supply, I absolutely think that we're starting to see the supply come back in the auctions, and I think that's a good thing for CarMax. As that supply comes back, it helps to drive the difference in price between a new car and a late-model used car. So while I didn't highlight that as one of the factors in the prepared remarks, I absolutely think that that's also a contributing factor.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's on the wholesale business, which fell a little bit. Do you think you're seeing your fair share of appraisal traffic? Or are sellers starting to use some of these alternate channels, which, again, you may have access to with your new strategy? And the
componenttext: It's on the wholesale business, which fell a little bit. Do you think you're seeing your fair share of appraisal traffic? Or are sellers starting to use some of these alternate channels, which, again, you may have access to with your new strategy? And then on a related note, how does the increase in lease activity, we've got a lot of more leased cars today, impact your opportunity for appraisal given those sellers -- or those less user [ph] not selling a car?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the wholesale piece, I think that's more indicative of what I talked about in the early remarks that the -- as the new car SAAR works its way through from the recession, the shortage of new cars, for us, that's right in the 7- to 9-year-old vehic
componenttext: Okay. On the wholesale piece, I think that's more indicative of what I talked about in the early remarks that the -- as the new car SAAR works its way through from the recession, the shortage of new cars, for us, that's right in the 7- to 9-year-old vehicles, and you know that's right in the sweet spot of wholesale. And we saw the same phenomenon earlier on when those cars were 0 to 4. We saw less of them coming through as appraisal traffic. We expect and we're seeing the same thing come through in the 7- to 9-year-old vehicles. So we think that's more of a factor of what's in play there. And I'm sorry, the second question, what was it in regards to lease activity?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the increase in overall lease activity, there are a lot of people who have cars that are leased and not, therefore, for sale. Does that impact your ability in the wholesale business to attract those cars?
componenttext: With the increase in overall lease activity, there are a lot of people who have cars that are leased and not, therefore, for sale. Does that impact your ability in the wholesale business to attract those cars?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, I don't think so at this point because, first of all, the leases are just starting to come back at this point, and our wholesale cars are generally older. I do think that the -- as the leases come back, that's a good thing for the core business b
componenttext: Yes, no, I don't think so at this point because, first of all, the leases are just starting to come back at this point, and our wholesale cars are generally older. I do think that the -- as the leases come back, that's a good thing for the core business because that's a lot more selection of younger vehicles. But I don't think that's having an impact on the wholesale business.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Within the SG&A, other than the advertising, which was down for reasons that you stated, your compensation expense was also quite well controlled. It looks like, on an aggregate basis, it was up only 3% year-on-year. And this comp in benefits -- and up --
componenttext: Within the SG&A, other than the advertising, which was down for reasons that you stated, your compensation expense was also quite well controlled. It looks like, on an aggregate basis, it was up only 3% year-on-year. And this comp in benefits -- and up -- really barely up on a 2-year basis in aggregate dollars despite a big increase in stores. Was there anything related to stock comp, which I know you have sometimes called out or any other factor, incentive comp, that would have led this number to be so subdued here in the third quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, the stock comp actually this quarter is the first time it's been at a level so small that it's not worth talking about on a year-over-year basis. But there are some good guys embedded in that comp and benefit number, both some unfavorability las
componenttext: Yes. Yes, the stock comp actually this quarter is the first time it's been at a level so small that it's not worth talking about on a year-over-year basis. But there are some good guys embedded in that comp and benefit number, both some unfavorability last year and some favorability this year. But despite that, we still did leverage that line relative to growth in unit sales. You could probably double the percentage increase, and it would be a rough idea of what we kind of thought a run rate would be.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in other words, the run rate would have been something like 6% in dollars normalized for everything, which would have led you to good leverage?
componenttext: So in other words, the run rate would have been something like 6% in dollars normalized for everything, which would have led you to good leverage?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's fair to say.
componenttext: Yes, that's fair to say.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. That's very helpful. If I can -- I'll count that as my follow-up and come back if we have more.
componenttext: Got it. That's very helpful. If I can -- I'll count that as my follow-up and come back if we have more.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Levin with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Levin with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to kind of focus on the loss provision rates at CAF for a second. Is there a way that you can kind of talk about  is this factoring in just what you're currently experiencing? Or does this take into account additional expected to go [ph] lines
componenttext: Just wanted to kind of focus on the loss provision rates at CAF for a second. Is there a way that you can kind of talk about  is this factoring in just what you're currently experiencing? Or does this take into account additional expected to go [ph] lines in used vehicle values moving forward? If it's just now, how much do you think this could continue to move down with used values coming down further from here?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me hit on a couple things. One is used values definitely has an impact on loss rates. But historically, customer behavior has been a much bigger driver. And on an ongoing basis, there's many things moving. So it's hard to say that, that one indiv
componenttext: Yes, let me hit on a couple things. One is used values definitely has an impact on loss rates. But historically, customer behavior has been a much bigger driver. And on an ongoing basis, there's many things moving. So it's hard to say that, that one individual factor could have a dramatic impact on a go-forward basis. So the determination, every quarter, we determine, based on what we know to date rather than based on any kind of speculation, a 12-month look forward on loss expectation. So as I said, it's based on historical information that we have and then how we're performing to date relative to that historical performance. So in a quarter, where things are moving, you're going to see us move that loss expectation. We have not  in the past, when things are going good, taken a view to try to get ahead of things, and we haven't done that here as well.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I mean, maybe to put that in a little bit of perspective, these current rates versus history. I know the accounting was different at the time, but could you kind of compare where these loss rates are versus where we were, say, to the crisis?
componenttext: Got it. I mean, maybe to put that in a little bit of perspective, these current rates versus history. I know the accounting was different at the time, but could you kind of compare where these loss rates are versus where we were, say, to the crisis?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, well, through the crisis, we typically try to manage our portfolio to kind of a 2% to 2.5% cumulative net loss rate. And the average life of these loans, it was -- has been roughly 2 years as a proxy. So during the recession, we saw rate --
componenttext: Yes. I think, well, through the crisis, we typically try to manage our portfolio to kind of a 2% to 2.5% cumulative net loss rate. And the average life of these loans, it was -- has been roughly 2 years as a proxy. So during the recession, we saw rate -- loss rates go to double that in the portfolio. But one thing I think I'd point out. At the one point -- and if you look at the size of the loan loss allowance today, which is a 12-month look, it's 1.10%. So if you double that, you get -- you can see there was [ph] still relative to the range of expectation in the zone that we're looking to originate. And something to remember also is that our Tier 3 test is also part of that over our loan loss provision and represents almost 10% of it.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: 10% of the dollar volume, the $114 million, $115 million of loan loss allowance. So when we step back and look at this, yes, we've seen deterioration relative to recent years, but still not to the point where we were pre-recession.
componenttext: 10% of the dollar volume, the $114 million, $115 million of loan loss allowance. So when we step back and look at this, yes, we've seen deterioration relative to recent years, but still not to the point where we were pre-recession.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you guys have always talked about Tier 3 sales is really being incremental to the core run rate. So my question is, when CAF increases penetration, do you have an estimate what percent of those CAF sales are incremental? So in other words, is CAF finan
componenttext: So you guys have always talked about Tier 3 sales is really being incremental to the core run rate. So my question is, when CAF increases penetration, do you have an estimate what percent of those CAF sales are incremental? So in other words, is CAF financing some people that wouldn't have received credit elsewhere?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the answer to that is yes and not necessarily because were more aggressive than other folks. But every lender has a way that they look at credit. With think we have ways to look at our applicants and find pockets that work for us that may convert
componenttext: I think the answer to that is yes and not necessarily because were more aggressive than other folks. But every lender has a way that they look at credit. With think we have ways to look at our applicants and find pockets that work for us that may convert at a better rate because they got a CAF offer than if they get a Tier 2 or Tier 3. So if you look at the conversion customers based on a CAF offer, basin or Tier 2 or 3 offer, it's much more significant. So you would expect that some of the CAF offers would be incremental just because of that phenomenon.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Tom, if you had, let's call it, 7,600 extra unit sales because of the increasing CAF penetration, is there a percentage she would kind of suggest that what was incremental based on what you guys you have in your models?
componenttext: But Tom, if you had, let's call it, 7,600 extra unit sales because of the increasing CAF penetration, is there a percentage she would kind of suggest that what was incremental based on what you guys you have in your models?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like I said, there'll be some incremental there but we haven't shared anything as far as fractions. I can tell you that, that percentage, it would not be expected to be up or down relative to recent years.
componenttext: Like I said, there'll be some incremental there but we haven't shared anything as far as fractions. I can tell you that, that percentage, it would not be expected to be up or down relative to recent years.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right. And I mean, kind of related to that because it has to do with on the credit side. Given that the rise in interest rates that we've seen, I would assume that you are funding costs have actually increased. And just how should we generally think about
componenttext: Right. And I mean, kind of related to that because it has to do with on the credit side. Given that the rise in interest rates that we've seen, I would assume that you are funding costs have actually increased. And just how should we generally think about how you guys playing to manage the spread versus moving interest rates too quickly on customers with the potential for negative unit elasticity.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the nice thing about our business is we can test quickly and we can test pretty accurately in the CAF space. So we have seen an increase in benchmarks in recent weeks, I guess, to look at it. And we have taken action or raise in certain pockets
componenttext: Yes. Well, the nice thing about our business is we can test quickly and we can test pretty accurately in the CAF space. So we have seen an increase in benchmarks in recent weeks, I guess, to look at it. And we have taken action or raise in certain pockets selectively to offset to some extent. Now what we'll need to do is, as we look at it going forward, see if the market allows to keep those rates up. Because as I said many times, we're going to be a market lender. We've got to provide competitive rates to the customers so nobody is getting sour on CarMax over the finance offer they got. And we'll closely monitor our 3-day payoffs. We'll closely monitor conversion as we ramp up rates and will do what the market allows us. But this is something that's just ongoing business as usual for CarMax Auto Finance. We're constantly testing ways to maximize the profit and sales coming from that portfolio.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from line of John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from line of John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on supply and the impact potentially on grosses. I mean, it seems like there's a lot of new vehicle dealers that are getting off the stop sale wagon and retailing a lot of these vehicles that kind of stored on their lots in a short run. So
componenttext: Just a question on supply and the impact potentially on grosses. I mean, it seems like there's a lot of new vehicle dealers that are getting off the stop sale wagon and retailing a lot of these vehicles that kind of stored on their lots in a short run. So I'm just curious what you think about supply there. And then also, as you look at this leasing bubble that's coming over the next 3 years, kind of where you think we are in that increase in supply? And as you think about those 2 legs of supply increases, what you think you can do as far as holding your gross so you're going to stay committed to this $2,100 to $2,200 range as we see that increase in supply really pick up?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John, so on the first part of the question about the stop sale. I don't really think that's much about the impact. There's lots of dealers have been selling vehicles that have open recalls while you've got the franchise dealers that cannot by the man
componenttext: Yes, John, so on the first part of the question about the stop sale. I don't really think that's much about the impact. There's lots of dealers have been selling vehicles that have open recalls while you've got the franchise dealers that cannot by the manufacturer saying that you can't sell for that franchise, they still sell other non brand franchise at those stores. So for me, that's not really -- I don't really see that as either positive or negative, I think just continuing on. As far as the leasing, as I said earlier, we're seeing more vehicles come back from the leasing channels. And we think it'll continue through next year and even into the year after that. And I think we've proven over time that we've been able to hold our margins throughout many different cycles. Now live on the caveat that I will give the there is you know we constantly do testing. And if we think that moving that margin down would more than pay for itself than in units, then we would look at that. And so we'll continue to test. But we feel confident that we can continue to maintain those gross profit margins.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I could just follow up I mean, what we've simply think that if you drop your gross by 10%, you would expect to get at least a 10% pickup in volume or else you wouldn't do it. Is that correct? Meaning, or 11% increase in volume to offset that drop i
componenttext: And if I could just follow up I mean, what we've simply think that if you drop your gross by 10%, you would expect to get at least a 10% pickup in volume or else you wouldn't do it. Is that correct? Meaning, or 11% increase in volume to offset that drop in gross?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, we would want to see total gross more than offset the drop than what we saw. So it would have to be a win on total gross.
componenttext: Yes, we would want to see total gross more than offset the drop than what we saw. So it would have to be a win on total gross.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Montani with Evercore.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Montani with Evercore.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask if I could and apologize if I missed it. But what are you seeing now in terms of SUV truck penetration? I think last year was 23% by your measures and I was looking for to maybe low 30s. Could you talk about that?
componenttext: Just wanted to ask if I could and apologize if I missed it. But what are you seeing now in terms of SUV truck penetration? I think last year was 23% by your measures and I was looking for to maybe low 30s. Could you talk about that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our large SUV mix for the quarter was up year-over-year, it's about 25.7% versus last year's third quarter, it was 23.3%. So it's about 250 basis points. It's up about 1 point from the second quarter of this year. So the mix is up a little bit, wh
componenttext: Yes. So our large SUV mix for the quarter was up year-over-year, it's about 25.7% versus last year's third quarter, it was 23.3%. So it's about 250 basis points. It's up about 1 point from the second quarter of this year. So the mix is up a little bit, which would inherently drive our ASPs up a little bit. But then because we had a shift in some of the older vehicles, that brought the ASPs down as well as acquisition prices, lower acquisition prices brought it down. So SUV mix was up a little bit.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Can you talk a little bit about sourcing and how it's trended in terms of by so that you would do it, appraisal lanes versus auction and other areas. Just thinking about big picture. It would seem that you'd be in a better position t
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Can you talk a little bit about sourcing and how it's trended in terms of by so that you would do it, appraisal lanes versus auction and other areas. Just thinking about big picture. It would seem that you'd be in a better position to sort in merchandise given that acquisition cost has come down. So just wanted to see how that's playing out.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is this in particular, the large SUVs or just in general?
componenttext: Is this in particular, the large SUVs or just in general?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, just in general.
componenttext: No, just in general.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think what we're seeing others we've typically see in this time of the year would fall depreciation. And I think with the fall depreciation obviously is going to lower the acquisition prices. Again, that's -- we feel that's a good thing for
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think what we're seeing others we've typically see in this time of the year would fall depreciation. And I think with the fall depreciation obviously is going to lower the acquisition prices. Again, that's -- we feel that's a good thing for us because I step position prices go down, just come passive those lower prices on to the customers and as a bigger delta between new cars and late-model used cars. So we think it's good.

componenttext: I wanted to ask and I know it's early, but certainly, we're getting a lot of questions and you hosted the call yesterday on subject matter. componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King & Associates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you mentioned a small increase in overall traffic into the stores but we also had a reduction in a appraisal traffic. Are you seeing any change in consumer behavior in terms of your people coming in with trade it's? Or what do think explains for that a
componenttext: So you mentioned a small increase in overall traffic into the stores but we also had a reduction in a appraisal traffic. Are you seeing any change in consumer behavior in terms of your people coming in with trade it's? Or what do think explains for that apparent disparity?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, like you said, we saw a small increase in store traffic. I talked to limit about store traffic last quarter in that you really can't look at just store traffic by itself. You really have to look at Web traffic, and especially for us, leave a
componenttext: Yes, I think, like you said, we saw a small increase in store traffic. I talked to limit about store traffic last quarter in that you really can't look at just store traffic by itself. You really have to look at Web traffic, and especially for us, leave and store traffic to understand the overall big picture. Consumers are a lot more educated. We know that of the consumers that buy vehicle from us, 9 out of 10 of them have already done a lot of research on CarMax.com. So they're already much better educated. I think on the difference between getting a little bit more store traffic in and of the appraisal traffic down. Again, lot of it is tied to what we're seeing as the SAAR rate breaks it suite through the bubble. And I think that's a main driver of why you see some of the appraisal traffic down.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Because they are getting less...
componenttext: Because they are getting less...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just because there aren't as many. So like I talked about early, the 7 to 9-year-old vehicle, they're just aren't many as there were because 7 to 9 years ago, the new car sales rates were going down. So if those -- if there aren't as many customers that h
componenttext: Just because there aren't as many. So like I talked about early, the 7 to 9-year-old vehicle, they're just aren't many as there were because 7 to 9 years ago, the new car sales rates were going down. So if those -- if there aren't as many customers that have those cars are obviously, did give them a price.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys called out increase in a mix of sales to higher credit customers and their supply of late model vehicles. But at the same time, you're selling a higher mix of older vehicles. Can you help square away that dynamic, which has occurred for the last
componenttext: You guys called out increase in a mix of sales to higher credit customers and their supply of late model vehicles. But at the same time, you're selling a higher mix of older vehicles. Can you help square away that dynamic, which has occurred for the last 2 quarters now?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think contrary to what a lot of people think is that your Tier 3 customers are going to be the ones buying your late-model or your older, less expensive vehicles. And for us, that's just not the case. The majority of the vehicles that we sell are o
componenttext: Yes, I think contrary to what a lot of people think is that your Tier 3 customers are going to be the ones buying your late-model or your older, less expensive vehicles. And for us, that's just not the case. The majority of the vehicles that we sell are of the older, less expensive vehicles are to non-Tier 3 customers. So I think what it says is that the consumers are still out there looking for a great deal and they've opted to go a little bit older and a little bit cheaper. So I think that's kind of explains the dynamic. It's not just Tier 3 customers that would be buying older, more -- less expensive vehicles.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just as a follow-up. Considering their increase supply of late-model vehicles, would you expect your mix to shift back to that direction over the next few quarters?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just as a follow-up. Considering their increase supply of late-model vehicles, would you expect your mix to shift back to that direction over the next few quarters?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seth, we all sell whatever the consumers want. So if the consumers want that late-model vehicle, then we'll absolutely adjust our inventory accordingly. If they want to continue to buy older vehicles, then we'll -- you won't see that change. So just depen
componenttext: Seth, we all sell whatever the consumers want. So if the consumers want that late-model vehicle, then we'll absolutely adjust our inventory accordingly. If they want to continue to buy older vehicles, then we'll -- you won't see that change. So just depends. So driven by consumer demand.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Whiston with Morningstar.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016

componenttext: Just wanted to talk about the future on e-commerce and the pilot programs you're doing. Obviously, there's still consumer so what this process to be very easy but at the same time, it's still roughly a $20,000 purchase for people. So how willing do think people are to buy a vehicle without even coming in those shortage to do a testdrive. Is this a small portion of the American public? Are there ultimately going to be a lot of people? What are your thoughts on that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, it's a good question, David. And I think you hit the nail on head. It's not an easy transaction. It's a complicated transaction. That being said, I do think there's a small subset of customers that want to try that experience. I think for us, we
componenttext: Yes, no, it's a good question, David. And I think you hit the nail on head. It's not an easy transaction. It's a complicated transaction. That being said, I do think there's a small subset of customers that want to try that experience. I think for us, we certainly are going to be meet those customers wherever and however, they want to do business. But I think more importantly, is that I think consumers will want to do more of the transaction online in the near term. And we will have the ability to not only do more of the transaction online, but it will be a seamless integration into the sir. I think that's really what we're focused on in addition to giving the customers the ability to do everything, it really is, okay, you want to do part of it online, let's make sure it's a great experience. And then when you walk into the store, which is pick up from where you left off, and that's really what we're focused on.  And I think that's really where the consumer demand is going to be in the near term.

componenttext: No, as we've discussed before, we tie kind of enlightened averaging in methodology to repurchases. So at a given time, were trying to average into the market and maintain our capital structure this on that we've targeted. You saw that in this quarter, we bought back $199 million versus $125 million in Q2. That did represent a little bit of a step up and aggressiveness because we saw some weakness in the stock price. But the parameters we put in place allow for a little bit of that allows to be a little bit more aggressive when the price is weak and a little more conservative in the volume in the prices looking strong. But we intend to be in the market on a regular basis.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think, first of all, just a comment on your first part about the online competitor kind of ceasing operations. I think it goes back to something I talked about earlier, which this is not a simple business. This is a hard business. It's not easy to
componenttext: Yes, I think, first of all, just a comment on your first part about the online competitor kind of ceasing operations. I think it goes back to something I talked about earlier, which this is not a simple business. This is a hard business. It's not easy to go out source inventory for the right amount. It's not easy to go out and put a cash offer on every single car. And I think that's just an indication of why some of these folks are struggling. I think competition is hot both the online space in the traditional. I think our challenge is to make sure that to be continue to leverage the equities has made a successful and made them even better and leverage our data and our processes and our systems and our people to continue to widen the gap between us and our competition. Like I said earlier, I mean, we've got 23 worth of experience and 23 years worth of data, and we're leveraging that data and tapping it in ways we haven't been able to and haven't done in the past. So although the competition is hot and heavy, we feel really good about the position that we're in. And I think, ultimately, to be as successful as we can be, we do need to ensure that we can be in the online space. But equally important is we got at the end of the brick-and-mortar space. I think you have to do both very, very well, and I think we're positioning ourselves to do just that.

componenttext: Sure. As far cycling, I think in the current period right now, will begin to cycle over the trend with been observing the traffic. So remember, we've been talking for several quarters about seeing fewer application volume of a lower end of the credit spectrum. That started somewhere around this time last year. So that portion of the decrease will start to see some cycling. As I mentioned in my comments, the most recent tiding we saw was in mid-Q1 from our Tier 3, one of our Tier 3 lenders. Since that time, they have been behaving very consistently if we look at conversion of customers in the Tier 3 space since missed the middle of Q1. It's been very consistent. It's below last year, but it's been consistent. So yes, all else equal in a row, you start to see this rolling over that on a year-over-year basis. In the Tier 2 space, it's almost exactly the opposite phenomenon conversion has been consistently better than last year since the first quarter. But as I mentioned, they're doing a great job of converting the volume of that they see. A lot of this -- the mix dynamic we're seeing is a lot of it is from the customer traffic coming through the door. That's why CAF is up, that's why other is up and that's why the Tier 2 and 3 are down.

componenttext: I think it's going to be a matter of what a lot of it is going to matter what customers come to. The Tier 3 space has a lot more fragmented than the more prime space in auto lending. We're happy with the performance of our partners. We test other partners occasionally. And to the extent one can add value we consider bring them in the mix. But I think, if you step back and think about our credit base as a platform for growing, it's a much more profitable dynamic to grow at this mix than to have the mix migrate back to something higher.

componenttext: I'll start on the last one. We'll see how it impacts the loss rates going forward depending on the environment. It's way too early to tell. We're not in a position to give you numbers regarding this, but I can give you a little car around what we looked at. We bought data related to auto inquiries. Meaningful so that are hitting the peers in conjunction with for the past several years. Both through submissions to captives and submissions or inquiries through the major dealer groups. And while we likely started feeling the phenomenon a little  the earlier, the data is telling us that the lower and lower middle part of the credit spectrum has seen a year-over-year decline in recent quarters for everybody. As far as the higher credit folks in the growth there, our data appears to show that we are -- we're growing a little bit stronger than the rest of them. But there can be a lot of factors between Nucor mix, used car mix, et cetera to drive done. I do think there's anything really to take away from that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax Fiscal 2017 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call ove
componenttext: Good morning. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax Fiscal 2017 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Katharine Kenny, Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Thank you all for joining our fiscal third quarter earnings conference call. On the call with me today is Bill Nash, our President and Chief Executive Officer, who by the way, is very proud, along with Cliff Wood's and our man
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Thank you all for joining our fiscal third quarter earnings conference call. On the call with me today is Bill Nash, our President and Chief Executive Officer, who by the way, is very proud, along with Cliff Wood's and our many CarMax JMU alumni, of the Dukes, who are playing in the FCS National Championship. And of course, with us is Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them.
For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 29, 2016, filed with SEC. [Operator Instructions] 
Thank you so much. I'll turn the call over to Bill.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Katharine, I was not going to mention JMU since we're a little bit more team-agnostic now that Folliard has left. But since you did mention it, I'm excited about it, and I wish them well. For today's call, I will first review the
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Katharine, I was not going to mention JMU since we're a little bit more team-agnostic now that Folliard has left. But since you did mention it, I'm excited about it, and I wish them well. 
For today's call, I will first review the key highlights of the quarter, then I'll turn the call over to Tom Reedy to cover financing. And then I'll close the call before Q&A with a brief update on some of our new initiatives.
As you read in our press release this morning, our total used unit comps for the third quarter increased by 5.4%, and total used units grew by 9.1%. Total used unit comps were driven by a strong improvement in conversion as well as by a small increase in store traffic. We believe the increase in used units was due to a variety of factors. These include improved store execution, our website redesign and related online capabilities, which have made it easier for our customers to submit leads. We continue to be very pleased with our core business as we again saw headwind from Tier 3 sales. We estimate used unit comps for our non-Tier 3 customers were again significantly stronger this quarter at 9.8%. 
Our total Web traffic was flat compared with the prior year quarter, while Web leads performed well in the quarter. We continue to see a positive response to the website with increased activity, such as engagement with a search tool and car pages as well as submitting leads. Our goal is to drive leads and convert more customers from the website to the store and finally, to a sale. 
Our wholesale units declined by approximately 2% in the third quarter. This was driven by a decrease in appraisal traffic, partially offset by the growth in our store base and a higher buy rate. The decline in industry new vehicle sales during the recession is affecting the supply of older vehicles. Remember, we saw this dynamic in our core retail business following the recession. 
We continue to maintain a consistent gross profit per used unit at $2,155 compared to $2,160 in the third quarter of last year. Gross profit per wholesale unit decreased to $900 compared to $949 in last year's third quarter. Again, as we reported in the second quarter, last year's wholesale gross profit per unit was the highest recorded in any third quarter. So like last quarter, it was again a tough comparison.
A few other topics before I turn the call over to Tom. As a percentage of our sales mix, 0 to 4-year-old vehicles fell this quarter to 78% compared to 81% last year, once again, as a result of higher customer demand for older and less expensive vehicles. SG&A expenses for the third quarter increased 5.7% to $357 million. This growth partially reflects the 12% or 18-store increase in our base since the beginning of the third quarter of last year. While we reported leverage of approximately $74 per unit, remember that our advertising expense in last year's third quarter was significantly higher due to the production and rollout of our new brand launch. Absent this increased spend in the prior year, leverage was modestly positive. Other overhead costs were up year-over-year, reflecting our continued investment in strategic initiatives. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. In recent quarters, we have discussed the trend of year-over-year increases in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and less application volume at the lower end, and we saw this
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. In recent quarters, we have discussed the trend of year-over-year increases in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and less application volume at the lower end, and we saw this continuing in the third quarter. We recently purchased credit bureau data related to auto credit inquiries in the marketplace, and our analysis of this data suggests that this trend is not unique to CarMax. This application mix drove growth in cash net penetration, which increased to 45% compared with 43.3% in last year's third quarter.
Net loans originated in the quarter rose more than 9% year-over-year to $1.3 billion due to a combination of CarMax sales growth and a higher penetration, partially offset by our lower average selling prices. In addition, as you'd expect, the higher credit mix of applications drove growth in the portion of sales where customers paid cash or bought their own financing. 
Tier 2 penetration fell year-over-year in the quarter to 15.7% from 16.9%. But just as we said last quarter, our Tier 2 lenders continue to provide strong offers based on what we have observed in customer conversion. Tier 3 sales mix was 10.2% of used unit sales compared to 13.8% for the same period last year. This decrease in penetration continues to be due to the same factors credits hiking early in the year and lower application volumes. Performance of our Tier 3 partners, however, has been consistent since the middle of Q1. 
GAAP income fell 3.2% to about $89 million compared to the third quarter of fiscal 2016, while average managed receivables grew by 11% to $10.3 billion. The provision for loan losses increased, and the portfolio interest margin decreased very modestly.
During the third quarter, we continue to see higher loss experience. Our ending allowance for loan losses at $115 million was 1.1% of ending managed receivables compared to 1.08% last quarter and 0.97% in last year's third quarter. This level of losses is a departure from our experience in recent years. However, losses in the last several years have been quite favorable. The current level of loan loss reserve is consistent with our range of expectations given our origination strategy and portfolio mix.
For loans originated during the quarter, the weighted average contract rate charged to customers was flat year-over-year at 7.3%. Total interest margin declined slightly to 5.8% of average managed receivables. This compared to 6% in the third quarter of last year and 5.9% sequentially from Q2. And during the quarter, we repurchased 3.8 million shares for $199 million. As of the end of Q3, we had $1.7 billion remaining in our stock repurchase authorization. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Bill.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. During the third quarter, we opened 6 stores, including 2 in new markets, Boise and Grand Rapids. We also opened 4 stores in existing markets: Philadelphia, Daytona and 2 in San Francisco. Late in the current fourth quarter, we expect to open
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. During the third quarter, we opened 6 stores, including 2 in new markets, Boise and Grand Rapids. We also opened 4 stores in existing markets: Philadelphia, Daytona and 2 in San Francisco. Late in the current fourth quarter, we expect to open 4 more stores: 2 in our Los Angeles market, 1 in Murrieta, centralized production auction facilities this quarter, both in Southern California. In addition, we plan to open 2 small format stores in the fourth quarter both in new markets: Boldo, Alabama and Albany, New York. 
Next, I'd like to give an update on our new online offerings and the tests we are conducting to continue to advance the customer experience. First, as we discussed last quarter, we've been testing a new online financing capability that has helped our customers get pre-qualified for a loan. When we talked at the end of the second quarter, we were piloting this product in 13 stores. Towards the end of Q3, we successfully rolled this new capability out to all stores nationwide, and we're pleased with the early results, which includes increased leads. 
Second, we continue to test our home delivery offering in Charlotte, North Carolina. As a reminder, home delivery allows the customers to shop for and buy a car at their convenience without coming into the store. We continue to learn about the customer demand and operational scalability while also ensuring it meets our standards for an exceptional experience. 
The last update is regarding a one store test we'll be conducting in the fourth quarter. We plan to test a new digital solution for customers who are interested in getting an appraisal value for their vehicle by submitting their vehicle information online without having to come into the store. These initiatives position CarMax to deliver more of the car buying experience online, and we remain committed to giving the customers the ability to go between the digital and in-store experience whenever and however they would like. 
While we are constantly working to innovate and improve the business, we are also very focused on being cost-conscious in eliminating waste across the entire organization. We continue to look for new opportunities to ensure we're going in a way that is in the best interest of our customers, associates and shareholders. 
Like last quarter, I remain confident that we will continue to lead the industry. We have 23 years of experience to build upon to help us excel into the future. With our great associates, our national footprint, our unparalleled inventory, brand strength and continued focus on improving the customer experience both online and in-store, no one is in a better position than CarMax to fully deliver the best car buying experience. 
With that, I will open up the call for questions. So, Victoria?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016

componenttext: A question on the search engine optimization that you've been working on, I think, earnestly this year. I guess I'm a little surprised that Web traffic is flattish given that. So can you give us an update kind of where you stand on search engine optimization and how much of a driver that might really be going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Sharon. So SEO is a big focus for us. The things that we've done so far this year to really focus on that is, first of all, the website which we've talked about in the past. In addition to the website here recently, we've been working on som
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Sharon. So SEO is a big focus for us. The things that we've done so far this year to really focus on that is, first of all, the website which we've talked about in the past. In addition to the website here recently, we've been working on some of the design of the website to make sure that search engines can get the information in a quick, time-sensitive fashion so that they can pull all the relevant data down. So that's something that we've been working on here more recently. We've also been publishing some content that our customers want and expect. But this is an area -- now that we've got the website up, we've made some tweaks to it, this is an area that we think still has a lot of opportunity going forward.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Nagel with Oppenheimer.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: My question, I'm going to -- it's on used car unit comps. Two parts. I'm going to shove it together. First off, a number of retailers across the board have discussed some sales disruptions at their chains around the recent presidential election. So I know
componenttext: My question, I'm going to -- it's on used car unit comps. Two parts. I'm going to shove it together. First off, a number of retailers across the board have discussed some sales disruptions at their chains around the recent presidential election. So I know it's not typical for CarMax to talk about inter-quarter trends, but I thought maybe you could at least -- maybe you could discuss that. And then the second question, also relating to car sales. You talked a lot about in the prepared comments about some of the internal initiatives. We've clearly seen a sequential improvement in used car unit comps over the past few quarters. From a market standpoint, has CarMax started to benefit yet from the supply of vehicles, including within the industry?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Brian. So on the first question, I really don't have a comment on that and the Trump effect. On the second part of the question, as it relates to the supply, I absolutely think that we're starting to see the supply come back in the auctions, and I th
componenttext: Yes, Brian. So on the first question, I really don't have a comment on that and the Trump effect. On the second part of the question, as it relates to the supply, I absolutely think that we're starting to see the supply come back in the auctions, and I think that's a good thing for CarMax. As that supply comes back, it helps to drive the difference in price between a new car and a late-model used car. So while I didn't highlight that as one of the factors in the prepared remarks, I absolutely think that that's also a contributing factor.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison with Baird.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's on the wholesale business, which fell a little bit. Do you think you're seeing your fair share of appraisal traffic? Or are sellers starting to use some of these alternate channels, which, again, you may have access to with your new strategy? And the
componenttext: It's on the wholesale business, which fell a little bit. Do you think you're seeing your fair share of appraisal traffic? Or are sellers starting to use some of these alternate channels, which, again, you may have access to with your new strategy? And then on a related note, how does the increase in lease activity, we've got a lot of more leased cars today, impact your opportunity for appraisal given those sellers -- or those less used are not selling a car?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. On the wholesale piece, I think that's more indicative of what I talked about in the early remarks that the -- as the new car SAAR works its way through from the recession, the shortage of new cars, for us, that's right in the 7- to 9-year-old vehic
componenttext: Okay. On the wholesale piece, I think that's more indicative of what I talked about in the early remarks that the -- as the new car SAAR works its way through from the recession, the shortage of new cars, for us, that's right in the 7- to 9-year-old vehicles, and you know that's right in the sweet spot of wholesale. And we saw the same phenomenon earlier on when those cars were 0 to 4. We saw less of them coming through as appraisal traffic. We expect and we're seeing the same thing come through in the 7- to 9-year-old vehicles. So we think that's more of a factor of what's in play there. And I'm sorry, the second question, what was it in regards to lease activity?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: With the increase in overall lease activity, there are a lot of people who have cars that are leased and not, therefore, for sale. Does that impact your ability in the wholesale business to attract those cars?
componenttext: With the increase in overall lease activity, there are a lot of people who have cars that are leased and not, therefore, for sale. Does that impact your ability in the wholesale business to attract those cars?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, I don't think so at this point because, first of all, the leases are just starting to come back at this point, and our wholesale cars are generally older. I do think that the -- as the leases come back, that's a good thing for the core business b
componenttext: Yes, no, I don't think so at this point because, first of all, the leases are just starting to come back at this point, and our wholesale cars are generally older. I do think that the -- as the leases come back, that's a good thing for the core business because that's a lot more selection of younger vehicles. But I don't think that's having an impact on the wholesale business.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Within the SG&A, other than the advertising, which was down for reasons that you stated, your compensation expense was also quite well controlled. It looks like, on an aggregate basis, it was up only 3% year-on-year. And this comp in benefits -- and up --
componenttext: Within the SG&A, other than the advertising, which was down for reasons that you stated, your compensation expense was also quite well controlled. It looks like, on an aggregate basis, it was up only 3% year-on-year. And this comp in benefits -- and up -- really barely up on a 2-year basis in aggregate dollars despite a big increase in stores. Was there anything related to stock comp, which I know you have sometimes called out or any other factor, incentive comp, that would have led this number to be so subdued here in the third quarter?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Yes, the stock comp actually this quarter is the first time it's been at a level so small that it's not worth talking about on a year-over-year basis. But there are some good guys embedded in that comp and benefit number, both some unfavorability las
componenttext: Yes. Yes, the stock comp actually this quarter is the first time it's been at a level so small that it's not worth talking about on a year-over-year basis. But there are some good guys embedded in that comp and benefit number, both some unfavorability last year and some favorability this year. But despite that, we still did leverage that line relative to growth in unit sales. You could probably double the percentage increase, and it would be a rough idea of what we kind of thought a run rate would be.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So in other words, the run rate would have been something like 6% in dollars normalized for everything, which would have led you to good leverage?
componenttext: So in other words, the run rate would have been something like 6% in dollars normalized for everything, which would have led you to good leverage?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's fair to say.
componenttext: Yes, that's fair to say.
