headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Levin with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Michael Levin with Deutsche Bank.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to kind of focus on the loss provision rates at CAF for a second. Is there a way that you can kind of talk about is this factoring in just what you're currently experiencing? Or does this take into account additional expected declines in used
componenttext: Just wanted to kind of focus on the loss provision rates at CAF for a second. Is there a way that you can kind of talk about is this factoring in just what you're currently experiencing? Or does this take into account additional expected declines in used vehicle values moving forward? If it's just now, how much do you think this could continue to move down with used values coming down further from here?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me hit on a couple things. One is used values definitely has an impact on loss rates. But historically, customer behavior has been a much bigger driver. And on an ongoing basis, there's many things moving. So it's hard to say that, that one indiv
componenttext: Yes, let me hit on a couple things. One is used values definitely has an impact on loss rates. But historically, customer behavior has been a much bigger driver. And on an ongoing basis, there's many things moving. So it's hard to say that, that one individual factor could have a dramatic impact on a go-forward basis. So the determination, every quarter, we determine, based on what we know to date rather than based on any kind of speculation, a 12-month look forward on loss expectation. So as I said, it's based on historical information that we have and then how we're performing to date relative to that historical performance. So in a quarter, where things are moving, you're going to see us move that loss expectation. We have not in the past, when things are going good, taken a view to try to get ahead of things, and we haven't done that here as well.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. I mean, maybe to put that in a little bit of perspective, these current rates versus history. I know the accounting was different at the time, but could you kind of compare where these loss rates are versus where we were, say, to the crisis?
componenttext: Got it. I mean, maybe to put that in a little bit of perspective, these current rates versus history. I know the accounting was different at the time, but could you kind of compare where these loss rates are versus where we were, say, to the crisis?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, well, through the crisis, we typically try to manage our portfolio to kind of a 2% to 2.5% cumulative net loss rate. And the average life of these loans, it was -- has been roughly 2 years as a proxy. So during the recession, we saw rate --
componenttext: Yes. I think, well, through the crisis, we typically try to manage our portfolio to kind of a 2% to 2.5% cumulative net loss rate. And the average life of these loans, it was -- has been roughly 2 years as a proxy. So during the recession, we saw rate -- loss rates go to double that in the portfolio. But one thing I think I'd point out. At the one point -- and if you look at the size of the loan loss allowance today, which is a 12-month look, it's 1.10%. So if you double that, you get -- you can see that we're still relative to the range of expectation in the zone that we're looking to originate. And something to remember also is that our Tier 3 test is also part of that over our loan loss provision and represents almost 10% of it.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: 10% of the dollar volume, the $114 million, $115 million of loan loss allowance. So when we step back and look at this, yes, we've seen deterioration relative to recent years, but still not to the point where we were pre-recession.
componenttext: 10% of the dollar volume, the $114 million, $115 million of loan loss allowance. So when we step back and look at this, yes, we've seen deterioration relative to recent years, but still not to the point where we were pre-recession.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you guys have always talked about Tier 3 sales as really being incremental to the core run rate. So my question is, when CAF increases penetration, do you have an estimate what percent of those CAF sales are incremental? So in other words, is CAF finan
componenttext: So you guys have always talked about Tier 3 sales as really being incremental to the core run rate. So my question is, when CAF increases penetration, do you have an estimate what percent of those CAF sales are incremental? So in other words, is CAF financing some people that wouldn't have received credit elsewhere?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the answer to that is yes and not necessarily because we're more aggressive than other folks. But every lender has a way that they look at credit. We think we have ways to look at our applicants and find pockets that work for us that may convert a
componenttext: I think the answer to that is yes and not necessarily because we're more aggressive than other folks. But every lender has a way that they look at credit. We think we have ways to look at our applicants and find pockets that work for us that may convert at a better rate because they got a CAF offer than if they get a Tier 2 or Tier 3 offer. So if you look at the conversion customers based on a CAF offer, based on a Tier 2 or 3 offer, it's much more significant. So you would expect that some of the CAF offers would be incremental just because of that phenomenon.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: But Tom, if you had, let's call it, 7,600 extra unit sales because of the increase in CAF penetration, is there a percentage you would kind of suggest that it was incremental based on what you guys put in your models?
componenttext: But Tom, if you had, let's call it, 7,600 extra unit sales because of the increase in CAF penetration, is there a percentage you would kind of suggest that it was incremental based on what you guys put in your models?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Like I said, there would be some incremental there, but we haven't shared anything as far as fractions. I can tell you that, that percentage, it would not be expected to be up or down relative to recent years.
componenttext: Like I said, there would be some incremental there, but we haven't shared anything as far as fractions. I can tell you that, that percentage, it would not be expected to be up or down relative to recent years.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, right, understood. And then, Tom, related to that, because it has to do with -- on the credit side. Given that the rise in interest rates that we've seen, I would assume that your funding costs have actually increased. And just how should we genera
componenttext: Right, right, understood. And then, Tom, related to that, because it has to do with -- on the credit side. Given that the rise in interest rates that we've seen, I would assume that your funding costs have actually increased. And just how should we generally think about how you guys are planning to manage the spread versus moving interest rates too quickly on customers with a potential for negative unit elasticity?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Well, the nice thing about our business is we can test quickly and we can test pretty accurately in the CAF space. So we have seen an increase in benchmarks in recent weeks. I guess we'll look at it. And we have taken action to raise rates in certain
componenttext: Yes. Well, the nice thing about our business is we can test quickly and we can test pretty accurately in the CAF space. So we have seen an increase in benchmarks in recent weeks. I guess we'll look at it. And we have taken action to raise rates in certain pockets selectively to offset it to some extent. Now what we'll need to do is, as we look at it going forward, to see if the market allows to keep those rates up. Because I've said many times, we're going to be a market lender. We got to provide competitive rates to the customers so nobody is getting sour on CarMax over the finance offer they got. And we'll closely monitor our 3-day payoffs. We'll closely monitor conversion as we ramp up rates and will do what the market allows us. But we're -- this is something that's just ongoing business as usual for CarMax Auto Finance. We're constantly testing ways to maximize the profit and sales coming from that portfolio.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of John Murphy with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a question on supply and the impact potentially on grosses. I mean, it seems like there's a lot of new vehicle dealers that are getting off the stop sale wagon and retailing a lot of used vehicles they kind of had stored on their lots in a short run.
componenttext: Just a question on supply and the impact potentially on grosses. I mean, it seems like there's a lot of new vehicle dealers that are getting off the stop sale wagon and retailing a lot of used vehicles they kind of had stored on their lots in a short run. So I'm just curious what you think about supply there. And then also, as you look at this leasing bubble that's coming over the next 3 years, kind of where do you think we are in that increase in supply? And as you think about those 2 legs of supply increases, what you think you can do as far as holding your grosses? Are you going to stay committed to this $2,100 to $2,200 range as we see that increase in supply really pick up?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, John. So on the first part of the question about the stop sale, look, I don't really think that's much about of an impact. Because there's lots of dealers who've been selling vehicles that have open recalls while you've got the franchise dealers that
componenttext: Yes, John. So on the first part of the question about the stop sale, look, I don't really think that's much about of an impact. Because there's lots of dealers who've been selling vehicles that have open recalls while you've got the franchise dealers that cannot -- while the manufacturers are saying, hey, you can't sell it for that franchise, they still sell other non-brand franchise at those stores. So for me, that's not really -- I don't really see that as either a positive or negative. I think just continuing on. As far as the leasing, I said earlier, we're seeing more vehicles come back from the leasing channels, and we think it'll continue through next year and even into the year after that. And I think we've proven over time that we've been able to hold our margins throughout many different cycles. Now the only caveat that I would give there is you know we constantly do testing. And if we think that moving that margin down would more than pay for itself in units, then we would look at that. And so we'll continue to test, but we feel confident that we can continue to maintain those gross profit margins.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: And if I can just follow up. I mean, would we simply think that if you drop your gross by 10%, you would expect to get at least a 10% pickup in volume or else you wouldn't do it, is that correct? Meaning -- or 11% increase in volume to offset that drop in
componenttext: And if I can just follow up. I mean, would we simply think that if you drop your gross by 10%, you would expect to get at least a 10% pickup in volume or else you wouldn't do it, is that correct? Meaning -- or 11% increase in volume to offset that drop in gross? How we should think about it?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We would want to see total gross more than offset the drop than what we saw, so it would have to be a win on total gross.
componenttext: Yes. We would want to see total gross more than offset the drop than what we saw, so it would have to be a win on total gross.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Montani with Evercore.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Mike Montani with Evercore.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to ask if I could and apologize if I missed it. But what are you seeing now in terms of SUV truck penetration? I think last year was 23% by your measures, and I was looking for it to be maybe the low 30s. Could you talk about that?
componenttext: Just wanted to ask if I could and apologize if I missed it. But what are you seeing now in terms of SUV truck penetration? I think last year was 23% by your measures, and I was looking for it to be maybe the low 30s. Could you talk about that?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our large SUV mix for the quarter was up. Year-over-year, it's about 25.7%. Versus last year's third quarter, it was 23.3%, so it's about 250 basis points. It's up about 1 point from the second quarter of this year. So the mix is up a little bit,
componenttext: Yes. So our large SUV mix for the quarter was up. Year-over-year, it's about 25.7%. Versus last year's third quarter, it was 23.3%, so it's about 250 basis points. It's up about 1 point from the second quarter of this year. So the mix is up a little bit, which would inherently drive our ASPs up a little bit. But then because we had a shift in some of the older vehicles, that brought the ASPs down as well as acquisition prices -- lower acquisition prices brought it down. So SUV mix was up a little bit.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. Can you talk a little bit about sourcing and how it's trended in terms of buys that you would do at appraisal lanes versus auction and other areas? And just thinking about big picture, it would seem that you'd be in a better position
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. Can you talk a little bit about sourcing and how it's trended in terms of buys that you would do at appraisal lanes versus auction and other areas? And just thinking about big picture, it would seem that you'd be in a better position to assort and merchandise given that acquisition cost has come down. So I just wanted to see how that's playing out.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is this in particular, the large SUVs or just in general?
componenttext: Is this in particular, the large SUVs or just in general?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, just in general.
componenttext: No, just in general.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, I think what we're seeing out there is what we typically would see this time of the year with fall depreciation. And I think the fall depreciation, obviously, is going to lower the acquisition prices. Again, that's a -- we feel like that's a
componenttext: Yes. I mean, I think what we're seeing out there is what we typically would see this time of the year with fall depreciation. And I think the fall depreciation, obviously, is going to lower the acquisition prices. Again, that's a -- we feel like that's a good thing for us because as the acquisition prices go down, we just can pass those lower prices onto the customers, and there's a bigger delta between new cars and late-model used cars. So we think it's good.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016

componenttext: I wanted to ask about third-party lead channel writers, where you stand with those. And did you do anything different this quarter with the lead generators?

componenttext: Yes. So the -- we're -- we have all of our inventory listed on for the quarter. It was on CarGurus, and that was the only site that we were -- that we had our inventory listed on during the third quarter. Now we'll constantly's test some different things, but that was the only one during the quarter.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask, and I know it's early. But certainly, we're getting a lot of questions and we hosted a call yesterday on the subject matter, in fact. I wanted to understand your thinking and maybe what you're hearing from your advisers as it relates to t
componenttext: I wanted to ask, and I know it's early. But certainly, we're getting a lot of questions and we hosted a call yesterday on the subject matter, in fact. I wanted to understand your thinking and maybe what you're hearing from your advisers as it relates to tax planning for next year and maybe some of the pushes and pulls as you think about the potential deductibility of CapEx, of PP&E, maybe the reversal of deducting interest expense and so forth as well as the reduction in corporate tax rates. So just kind of any strategy thoughts there would be helpful in helping us sort of frame how you guys are thinking about it relative to peers even.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, James, since you had a call yesterday, maybe you should brief us on it because you probably have more information than we do. We really don't have any thoughts at this point. I mean, it's also new, and there's so much up in the air. It's just -- it'
componenttext: Well, James, since you had a call yesterday, maybe you should brief us on it because you probably have more information than we do. We really don't have any thoughts at this point. I mean, it's also new, and there's so much up in the air. It's just -- it's too early, too early to really talk about.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bill Armstrong with CL King & Associates.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you mentioned a small increase in overall traffic into the stores, but you also had a reduction in appraisal traffic. Are you seeing any change in consumer behavior in terms of fewer people coming in with trade-ins? Or what do you think explains for th
componenttext: So you mentioned a small increase in overall traffic into the stores, but you also had a reduction in appraisal traffic. Are you seeing any change in consumer behavior in terms of fewer people coming in with trade-ins? Or what do you think explains for that apparent disparity?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, like you said, we saw a small increase in store traffic, and I talked a little bit about store traffic last quarter and that you really can't look at just store traffic by itself. You really have to look at Web traffic and especially for us,
componenttext: Yes. I think, like you said, we saw a small increase in store traffic, and I talked a little bit about store traffic last quarter and that you really can't look at just store traffic by itself. You really have to look at Web traffic and especially for us, leads and store traffic and -- to understand the overall big picture. Consumers are a lot more educated. We know that of the consumers that buy a vehicle from us, 9 out of 10 of them have already done a lot of research on carmax.com. So they're already much better educated. I think on the difference between getting a little bit more store traffic in and the appraisal traffic down, again, lot of it is tied to what we're seeing as the SAAR rate works its way through the bubble. And I think that's a main driver of why you see some of the appraisal traffic down.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Because they are getting less money...
componenttext: Because they are getting less money...

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just because there's not as many -- there aren't as many. So like I talked about earlier, the 7- to 9-year-old vehicles, there just aren't as many as there were because 7 to 9 years ago, the new car sales rates were going down. So if those -- if there are
componenttext: Just because there's not as many -- there aren't as many. So like I talked about earlier, the 7- to 9-year-old vehicles, there just aren't as many as there were because 7 to 9 years ago, the new car sales rates were going down. So if those -- if there aren't as many customers that have those cars, they're obviously not coming in to get them appraised.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Seth Basham with Wedbush Securities.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You guys called out an increase in the mix of sales to higher credit customers and their supply of late model vehicles. But at the same time, you're selling a higher mix of older vehicles. Can you help square away that dynamic, which has occurred for the
componenttext: You guys called out an increase in the mix of sales to higher credit customers and their supply of late model vehicles. But at the same time, you're selling a higher mix of older vehicles. Can you help square away that dynamic, which has occurred for the last 2 quarters now?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think contrary to what a lot of people think is that your Tier 3 customers are going to be the ones buying your late-model -- or your older, less expensive vehicles. And for us, that's just not the case. The majority of the vehicles that we sell ar
componenttext: Yes. I think contrary to what a lot of people think is that your Tier 3 customers are going to be the ones buying your late-model -- or your older, less expensive vehicles. And for us, that's just not the case. The majority of the vehicles that we sell are in -- the older, less expensive vehicles are to non-Tier 3 customers. So I think what it says is that the consumers are still out there looking for a great deal, and they've opted to go a little bit older and a little bit cheaper. So I think that kind of explains the dynamic. It's not just Tier 3 customers that would be buying older, more -- less expensive vehicles.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And just as a follow-up, considering the increased supply of late-model vehicles, would you expect your mix to shift back to that direction over the next few quarters?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And just as a follow-up, considering the increased supply of late-model vehicles, would you expect your mix to shift back to that direction over the next few quarters?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Seth, we all sell whatever the consumers want. So if the consumers want that late-model vehicle, then we'll absolutely adjust our inventory accordingly. If they want to continue to buy older vehicles, then we'll -- you won't see that change. So it just de
componenttext: Seth, we all sell whatever the consumers want. So if the consumers want that late-model vehicle, then we'll absolutely adjust our inventory accordingly. If they want to continue to buy older vehicles, then we'll -- you won't see that change. So it just depends. It's all driven by consumer demand.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Whiston with Morningstar.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Whiston with Morningstar.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to talk about the future on e-commerce and the pilot programs you're doing. Obviously, there's -- there are consumers who want this process to be very easy. But at the same time, it's still roughly a $20,000 purchase for people. So how willing
componenttext: Just wanted to talk about the future on e-commerce and the pilot programs you're doing. Obviously, there's -- there are consumers who want this process to be very easy. But at the same time, it's still roughly a $20,000 purchase for people. So how willing do you think people are to buy a vehicle without even coming into the store to do a test drive? Is it a small portion of the American public? Is it ultimately going to be a lot of people? Just love to hear your thoughts on that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, no, it's a good question, David. And I think you hit the nail on head. It's not an easy transaction. It's a complicated transaction. That being said, I do think there's a small subset of customers that want to try that experience. I think for us, we
componenttext: Yes, no, it's a good question, David. And I think you hit the nail on head. It's not an easy transaction. It's a complicated transaction. That being said, I do think there's a small subset of customers that want to try that experience. I think for us, we certainly are going to meet those customers wherever and however they want to do business. But I think more importantly is that I think consumers will want to do more of the transaction online in the near term. And we will have the ability to not only do more of the transaction online, but it will be a seamless integration into the store. And I think that's really what we're focused on. In addition to giving the customers the ability to do everything, it really is, okay, you want to do part of it online, let's make sure it's a great experience. And then when you walk into the store, we just pick up from where you left off, and that's really what we're focused on. I think that's really where the consumer demand is going to be in the near term.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And for my follow-up, I wanted to ask Tom about buybacks. Stocks have been near 52-week high. Are those still full steam ahead?
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And for my follow-up, I wanted to ask Tom about buybacks. Stocks have been near 52-week high. Are those still full steam ahead?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Pardon me, I didn't hear the tail end to your question.
componenttext: Pardon me, I didn't hear the tail end to your question.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: The stocks near 52-week high. Are buybacks still full steam ahead? Or are you looking to be a bit more cautious on that going forward?
componenttext: The stocks near 52-week high. Are buybacks still full steam ahead? Or are you looking to be a bit more cautious on that going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. As we've discussed before, we take kind of an enlightened averaging in methodology to repurchases. So at any given time, we're trying to average into the market and maintain our capital structure in the zone that we've targeted. You saw that in this q
componenttext: No. As we've discussed before, we take kind of an enlightened averaging in methodology to repurchases. So at any given time, we're trying to average into the market and maintain our capital structure in the zone that we've targeted. You saw that in this quarter, we bought back $199 million versus $125 million in Q2. That did represent a little bit of a step-up in aggressiveness because we saw some weakness in the stock price. But the parameters we put in place allow for a little bit of that. It allows us to be a little more aggressive when the price is weak and a little more conservative in the volume when the price is looking strong. But we intend to be in the market on a regular basis.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Paresh Jain with Morgan Stanley.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question on inventory sourcing. Would it be fair to say that you currently source about 40% of your inventory from auctions? How has that number changed in the last 2 years if it has changed at all?
componenttext: Just a quick question on inventory sourcing. Would it be fair to say that you currently source about 40% of your inventory from auctions? How has that number changed in the last 2 years if it has changed at all?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when we think about self-sufficiency, which is opposite of the auctions but actually getting it through our own appraisal lane, we've given the range of 40% to 50%. We're at the lower end of that range, but we're higher than we were 1 year ago, an
componenttext: Yes. So when we think about self-sufficiency, which is opposite of the auctions but actually getting it through our own appraisal lane, we've given the range of 40% to 50%. We're at the lower end of that range, but we're higher than we were 1 year ago, and we're very similar to where we were last quarter.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And a follow-up on the profitability of the vehicles sourced from auction. Has the gap in profitably with those sourced through trade-ins changed at all in the last 2 years? The gap is about hundreds of dollars between the 2.
componenttext: Got it. And a follow-up on the profitability of the vehicles sourced from auction. Has the gap in profitably with those sourced through trade-ins changed at all in the last 2 years? The gap is about hundreds of dollars between the 2.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: So the vehicles that we source through our appraisal lane are still more profitable than the ones that we source off-site. As you can imagine, you don't have transportation fees. You don't have folks going on incurring expenses, that kind of thing. So the
componenttext: So the vehicles that we source through our appraisal lane are still more profitable than the ones that we source off-site. As you can imagine, you don't have transportation fees. You don't have folks going on incurring expenses, that kind of thing. So there's still about the same amount of profitability over what they were before.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And no change in the last 2 years on that gap?
componenttext: Got it. And no change in the last 2 years on that gap?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't speak really off top of my head on the last 2 years, but I -- it's been very similar.
componenttext: I can't speak really off top of my head on the last 2 years, but I -- it's been very similar.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Bottiglieri with Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Bottiglieri with Wolfe Research.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Did you guys give out the 0 to 4 mix this quarter like you historically have and how that compares versus last year?
componenttext: Did you guys give out the 0 to 4 mix this quarter like you historically have and how that compares versus last year?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: 0 to 4, we were down slightly 81 to 78.
componenttext: 0 to 4, we were down slightly 81 to 78.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got you, okay. And then as a follow-up to that, given the scarcity of those cars given supply, wondering if you're holding back more of those vehicles from wholesale to sell it used if the 2 are related at all?
componenttext: Got you, okay. And then as a follow-up to that, given the scarcity of those cars given supply, wondering if you're holding back more of those vehicles from wholesale to sell it used if the 2 are related at all?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, actually, I think the supply is starting to come back on those, so we're seeing more out there. But as far as the selectivity, we're always looking at selectivity when we purchase a car, whether we designate it wholesale or we put it through. I woul
componenttext: Well, actually, I think the supply is starting to come back on those, so we're seeing more out there. But as far as the selectivity, we're always looking at selectivity when we purchase a car, whether we designate it wholesale or we put it through. I would say, at this point, when you're talking about 0 to 4-year-old cars, we really haven't changed anything recently as far as selectivity goes.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'm sorry, I meant holding back the 7 to 9s, where you had tighter supply. Have you held back some of those from wholesale to retail at this point?
componenttext: I'm sorry, I meant holding back the 7 to 9s, where you had tighter supply. Have you held back some of those from wholesale to retail at this point?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's -- I don't think it's considerably different than what we've been doing before. It really depends on the vehicles as they roll through. If they're good quality vehicles and we can turn them into CarMax cars, then we're going to do that. But we look
componenttext: That's -- I don't think it's considerably different than what we've been doing before. It really depends on the vehicles as they roll through. If they're good quality vehicles and we can turn them into CarMax cars, then we're going to do that. But we look at selectivity every single quarter and make the decisions that are appropriate at that point. I wouldn't say that this one's necessarily -- there hasn't been a big change in this quarter versus other quarters.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And one quick follow-up. Two questions have been asked on auction supply. It seems to me just looking at the auction data that there seems to be a mix of improvement in SUV and truck availability at the auction lanes. Is that -- has it been a
componenttext: Okay, great. And one quick follow-up. Two questions have been asked on auction supply. It seems to me just looking at the auction data that there seems to be a mix of improvement in SUV and truck availability at the auction lanes. Is that -- has it been a driver for your business in terms of increased SUV and truck penetration?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's -- when you see that increased inventory, that will drive the prices down, and that probably has a factor. It is a factor into whether customers want to buy that car depending on how attractive it is from a price standpoint. But again,
componenttext: Well, I think it's -- when you see that increased inventory, that will drive the prices down, and that probably has a factor. It is a factor into whether customers want to buy that car depending on how attractive it is from a price standpoint. But again, we really go off of customer demand. And if they're looking for large SUVs and we can get them at prices that they'll pay, then we're going to -- we'll put them on our front line. Just this quarter, folks were looking more for older, cheaper cars, and so that's what we did.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: You do have a follow-up from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: You do have a follow-up from the line of Matt Fassler with Goldman Sachs.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: If we were to be able to accurately calculate how new space productivity looked versus a year ago just in terms of raw numbers, what do you think we would see? And how did new store performance compare to your expectations?
componenttext: If we were to be able to accurately calculate how new space productivity looked versus a year ago just in terms of raw numbers, what do you think we would see? And how did new store performance compare to your expectations?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're pleased with new store performance. As we've talked about in the past, it's difficult to talk about store productivity when you look at the size of stores that we're building, when you throw in the small formats, when you look at going into new
componenttext: Yes. We're pleased with new store performance. As we've talked about in the past, it's difficult to talk about store productivity when you look at the size of stores that we're building, when you throw in the small formats, when you look at going into new metro markets where awareness is at different levels. You're going to have different ramping up. All the new stores are reaching profitability quicker than the old stores because of the GPU, and they're also meeting all of our internal rate of return. So we're pleased with new store productivity.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then secondly, I know you're far more focused on your customers than on your competition. But we did see one piece of competitive fall-out with one of the online -- one of the higher profile albeit small online start-ups essentially ceasing op
componenttext: Got it. And then secondly, I know you're far more focused on your customers than on your competition. But we did see one piece of competitive fall-out with one of the online -- one of the higher profile albeit small online start-ups essentially ceasing operations in its prior form and merging with another company. What's your sense about the competitive environment online? Is it intensifying? Are you starting to see any signs of more rationalization in terms of the kind of offers that your customers can pursue away from CarMax?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think, first of all, on the -- just to comment on your first part about the online competitor kind of ceasing operations. I think it goes back to something I talked about earlier, which this is not a simple business. This is a hard business. It's n
componenttext: Yes. I think, first of all, on the -- just to comment on your first part about the online competitor kind of ceasing operations. I think it goes back to something I talked about earlier, which this is not a simple business. This is a hard business. It's not easy to go out, source inventory for the right amount. It's not easy to go out and put a cash offer on every single car. And I think that's just an indication of why some of these folks are maybe struggling. I think competition is hot in both the online space and the traditional. And I think our challenge is to make sure that we continue to leverage the equities that's made us successful and make them even better and leverage our data and our processes and our systems and our people to continue to widen the gap between us and our competition. And like I said earlier, I mean, we've got 23 years worth of experience and 23 years worth of data, and we're leveraging that data and tapping into it in ways that we haven't been able to and haven't done in the past. So although the competition is hot and heavy, we feel really good about the position that we're in. And I think, ultimately, to be as successful as we can be, we do need to make sure that we can be in the online space. But equally important is we got to be in the brick-and-mortar space. I think you have to do both very, very well, and I think we're positioning ourselves to do just that.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next follow-up comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next follow-up comes from the line of Scot Ciccarelli with RBC Capital Markets.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I guess, just a bit of follow-up on Matt's question. But I guess, what I'm trying to figure out is on some of these delivery tests, are there any key differences to what you are trying to do versus the guys like Vroom and Beepi? And also, how is it that y
componenttext: I guess, just a bit of follow-up on Matt's question. But I guess, what I'm trying to figure out is on some of these delivery tests, are there any key differences to what you are trying to do versus the guys like Vroom and Beepi? And also, how is it that you're allowed to close a transaction outside of the dealership? Because, I guess, I was always under the impression just legally, you had to close the transaction at a dealership.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So on the second part of your question, there are some states where you can't close it outside of the dealership. Our delivery -- where we're doing our test, that's obviously not the case. I think as far as differences, one of the difference in our h
componenttext: Yes. So on the second part of your question, there are some states where you can't close it outside of the dealership. Our delivery -- where we're doing our test, that's obviously not the case. I think as far as differences, one of the difference in our home delivery test is you don't have to buy the vehicle before we bring it out to you. We'll bring it to you. You can test-drive it at your home. And if you decide to purchase it, we can do the transaction right there. That's different than any other tests that are out there, where they make you purchase the vehicle before it's brought out to you. And again, it's a small test work, trying to understand exactly what the customers want. And the good thing is we can adjust the test as we move forward. Scot, I think -- Tom was just saying, he thinks maybe one with the online competitors might allow you to...

componenttext: Yes. There's one that allows you to test-drive, but they also are making you give up your car and try to sell it.

componenttext: There is one competitor that allows you to test-drive as a purchaser, but they're a C2C enabler, and the other part of their business offer is that they take possession of your car when -- while you're attempting to sell it so you don't have use of your vehicle.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016

componenttext: Yes. So Jamie, I think it's a little early to be talking about the differences. And outside of that, all the other online capabilities, customers are utilizing them and then transitioning into the store. componenttext: And I guess, the question is, do you start to cycle the pullback in March, April, if memory serves? And then also, what are you seeing in terms of lender behavior from third-parties? Does it appear stable at this level? Or is there further pullback that you can see now?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. As far cycling, I think in the current period right now, we'll begin to cycle over the trend we began observing in traffic. So remember, we've been talking for several quarters about seeing fewer application volume at the lower end of the credit spe
componenttext: Sure. As far cycling, I think in the current period right now, we'll begin to cycle over the trend we began observing in traffic. So remember, we've been talking for several quarters about seeing fewer application volume at the lower end of the credit spectrum. That started somewhere around this time last year. So that portion of the decrease, we'll start to see some cycling. As I mentioned in my comments, the most recent tiding we saw was in mid-Q1 from our Tier 3 -- at one of our Tier 3 lenders. Since that time, they have been behaving very consistently. If we look at conversion of customers in the Tier 3 space since mid -- the middle of Q1, it's been very consistent. It's below last year, but it's been consistent. So yes, all else equal in April, you'll start to see us rolling over that on a year-over-year basis. In the Tier 2 space, it's almost exactly the opposite phenomenon. Conversion has been consistently better than last year since the first quarter. And as I mentioned, they're doing a great job of converting the volume that they see. A lot of -- the mix dynamic we're seeing is -- a lot of it's from the customer traffic coming through the door. That's why CAF is up. That's why other is up, and that's why the other -- the Tier 2 and 3 are down.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016

componenttext: I guess, are you guys happy with the third-party subprime where it's at now at around 10%? Or could we consider new lenders that might help to grow that again?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think it's going to be a matter of what -- a lot of -- it's going to be a matter of where customers come through. We're happy today with the amount we're investing in the Tier 3 space, which is about $1,000 a car of margin that we give away in order to
componenttext: I think it's going to be a matter of what -- a lot of -- it's going to be a matter of where customers come through. We're happy today with the amount we're investing in the Tier 3 space, which is about $1,000 a car of margin that we give away in order to enable those transactions. The Tier 3 space is a lot more fragmented than the more prime space in auto lending. We're happy with the performance of our partners. We test other partners occasionally. And to the extent one can add value, we consider bringing them in the mix. But I think if you just step back and think about our current base as a platform for growing, it's a much more profitable dynamic to grow at this mix than to have the mix migrate back to something higher.

componenttextpreview: Just thinking about the fact that most of your customers are shopping online before visiting the stores. As you consider the store model of the future, what kind of changes are you thinking about? We noticed, for example, in the Seattle area, you're openi
componenttext: Just thinking about the fact that most of your customers are shopping online before visiting the stores. As you consider the store model of the future, what kind of changes are you thinking about? We noticed, for example, in the Seattle area, you're opening a pretty large sort of mega store, which is likely a reconditioning-focused facility in a lower cost area. Is that something you'll consider in other markets, too?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think what you're seeing in Seattle is more driven by the market dynamics and what's available land-wise. Obviously, we're looking at our store prototypes. We've got the small format store out there. We -- you've seen we've opened more of those her
componenttext: Yes. I think what you're seeing in Seattle is more driven by the market dynamics and what's available land-wise. Obviously, we're looking at our store prototypes. We've got the small format store out there. We -- you've seen we've opened more of those here more recently. I think it's something that we'll stay close to as we better understand the customer desire for transacting more and more parts of the transaction online. But I'll tell you, it's not like we have 1,000 stores around the country. We have 169 stores, and I think they're all strategically located. And the products we sell, you need space, and you need places to build those cars. So I feel very comfortable with our growth strategy, what we've done so far, and I feel very comfortable with what we've got in the pipeline currently.

componenttext: I wanted to just follow up on your comments about increasing applications at the high end of the credit spectrum. And you said you also bought some market data that you were taking to look at. Just wondering if you could maybe put a few numbers behind what you're seeing at CarMax, how that compares to what you're seeing within the market. Are you kind of outperforming those increases? And then how we might think about higher credits being a larger percentage of your mix impacting loss rates going forward.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the last one. We'll see how it impacts loss rates going forward depending on the environment. It's way too early to tell. I'm not -- we're not in a position to give you any numbers regarding this, but I can give you a little color around w
componenttext: I'll start with the last one. We'll see how it impacts loss rates going forward depending on the environment. It's way too early to tell. I'm not -- we're not in a position to give you any numbers regarding this, but I can give you a little color around what we looked at. We bought data related to auto inquiries, meaning, folks that are hitting the bureaus in conjunction with an application for credit for an automobile for the past several years both through submissions to captives and submissions or inquiries through the major dealer groups. And while we likely started feeling the phenomenon a little earlier, the data is telling us that the lower and lower middle part of the credit spectrum has seen a year-over-year decline in recent quarters for everybody. As far as the higher credit folks and the growth there, our data appears to show that we are -- we're growing a little bit stronger than the rest of them. But there could be a lot of factors between new car mix, used car mix, et cetera, that drive that. I don't know if there's anything to really take away from that.

componenttext: Good morning. My name is Victoria, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the CarMax Fiscal 2017 Third Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the call over to Katharine Kenny, Vice President, Investor Relations.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, and good morning. Thank you all for joining our fiscal third quarter earnings conference call. On the call with me today is Bill Nash, our President and Chief Executive Officer, who by the way, is very proud, along with Cliff Wood's and our man
componenttext:
Thank you, and good morning. Thank you all for joining our fiscal third quarter earnings conference call. On the call with me today is Bill Nash, our President and Chief Executive Officer, who by the way, is very proud, along with Cliff Wood's and our many CarMax JMU alumni, of the Dukes, who are playing in the FCS National Championship. And of course, with us is Tom Reedy, our Executive Vice President and CFO.
Before we begin, let me remind you that our statements today regarding the company's future business plans, prospects and financial performance are forward-looking statements that we make pursuant to the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. These statements are based on management's current knowledge and assumptions about future events that involve risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from our expectations. In providing projections and other forward-looking statements, the company disclaims any intent or obligation to update them.
For additional information on important factors that could affect these expectations, please see the company's annual report on Form 10-K for the fiscal year ended February 29, 2016, filed with the SEC. [Operator Instructions] 
Thank you so much. I'll turn the call over to Bill.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, everyone. Katharine, I was not going to mention JMU since we're a little bit more team-agnostic now that Folliard has left. But since you did mention it, I'm excited about it, and I wish them well. For today's call, I will first review the
componenttext:
Good morning, everyone. Katharine, I was not going to mention JMU since we're a little bit more team-agnostic now that Folliard has left. But since you did mention it, I'm excited about it, and I wish them well. 
For today's call, I will first review the key highlights of the quarter, then I'll turn the call over to Tom Reedy to cover financing. And then I'll close the call before Q&A with a brief update on some of our new initiatives.
As you read in our press release this morning, our total used unit comps for the third quarter increased by 5.4%, and total used units grew by 9.1%. Total used unit comps were driven by a strong improvement in conversion as well as by a small increase in store traffic. We believe the increase in used units was due to a variety of factors. These include improved store execution, our website redesign and related online capabilities, which have made it easier for our customers to submit leads. We continue to be very pleased with our core business as we again saw headwind from Tier 3 sales. We estimate used unit comps for our non-Tier 3 customers were again significantly stronger this quarter at 9.8%. 
Our total Web traffic was flat compared with the prior year quarter, while Web leads performed well in the quarter. We continue to see a positive response to the website with increased activity, such as engagement with a search tool and car pages as well as submitting leads. Our goal is to drive leads and convert more customers from the website to the store and finally, to a sale. 
Our wholesale units declined by approximately 2% in the third quarter. This was driven by a decrease in appraisal traffic, partially offset by the growth in our store base and a higher buy rate. The decline in industry new vehicle sales during the recession is affecting the supply of older vehicles. Remember, we saw this dynamic in our core retail business following the recession. 
We continue to maintain a consistent gross profit per used unit at $2,155 compared to $2,160 in the third quarter of last year. Gross profit per wholesale unit decreased to $900 compared to $949 in last year's third quarter. Again, as we reported in the second quarter, last year's wholesale gross profit per unit was the highest recorded in any third quarter. So like last quarter, it was again a tough comparison.
A few other topics before I turn the call over to Tom. As a percentage of our sales mix, 0 to 4-year-old vehicles fell this quarter to 78% compared to 81% last year, once again, as a result of higher customer demand for older and less expensive vehicles. SG&A expenses for the third quarter increased 5.7% to $357 million. This growth partially reflects the 12% or 18-store increase in our base since the beginning of the third quarter of last year. While we reported leverage of approximately $74 per unit, remember that our advertising expense in last year's third quarter was significantly higher due to the production and rollout of our new brand launch. Absent this increased spend in the prior year, leverage was modestly positive. Other overhead costs were up year-over-year, reflecting our continued investment in strategic initiatives. 
Now I'll turn the call over to Tom.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. In recent quarters, we have discussed the trend of year-over-year increases in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and less application volume at the lower end, and we saw this
componenttext:
Thanks, Bill. Good morning, everybody. In recent quarters, we have discussed the trend of year-over-year increases in credit applications from customers at the higher end of the credit spectrum and less application volume at the lower end, and we saw this continuing in the third quarter. We recently purchased credit bureau data related to auto credit inquiries in the marketplace, and our analysis of this data suggests that this trend is not unique to CarMax. This application mix drove growth in cash net penetration, which increased to 45% compared with 43.3% in last year's third quarter.
Net loans originated in the quarter rose more than 9% year-over-year to $1.3 billion due to a combination of CarMax sales growth and a higher penetration, partially offset by our lower average selling prices. In addition, as you'd expect, the higher credit mix of applications drove growth in the portion of sales where customers paid cash or bought their own financing. 
Tier 2 penetration fell year-over-year in the quarter to 15.7% from 16.9%. But just as we said last quarter, our Tier 2 lenders continue to provide strong offers based on what we have observed in customer conversion. Tier 3 sales mix was 10.2% of used unit sales compared to 13.8% for the same period last year. This decrease in penetration continues to be due to the same factors credits hiking early in the year and lower application volumes. Performance of our Tier 3 partners, however, has been consistent since the middle of Q1. 
GAAP income fell 3.2% to about $89 million compared to the third quarter of fiscal 2016, while average managed receivables grew by 11% to $10.3 billion. The provision for loan losses increased, and the portfolio interest margin decreased very modestly.
During the third quarter, we continue to see higher loss experience. Our ending allowance for loan losses at $115 million was 1.1% of ending managed receivables compared to 1.08% last quarter and 0.97% in last year's third quarter. This level of losses is a departure from our experience in recent years. However, losses in the last several years have been quite favorable. The current level of loan loss reserve is consistent with our range of expectations given our origination strategy and portfolio mix.
For loans originated during the quarter, the weighted average contract rate charged to customers was flat year-over-year at 7.3%. Total interest margin declined slightly to 5.8% of average managed receivables. This compared to 6% in the third quarter of last year and 5.9% sequentially from Q2. And during the quarter, we repurchased 3.8 million shares for $199 million. As of the end of Q3, we had $1.7 billion remaining in our stock repurchase authorization. 
Now I'll turn the call back over to Bill.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. During the third quarter, we opened 6 stores, including 2 in new markets, Boise and Grand Rapids. We also opened 4 stores in existing markets: Philadelphia, Daytona and 2 in San Francisco. Late in the current fourth quarter, we expect to open
componenttext:
Thanks, Tom. During the third quarter, we opened 6 stores, including 2 in new markets, Boise and Grand Rapids. We also opened 4 stores in existing markets: Philadelphia, Daytona and 2 in San Francisco. Late in the current fourth quarter, we expect to open 4 more stores: 2 in our Los Angeles market, 1 in Murrieta, it will include a centralized production auction facilities this quarter, both in Southern California. In addition, we plan to open 2 small format stores in the fourth quarter both in new markets: Mobile, Alabama and Albany, New York. 
Next, I'd like to give an update on our new online offerings and the tests we are conducting to continue to advance the customer experience. First, as we discussed last quarter, we've been testing a new online financing capability that has helped our customers get pre-qualified for a loan. When we talked at the end of the second quarter, we were piloting this product in 13 stores. Towards the end of Q3, we successfully rolled this new capability out to all stores nationwide, and we're pleased with the early results, which includes increased leads. 
Second, we continue to test our home delivery offering in Charlotte, North Carolina. As a reminder, home delivery allows the customers to shop for and buy a car at their convenience without coming into the store. We continue to learn about the customer demand and operational scalability while also ensuring it meets our standards for an exceptional experience. 
The last update is regarding a one store test we'll be conducting in the fourth quarter. We plan to test a new digital solution for customers who are interested in getting an appraisal value for their vehicle by submitting their vehicle information online without having to come into the store. These initiatives position CarMax to deliver more of the car buying experience online, and we remain committed to giving the customers the ability to go between the digital and in-store experience whenever and however they would like. 
While we are constantly working to innovate and improve the business, we are also very focused on being cost-conscious and eliminating waste across the entire organization. We continue to look for new opportunities to ensure we're growing in a way that is in the best interest of our customers, associates and shareholders. 
Like last quarter, I remain confident that we will continue to lead the industry. We have 23 years of experience to build upon to help us excel into the future. With our great associates, our national footprint, our unparalleled inventory, brand strength and continued focus on improving the customer experience both online and in-store, no one is in a better position than CarMax to fully deliver the best car buying experience. 
With that, I will open up the call for questions. So, Victoria?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016

componenttext: A question on the search engine optimization that you've been working on, I think, earnestly this year. I guess I'm a little surprised that Web traffic is flattish given that. So do give us an update kind of where you stand on search engine optimization and how much of a driver that might really be going forward?

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Sharon. So SEO is a big focus for us. The things that we've done so far this year to really focus on that is, first of all, the website which we've talked about in the past. In addition to the website here recently, we've been working on som
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Sharon. So SEO is a big focus for us. The things that we've done so far this year to really focus on that is, first of all, the website which we've talked about in the past. In addition to the website here recently, we've been working on some of the design of the website to make sure that search engines can get the information in a quick, time-sensitive fashion so that they can pull all the relevant data down. So that's something that we've been working on here more recently. We've also been publishing some content that our customers want and expect. But this is an area -- now that we've got the website up, we've made some tweaks to it, this is an area that we think still has a lot of opportunity going forward.

headline: CarMax Inc., Q3 2017 Earnings Call, Dec 20, 2016
